PROCTEXT.PARA: Madam SPEAKER (Hon. Joan Child) took the chair at 10 a.m., and read prayers.

DEBATE.TITLE: PRIVILEGE

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Madam SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr N.A. Brown) raised as a matter of privilege a response he had received from an officer of the Department of Foreign Affairs to a request the honourable member had made under the Freedom of Information Act. In particular, the question of possible intimidation of members in respect of requests under the Act was raised. In order to accord precedence to a motion with respect to a matter of privilege, I must be satisfied that the matter has been raised at the earliest opportunity, and that a prima facie case of breach of privilege has been established. I am satisfied that the matter has been raised at the earliest opportunity.

INTERJECT.PARA: The House may recall that related matters were raised in October 1985 and my predecessor expressed certain views on them. I have considered the honourable member's remarks and I have examined the copy of the letter he received from the Department of Foreign Affairs. I note that no special provisions have apparently been provided in the Act for requests from members, and so, to that extent, there is no provision of the Act to be breached. Going to the question of possible obstruction or intimidation, I understand that members may feel that the arrangements being followed may serve to impede them. Nevertheless, having considered the matter, and having examined the particular words complained of, I do not believe that any action has been taken, or a statement made, which would constitute a prima facie breach of privilege or contempt.

I also remind the House of the general reluctance of the House to extend the ambit of privilege and the belief that the penal jurisdiction should be invoked as sparingly as possible and only when it is considered essential in order to protect the House and its members from substantial interference. I am not prepared to accord precedence to a motion in respect of the matter.

DEBATE.TITLE: INSPECTOR-GENERAL OF INTELLIGENCE AND SECURITY BILL 1986

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Lionel Bowen, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

In May last year the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) presented the final reports of the Royal Commission on Australia's Security and Intelligence Agencies-RCASIA-to the House and stated the Government's initial reaction to them. Since then, considerable effort has been devoted to implementing most of the reforms proposed by Mr Justice Hope and to developing the three Bills I am introducing today.

Madam Speaker, of necessity much of the work of the intelligence and security community is conducted confidentially and goes unnoticed. This intelligence and security community rarely receives public commendation, but its errors, and speculation about its activities, have a way of generating lurid headlines. Much of this speculation cannot be officially debated. It is an irony that the very confidentiality of the agencies' work seems to inspire demands to expose and publicise their activities and that the trust placed in them to conduct their work in confidence creates, in some, a want of trust.

Speculation and ill-advised criticism can negatively affect public perceptions of the agencies. In recognition of this, and in an attempt to counter it, we have seen over the last decade two major reviews of the intelligence and security community pointing to the need for clearer public statements of purpose, more visibility, greater oversight and accountability-all aimed at demystifying and increasing public confidence in the agencies.

In response to the Royal Commission on Intelligence and Security in the mid-seventies, the Fraser Government took some necessary steps towards making the intelligence and security community more accountable and meshing it with the wider processes of government. For example, the charter of the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation was clarified in legislation and a Security Appeals Tribunal was created; the existence of the Australian Secret Intelligence Service, and the Defence Signals Directorate, was formally acknowledged; and bipartisan arrangements were put in place to keep the Opposition informed of significant intelligence and security issues. A change in government has not altered the character of these arrangements, although we strongly believe that further steps are needed to hold the agencies more accountable and to increase public trust in their activities.

This Government has already announced some reforms, in response to the second of the royal commissions by Mr Justice Hope. These, together with the draft legislation being introduced today, will more clearly delineate the functions of the agencies and make them more accountable. I shall not repeat here all the measures announced in the Prime Minister's tabling statement to this House on 22 May 1985. Since then action has been taken to implement a number of the other recommendations. For example:

We have revised ASIS's directive to exclude preparation or training for covert action in the form of special operations or special political action. This will prevent the type of training that led to the Sheraton Hotel incident.

On 27 November 1985 my colleague the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley) announced details of action taken in response to the Royal Commission's recommendation to improve consultation between the Joint Intelligence Organisation and its major customers.

The Office of Security and Intelligence Co-ordination has been established within the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet to provide an independent secretariat to the Security Committee of Cabinet and the Secretaries Committee on Intelligence and Security.

We have also established a National Intelligence Committee, chaired by the Office of National Assessments, and including senior representatives of policy departments and JIO. The Committee advises ONA on the development of its work program, monitors ONA's product and advises it on intelligence needs and priorities.

Additionally, the Government recognises that, under existing arrangements, responsibility for protective security is dispersed among a number of departments and agencies, and none has responsibility for co-ordinating policy in this area. In response to specific RCASIA recommendations the Prime Minister has therefore decided to allocate this responsibility to the Department of the Special Minister of State, which will convene a new high level committee to co-ordinate protective security policy and physical and administrative security measures. There are other measures which, for security reasons, we will not be announcing.

A significant number of key recommendations of the Royal Commission require legislation. The three Bills I am introducing today will allow considerably increased scrutiny of the intelligence and security agencies. But the Government has also ensured that their effectiveness is in no way diminished. Indeed, we are satisfied that, as a result of these measures, public confidence in the agencies will be increased and as a consequence they will become more effective. The measures set out in the Bills are based on the Government's firm belief that the agencies should be accountable. Following close examination, they have been accepted by the agencies.

Before moving to the details of the proposals, I would like again to express the Government's appreciation to Mr Justice Hope. The Government has now considered, and in large part acted upon, all of the recommendations in the Royal Commission's reports. As we have looked more closely at his reports, which deal with some particularly sensitive issues, our appreciation of his contribution has grown. As Attorney-General I shall present shortly a Bill incorporating a number of major reforms relating to ASIO. These include more careful definition and limitation of ASIO's functions and activities, and the establishment of a joint parliamentary committee on ASIO.

I now turn to the proposal for an independent watchdog over all the agencies, which stems from the Australian Labor Party submission to the Royal Commission, and which was further developed by Mr Justice Hope. The Government's aims in establishing an Office of Inspector-General of Intelligence and Security include assisting Ministers with the oversight and review of: Firstly, the compliance with the law by Australian intelligence and security agencies; secondly, the propriety of their particular activities; thirdly, the effectiveness and appropriateness of certain procedures; and, finally, certain other aspects of the activities and procedures of some of those agencies, for example, concerning employee grievances. Our aims also include assisting Ministers in ensuring that the activities of the agencies are consistent with human rights and allowing for review of certain directions given to ASIO by the Attorney-General.

While the emphasis is on the Inspector- General's assistance to Ministers, elements of the Inspector-General's work will be available for parliamentary and public scrutiny. Provision is made for an annual report to be furnished to the Prime Minister, with a copy to the Leader of the Opposition. Edited as necessary on grounds of security, defence, international relations and privacy, the report will be laid before each House of the Parliament. A person of exceptional skills and particular qualities will be required for the Office. Being a new position, having a pivotal role in Australia's security and intelligence machinery, its occupant will deal with highly sensitive issues and respond to a range of ministerial and public requests. In recognition of the importance of this appointment, the Bill requires that before a recommendation on appointment is made to the Governor-General, the Prime Minister shall consult with the Leader of the Opposition. As the Prime Minister mentioned in May last year, the Office will be within his portfolio. Initially, it will comprise a small staff, but the Government will closely monitor its work load to ensure that staffing remains adequate.

Turning to the functions of the Inspector-General, honourable members will note that the Bill distinguishes between the agencies, both in terms of the Inspector-General's functions and the mechanisms by which inquiries can be instigated. The distinctions are consistent with the functions ascribed to the Inspector-General in the various RCASIA reports, and reflect the different purposes of ASIO as our domestic security intelligence organisation, ASIS and DSD as collectors of external intelligence, and JIO and ONA as assessors of intelligence.

These differing purposes are reflected in the mechanisms for initiating inquiries. For example, the Inspector-General may initiate his own inquiries into the legality or propriety of activities of ASIO, ASIS or DSD, but only the responsible Minister may initiate such an inquiry with respect to the activities of JIO or ONA. As Mr Justice Hope points out, questions of legality and propriety rarely arise with respect to ONA and JIO, which do not collect intelligence themselves but simply assess intelligence collected by others. Similarly, the Inspector-General may initiate an inquiry into ASIO's procedures for ensuring legality and propriety, but not into those of the other agencies whose operations rarely have a direct impact on individual Australians.

Despite these differences, the Bill confers a number of important functions on the Inspector-General with respect to all of the agencies. Specifically, the Inspector-General will inquire into the propriety of the agencies' activities; their compliance with Australian law, ministerial directions or guidelines; human rights; and their procedures relating to grievances of employees. In recognition of his overall responsibility for intelligence and security matters the Prime Minister, in addition to the responsible Ministers, will be able to request the Inspector-General to inquire into any one or more of the agencies.

There are two additional functions that relate to ASIO alone, in recognition of its potential impact on individual Australians. Honourable members will recollect that, in his report on the Combe-Ivanov affair in December 1983, Mr Justice Hope pointed out that circumstances can arise where ASIO produces a report adverse to the interests of an individual Australian and there is no existing right of review unless he or she is a public servant. His Honour recommended a statutory procedure whereby an independent body decides whether and, if so, how much a person should be provided with an opportunity to be heard. On tabling that report, the Prime Minister welcomed the recommendation; this Bill includes provision for the Inspector-General to make such inquiries.

The second additional function relates to directions given to ASIO by the Attorney-General concerning the collection or communication of intelligence about a particular individual. In the ASIO Amendment Bill, which I shall introduce shortly, a number of changes are proposed to section 8 of the ASIO Act to clarify the nature and extent of ministerial control of the Organisation. One element of those changes will provide that the Attorney cannot override the opinion of the Director-General on the question of whether the collection or communication of intelligence concerning a particular individual is justified on security grounds, except by a direction in writing which sets out the Attorney's reasons. The Inspector-General Bill gives the Inspector-General the function of inquiring into such directions, specifically into whether collection is justified by reason of its relevance to security or whether communication would be for a purpose relevant to security.

The Government agrees with Mr Justice Hope that the combination of these measures gives recognition to the paramountcy of ministerial control, whilst providing a safeguard to inhibit and bring to light any misuse of that control.

I mentioned that in respect of each of the agencies the Inspector-General is given the function of inquiring into matters relating to human rights. Under the provisions of the Bill, the Inspector-General is to perform the functions that would otherwise be the responsibility of the Human Rights Commission in relation to possible human rights breaches by the agencies-including privacy, and discrimination on grounds of race, sex and so on. This was not directly addressed by the Royal Commission, but the Government believes it to be an appropriate corollary to inquiry into the propriety of the agencies' activities. We intend to propose similar provisions in respect of the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission once it is established. By referring possible violations of human rights by the agencies to the Inspector-General, the Bill seeks to avoid duplication and meet the need for such matters to be examined by an independent authority with unrestricted access to classified information.

With the approval of the responsible Minister the Inspector-General will be able to inquire into a matter that occurred outside Australia or before the commencement of the Act. In deciding that ministerial approval will be required to do so, the Government has taken account of the prospective work load of the Inspector-General and the fact that Mr Justice Hope has conducted two major royal commissions over recent years, both of which invited public submissions. It is a fundamental tradition of our system of government that Ministers themselves are, and should remain, accountable to Parliament. Bearing in mind also that the Office of the Inspector-General is being created to assist Ministers in their oversight of the agencies, the Inspector-General is not to inquire into actions taken by Ministers except in relation to the specific ministerial directions to ASIO I have already addressed. The Government also wishes to avoid establishing the Inspector-General as a further avenue of appeal on matters that can already be taken to the Security Appeals Tribunal. The Inspector- General shall therefore not inquire into a matter that can be reviewed by that Tribunal.

The clauses of the Bill dealing with complaints are in the main comparable with those in other administrative review legislation. Amongst other things, the Bill enables a complaint to be made orally or in writing; gives the Inspector-General customary discretions not to proceed with inquiries into complaints under specified circumstances; and provides special arrangements for persons in custody. Similarly, the clauses dealing with inquiries also draw on the models provided by other administrative review legislation and I do not intend to elaborate on them. An important stipulation, given the sensitive national interests to be covered in this jurisdiction, is that the Inspector-General shall inform the responsible Minister and agency head before commencing an inquiry. During the course of inquiries the Inspector-General may also discuss relevant matters with the responsible Minister or the Prime Minister. We believe the maintenance of trust and good communications between all parties involved will be essential to the effective operation of the Office of the Inspector-General.

The consultative process built into the conduct of inquiries carries over into the preparation of reports. Draft reports are to be provided to the head of an agency and provision is made for relevant comments by the agency head to be included in the final report. Final reports are to be provided to the responsible Minister, to the agency head, and, if commissioned by the Prime Minister, to the Prime Minister. The Inspector-General is required to include in a report the reasons for conclusions and recommendations. In addition, where a report concludes that a person has been adversely affected by action taken by an agency, the Inspector-General may recommend compensation. Whenever an inquiry has been undertaken in response to a complaint, the complaint is to be given a written response by the Inspector-General, subject to agreement with the responsible Minister that the terms of the response will not jeopardise security, defence or international relations. The Inspector-General will be able to monitor action-or inaction-arising from reports. Where an agency head proposes taking action as a result of a report, the Inspector-General is to be given details. If the Inspector-General believes this action to be inadequate, he or she may discuss the matter with the responsible Minister and provide a report to the Prime Minister.

Finally, the Bill contains a number of standard miscellaneous and administrative provisions. The Bill provides for the Inspector-General's terms and conditions of appointment, remuneration, leave, resignation, termination of appointment, disclosure of interests and staff. It goes without saying that heavy emphasis is also placed on the need for the Inspector-General and staff to safeguard appropriately and maintain the secrets entrusted to them.

Madam Speaker, the creation of an Inspector-General of Intelligence and Security is a key recommendation of Mr Justice Hope and constitutes a vital component of the Government's reform package developed for the intelligence and security area. The Government embraced the concept and, having now translated it into draft legislation, is more than ever convinced that the creation of the Office is a highly beneficial addition to the machinery of government. We believe that the legislation establishes an Office which will, to paraphrase the Royal Commissioner, provide an independent oversight of the agencies' activities, give the public a greater assurance that those activities are proper ones, and clear the agencies, or bring them to task, as the case may be, if allegations of improper conduct are made against them.

Following the tabling of the Royal Commission reports last year the Opposition indicated its broad support for the establishment of an Inspector-General. I am confident that when it has had a chance to consider the legislation it will reaffirm its support. Madam Speaker, I commend the Bill to the House and present the explanatory memorandum.
Debate (on motion by Mr Spender) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN SECURITY INTELLIGENCE ORGANIZATION AMENDMENT BILL 1986

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Lionel Bowen, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

This Bill, and the related Inspector-General and Intelligence and Security (Consequential Amendments) Bills, stem from the Government's consideration of the report of the Royal Commission on Australia's Security and Intelligence Agencies. It is designed to clarify and define the role and powers of the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation and to strengthen the arrangements for its control and accountability.

In particular, the Bill provides, very much along the lines recommended by Mr Justice Hope, for significant changes to clarify ASIO's jurisdiction, and an additional function in regard to the obtaining of foreign intelligence in Australia; a strengthening of ministerial control over ASIO; and changes in the provisions concerning the Security Appeals Tribunal.

As foreshadowed by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) in his statement on 22 May 1985 on the tabling of the report of the Royal Commission, provision is also made for the establishment of a parliamentary joint committee to oversight certain of ASIO's activities. The opportunity has been taken to deal with a number of other matters that have come to light as a result of experience in the operation of the ASIO Act. I turn now to the details of the Bill.
ASIO Jurisdiction and Powers

The Government has given close consideration, in the light of the report of the Royal Commission, to the statutory definition of ASIO's role and powers. It is of great importance, to ASIO itself as well as to those charged with oversighting its activities and to the community at large, that ASIO's statutory charter should be defined appropriately and as clearly as possible.

The Bill provides for a number of changes to the ASIO Act which are designed to clarify ASIO's jurisdiction, and to define more closely and precisely matters of legitimate security interest. Clause 3 proposes the following significant changes to the key definition of `security' in section 4 of the Act:

The term `subversion' is deleted from the definition of `security' and relevant activities are more tightly defined and comprehended within the concept of `politically motivated violence'. Without detracting from ASIO's effectiveness, the definition will concentrate ASIO's attention more clearly on those violent activities, going beyond the scope of lawful advocacy and dissent, directed at undermining Australia's system of government.

The new definition of politically motivated violence also covers terrorism and related activities, of the kind covered by the present definition of `terrorism', and makes it clear that threats of or acts causing unlawful harm to achieve a political end, are included.

The term `active measures of foreign intervention' is deleted from the definition of `security' and replaced by a more tightly constructed definition of `act of foreign interference' along the lines suggested by Mr Justice Hope. The new definition spells out more clearly the kind of activity which, because it is of foreign origin, is a legitimate matter of security concern.

Clause 9 provides for the inclusion in the legislation of a new provision-section 17A-which declares that the ASIO Act shall not limit the right of persons to engage in lawful advocacy, protest or dissent, and that the exercise of that right shall not, by itself, be regarded as prejudicial to security. The functions of ASIO are to be construed accordingly. The Government regards this as an important statement of principle to guide ASIO in the often difficult exercise of its discretions under the Act.

Another change flows from the acceptance by the Government of Mr Justice Hope's recommendation that ASIO should be empowered to collect foreign intelligence in Australia; that is, intelligence relating to the capabilities, intentions or activities of foreign powers. Mr Justice Hope noted that there was no provision in Australian legislation providing for the collection of such intelligence, which it is in the national interest for Australia to acquire, and recommended that the legal authority to do so be given to ASIO. Such intelligence will only be obtained, pursuant to the new function which clause 8 will add to the statement of ASIO's functions in section 17, under the written warrant of the Attorney- General, following a request by the Minister for Foreign Affairs or the Minister for Defence.

Specific provision is made to prevent the use of the relevant powers for the purpose of collecting information concerning an Australian citizen, permanent resident or company. Strict controls will be placed on the communication of foreign intelligence under the new powers and provision is made for conditions minimising the obtaining and retention of information not publicly available concerning Australian citizens or permanent residents.

Clause 9 also proposes amendment of section 17 to put beyond doubt ASIO's power to provide advice on matters of protective security, that is, on administrative or physical measures for the protection of people, information or property. Mention should also be made in this context of the proposed provision, to which I shall refer again, empowering the Minister to lay down guidelines to be observed by ASIO. There will be clear scope for such guidelines to be given in regard to the exercise of its functions under aspects of the definition of `security' which necessarily are expressed in fairly broad terms. In regard to one aspect of security, that of `politically motivated violence', the Bill goes further and requires such guidelines to be laid down by the Minister.
Ministerial Control

Ministerial control is a fundamental element of the arrangements for the control and accountability of ASIO. The Organisation is accountable through the Director-General of Security to the Attorney-General and through him to the Parliament. Mr Justice Hope noted in his report the importance, for the oversight of ASIO's activities in the public interest and ASIO's accountability through the Parliament to the public, of the effectiveness of its ministerial control. He also noted the need for an appropriate balance to be struck between the ability of a government to exercise control over ASIO and the highly important principle that ASIO should be politically impartial.

The Bill contains in clause 5 provisions, along the lines proposed by Mr Justice Hope, which are designed to strengthen ministerial control over ASIO and to achieve this necessary balance. An amendment to section 8 makes it clear that, in the performance of his functions under the Act, the Director-General is subject to the directions of the Minister. Any such direction shall, if requested, be put in writing. The amendment ensures that the Minister's authority over the organisation is ultimately paramount. As stated by Mr Justice Hope, the Minister, as the elected office-holder accountable for ASIO and its activities to Parliament and the public, is placed in a position where he or she is able in the end to determine, and assume responsibility for, activities pertaining to the security of Australia.

There are two necessary qualifications to this provision. The first is that the Minister is not empowered to override the opinion of the Director-General concerning the nature of the advice which should be given by the Organisation. The second is that the Minister is not empowered to override the opinion of the Director-General as to whether the collection or communication of intelligence concerning a particular individual is or is not justified, except by a written direction to the Director-General setting out his reasons. This extends the area of ministerial control but, in order to guard against the possibility of misuse for political purposes, there are appropriate safeguards. The Minister is required in such a case to give a copy of his direction, including his reasons, to both the Prime Minister and the Inspector-General. The Inspector-General is to be required by his legislation to address the appropriateness of any such direction in his report.

As already mentioned, the Act will also be amended to insert a new provision authorising the Minister to give written guidelines to the Director-General in respect of the performance by ASIO of any of its statutory functions and powers. The Minister will thus be able to play a positive role in regulating ASIO's conduct. In particular, in areas of the legislation involving broad discretion and judgment the Minister will be able to set appropriate standards. As the Prime Minister observed when tabling Mr Justice Hope's report, the areas to be covered by guidelines will include intelligence collection, targeting, review of file holdings and the extent to which ASIO should, from time to time, be involved in investigating activities relating to the hindering of Defence Force functions.

The Bill provides that the Minister is to table guidelines in Parliament, subject to the deletion of sensitive material. Where appropriate, guidelines not tabled in Parliament will be referred to the Parliamentary Joint Committee. A copy of the guidelines, without deletion, will be made available to the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard).
Security Appeals Tribunal

The Security Appeals Tribunal plays an important role in the oversight of ASIO, by reviewing security assessments made by ASIO about individuals. Clauses 18 to 31 of the Bill propose a number of changes to the provisions concerning the review of adverse or qualified ASIO security assessments. Principally, they support and strengthen the present position that ASIO security assessments are advisory only, and should form only part of the information on which a security related decision is based. The amendments also include more precise definitions of adverse and qualified security assessments and a discretion in the Tribunal to make an order against the Commonwealth for costs reasonably incurred by an applicant who is successful, or substantially successful, in his application for review. The Intelligence and Security (Consequential Amendments) Bill also provides for an extension of the Tribunal's jurisdiction in respect of security assessments for deportation purposes.
Parliamentary Joint Committee on ASIO

The Government believes that existing oversight and accountability measures for ASIO will be improved by involving the Parliament to a greater extent in those measures. The Bill therefore proposes the establishment of a Parliamentary Joint Committee on ASIO. Because the Committee will be required to deal on a regular basis with various kinds of sensitive information, and because of the special considerations which must apply whenever information of that sort is made available, the Government believes it appropriate for the Committee to be set up by legislation and for that legislation to specifically delineate the powers, functions and obligations of the Committee.

The Committee will comprise seven members, and will have a majority of Government members and a majority of members from the House of Representatives. To achieve this result, the Bill provides that Committee members will be appointed as follows: For the House of Representatives, four members will be appointed by resolution of the House on the nomination of the Prime Minister. For the Senate, three members will be appointed by resolution of the Senate on the nomination of the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Before nominations are made, the Prime Minister and the Leader of the Government in the Senate are required to consult with the leader of each recognised political party represented in the House or the Senate, and they are required in making nominations to have regard to the desirability of ensuring that the composition of the Committee takes into account the representation of recognised political parties in the Parliament. Ministers are not eligible for appointment.

Broadly speaking, the functions of the Committee are to review aspects of the activities of ASIO that are referred to it either by the Minister or by either House of the Parliament, and to report to Parliament thereon. The Bill also enables the Committee to ask the Minister to refer a particular matter to it. It is not the function of the Committee to operate as a grievance mechanism. That is the function of the Inspector-General whose annual report will, however, be available to the Parliament. Nor will it be a function of the Committee to review operationally sensitive matters, or certain other matters set out in the Bill. The Bill makes provision for the protection of intelligence and security information. The Bill also makes provision empowering the Committee to obtain information and documents, including information and documents from ASIO.

The Government believes that the provisions provide a proper balance between greater parliamentary involvement in the oversight of ASIO and the limits of the Executive's ability, having in mind its responsibilities in regard to security matters, to make sensitive information more widely accessible. The Government believes that the creation of the proposed Parliamentary Joint Committee, independent as it is of the Executive Government, will, in conjunction with the other measures outlined, provide an effective and appropriate scheme of public accountability for ASIO.
Other Matters

The Bill also makes provision for extension of the offence in section 92, of making public the identity of an ASIO officer to cover, subject to appropriate exceptions, disclosure of the identity of former officers. It provides for changes to the provisions governing employment of staff by ASIO. Terms and conditions of employment will be put on a statutory basis, instead of the present unsatisfactory contractual arrangements. The Bill provides for a statutory requirement for the tabling in Parliament of an annual report. The Government has adopted the practice of making a report to Parliament each year on ASIO's activities. That practice will now be given a legislative base. The Director-General is to be given the power to delegate his powers relating to staff or financial management, placing him in a similar position to secretaries of Commonwealth departments, and assisting in the management of the organisation.
Financial Impact Statement

The creation of a Parliamentary Joint Committee on ASIO will have a minor impact on expenditure in providing a small staff, and secure premises, for the Committee. Giving the Security Appeals Tribunal a discretion to make an order against the Commonwealth for costs reasonably incurred by a successful applicant will have a minimal impact on expenditure. This may, however, be offset by savings which will result from requiring an applicant to indicate what matters are in dispute. This is likely to result in shorter hearings.
Conclusion

This Bill results from a thorough review by the Government of ASIO's role and powers. The Government has been greatly assisted in this review by the relevant findings and recommendations of Mr Justice Hope in the report of the Royal Commission on Australia's Security and Intelligence Agencies. The Government believes that its legislative proposals, by clarifying and stating ASIO's functions in appropriate terms, any by providing for more effective control and oversight, will facilitate the effective discharge by ASIO of its functions and will provide significant assurance to the community as to the way in which ASIO carries out its functions. The new review mechanisms do not in any way detract from the responsibilities of the Director-General of Security and the Minister for ensuring that ASIO is well managed and in its activities preserves a proper balance between the security of the nation and the individual rights of its citizens. I commend the Bill to the House. I present the explanatory memorandum to the Bill.
Debate (on motion by Mr Spender) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: INTELLIGENCE AND SECURITY (CONSEQUENTIAL AMENDMENTS) BILL 1986

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Lionel Bowen, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

This Bill provides for an amendment to the Crimes Act 1914, and for the amendment of other Acts as a consequence of the provisions of the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation Amendment Bill and the Inspector-General of Intelligence and Security Bill. Principal features of the Bill are as follows:

The Audit Act 1901 is to be amended to provide for the addition of further details to the certificate supplied by the Minister each year to the Auditor-General dealing with the Organisation's exempt account. That certificate will be required to state that the exempt accounts have been subject to internal inspection and examination, and whether any irregularity has been disclosed, and resolved or rectified;

Amendment of the offence of sedition in the Crimes Act 1914 to remove anachronistic provisions and to provide that the writing et cetera of seditious words is not an offence unless done with an intent to create violence or public disturbance or disorder. This implements a recommendation by Mr Justice Hope;
The exemption of documents in the possession of, or received from, the Inspector General of Intelligence and Security from the provisions of the Freedom of Information Act 1982;

Amendment of the Human Rights Commission Act 1981 to provide that a complaint about an act or practice of a security or intelligence agency is to be investigated by the Inspector-General instead of the Commission;

Amendment of the Migration Act 1958 to provide that the Minister can only order the deportation of a person from Australia on security grounds when he has been furnished with an adverse security assessment from ASIO. Where, in accordance with the provisions of the Act, the person has been informed of the adverse assessment, the security assessment will be reviewable by the Security Appeals Tribunal. Where the Tribunal does not confirm the adverse assessment the Minister will not be able to order deportation. This amendment will enable the security grounds on which a deportation decision is based to be fully reviewed by an independent tribunal; and

Finally there are a number of amendments to the Telecommunications (Interception) Act 1979, corresponding to changes made to the special powers provisions of the ASIO Act, to take account of the new ASIO function of collecting foreign intelligence in Australia.
Financial Impact Statement

The addition to the jurisdiction of the Security Appeals Tribunal may lead to a slight increase in the cost of that Tribunal. I commend the Bill to the House. I present the explanatory memorandum to the Bill.
Debate (on motion by Mr Spender) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: ACCOMMODATION AND WAREHOUSING FOR 51ST SUPPLY BATTALION, GUILDFORD, WESTERN AUSTRALIA

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Reference of Work: Public Works Committee Act

SPEECH.SPEAKER: West The Hon S.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That, in accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act 1969, the following proposed work be referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works for consideration and report: Construction of working accommodation and warehousing for 51st Supply Battalion, Guildford.

The proposed works are for the construction of a replacement working and storage facility for the 51st Supply Battalion. This Battalion provides supply service support to army units in Western Australia and is currently dispersed at six separate localities. The proposal enables the Battalion to be concentrated at Guildford and requires the existing inadequate facilities, some of which were constructed in 1916, to be replaced and expanded. The works proposed under this submission comprise a bulk storage warehouse, associated stores buildings and workshops, a single storey headquarters facility, an amenities building, a control post and associated engineering services and site works. The estimated cost of the proposal is $8.2m at April 1986 prices. It is intended that construction will commence early in 1987 and it is anticipated that the project will have a construction period of 12 months. I table plans of the proposed work and commend the motion to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beale Mr J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister for Housing and Construction (Mr West) for making available to me information on the motion that he has just moved. The Opposition does not oppose this motion, but a few remarks on budgetary procedures might seem appropriate. Under normal circumstances, the defence budget would be prepared by the Department of Defence and would be approved by the Parliament as part of the Budget. The Minister, in this case the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley), would then have the authority of Parliament to authorise any capital works or expenditures that were approved in the Budget. Presumably, the Minister would in turn delegate to his Department and to the Defence Services the authority to spend the funds. The amounts of money spent would depend on the responsibilities and seniority of the personnel involved. These personnel would then have responsibility for spending the funds up to the amounts and within the authorities delegated to them. They would not need to defer to their superiors unless there was an overrun on the relevant expenditure.

SPEECH.PARA: In the case of the working accommodation and warehouse for the 51st Battalion at Guildford, responsibility for carrying out this capital work would presumably rest with a regional officer or local base commander. The person responsible could then arrange for the calling of tenders, make the decision on who should carry out the works and supervise their completion without the need for referring the matter either to his superiors or, in this case, all the way back to the Parliament. An objection might be raised that if the delegation process were carried too far, it would result in some kind of deterioration of standards, but there is no reason why the local person responsible should not need to be required to carry out the work to standards that are established by the Department of Defence. It is, after all, that Department that will use the facilities.

This is a perfect example of bureaucratic waste. Here we have the Parliament, the Department of Housing and Construction and the Department of Defence all involved in a project worth $8.2m. Presumably, a number of bureaucrats will be required to spend time and money making sure that the final approval for this work meets all the rules and regulations that have been established when there is absolutely no reason why the local base commander could not take full responsibility for doing the job. Having said all that, I would ask the Minister to ensure that he requests the parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works to ensure that in its deliberations on this matter it makes certain that in the design and construction activities the role of the private sector is maximised. As I said earlier, the Opposition does not oppose this motion.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: STATES GRANTS (EDUCATION ASSISTANCE-PARTICIPATION AND EQUITY) AMENDMENT BILL 1986[COGNATE BILLS:STATES GRANTS (SCHOOLS ASSISTANCE) AMENDMENT BILL 1986STATES GRANTS (TERTIARY EDUCATION ASSISTANCE) AMENDMENT BILL 1986]
