That the Bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand it is the intention of the House to debate this order of the day concurrently with orders of the day Nos 6 and 7. There being no objection, the Chair will allow that the course to be followed.

DEBATE.TITLE: STATES GRANTS (EDUCATION ASSISTANCE-PARTICIPATION AND EQUITY) AMENDMENT BILL 1986

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Shack Mr P.

TALK.START.PARA: —These three Bills-the States Grants (Education Assistance-Participation and Equity) Amendment Bill, the States Grants (Schools Assistance) Amendment Bill and the States Grants (Tertiary Education Assistance) Amendment Bill-authorise retrospective cost supplementation of grants made annually to the education sector by the Commonwealth Government. As such, the Opposition will not oppose them. They are routine insofar as cost supplementation Bills of this sort are brought down by the Government-any government-every year. However, they are symbolic in a very important sense of this Government's entire approach to education policy, an approach which is marginal, incremental, with a bit tacked on to the edge of the system here and there and with little regard for or understanding of the state of the health of the education system in Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: This Government has a depressing lack of vision for the education sector and the people-students, teachers, academics and administrators-within it. It is completely void of any view as to how the system might better fulfil the needs of the consumers of its services, how it might become a more dynamic force in our society and economy, and how individual Australians and Australia as a whole could be more greatly enriched by its operation. This Government is incapable of meeting the challenges so patently evident, not only within the education system, but between that system, its user groups and the wider community. The Minister for Education (Senator Ryan) spends more time denying that there are problems in our schools and tertiary institutions than she spends on any other aspect of her ministerial duties. This is becoming less and less tenable as each month goes by. In each and every individual part of the education system, parents students and educators are facing difficulties of a chronic nature.

As I have said, the Bills under consideration today provide retrospective cost supplementation for schools and tertiary institutions. I intend to take this opportunity to outline some of the factors preventing those sectors from developing their potential more fully. The principal factor in education is, of course, the regressive, restrictive and vindictive education policy stance adopted by this Government, expressed in a number of instances with extremely adverse consequences for the hundreds of thousands of students and the thousands of educators involved in Australia's education effort.

It is in the Government's schools policy that the most covert and vicious aspects of its education agenda are to be seen. The so-called truce attained through that sham of all shams, `the historic settlement', to use the Minister's words, between the Government and non-government school sectors, is coming under increasing strain as the Minister's thinly concealed goals become clear. What are her goals? I would like to impart them to the Minister and to honourable members opposite and to impart a brutally plain understanding of her intentions and the methods by which she seeks to attain them. To do so I would like to use a very simple analogy. The Minister for Education has adopted and quietly implemented over the past year a pincer approach to squeeze the non-government school sector in a way which will really hurt the quality of Australian education in future years. She has put the clamps on the non-government school sector in a way which covertly, bureaucratically and underhandedly will deliver her goal, which has been with her for many years. The twin arms of this pincer with which she is squeezing the non-government school community are directed firstly to staunching the flow of school students from the government to the non-government school sector; and, secondly, to drawing the non-government sector even deeper into the Government's bureaucratic web of control over schooling in Australia,

This pincer mechanism, designed to put the lid on the growth of non-government schooling, inevitably will lead to lower standards in our education system in both the government and non-government sectors. It is abhorrent not just in the way it restricts the right of parents to choose the sort of schooling they want for their children, and not just in the way it seeks to homogenise Australian schooling into the one grey mass of mediocrity; it is abhorrent as well to all of us who care about our children's future and who care about Australia's future. It is appalling to those of us who want to ensure that everybody within the education system has the opportunity to acquire a decent school education, to get a strong grounding in the basic skills, and to maximise their further knowledge and training on that firm base.

How will the Minister's attempt to put the lid on the growth of the non-government school sector lower school standards? Let me spell it out. Her desire to limit family choice in education, to frustrate the expansion of non-government schooling to meet the demand that exists for it in the community and to homogenise the school system under one set of rigid bureaucratic rules and regulations, will wipe out the positive diversity which exists within the system. It will kill the remaining remnants of healthy competition within the system, competition which produces an impetus for achievement and for excellence by the students and teachers in it. If the Minister's attempts to level down the system, to force every school in the system into the same dull grey mould, continue to be embodied in public policy for much longer, the system will be dragged down to new performance lows.

The Minister has two principal policy tools for the pursuit of her goals-her policy on new non-government schools and the new accountability provisions which she is presently inflicting on all non-government schools. As I have stated in this House on other occasions, the Government's new non-government school policy marks a significant historical break with the school funding policies of both the Fraser and Whitlam governments. As a result of the Government's policy on new non-government schools all government schools receive a base level of Commonwealth support in respect of each pupil but all non-government schools do not.

This fundamentally punitive, unjust stance on the Government's part is not designed to deny funding assistance to well-resourced established independent schools which continue to receive a basic grant in respect of each student from the Commonwealth. Rather, it is designed to discourage the establishment of new non-government schools, to make it as difficult as possible for new institutions to be built and developed to meet the growing community demand for non-government schooling which exists in every Australian suburb. By these means the Government is trying to fence into the government school system students whose families for a whole range of reasons would prefer and would be willing to make the material sacrifices necessary to pay for non-government schooling for their children.

The Minister has become more sophisticated in her techniques but she is no less determined to achieve her regressive and conformist ends. While she was unable to starve existing non-government schools of funds, because of mass community outrage at her blatantly hostile attack on them and the fact that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) settled in to pour oil on troubled waters, she has not relinquished her program of forcing parents to educate their children in government schools rather than in the non-government school sector. This time, instead of starving existing schools of Commonwealth funding support, she has embarked on a course designed to prevent as many new non-government schools as possible from opening their doors to students flowing from the government to the non-government school sector.

Queues and waiting lists of families waiting for their children to be admitted to non-government schools grow longer month after month. Government policy on new non-government schools is designed to make the queues and the time spent on waiting lists longer and longer. It is designed with the sole intention of denying families real educational choice, of frustrating the fulfilment of their legitimate right to gain access to the sort of education they believe is best for their children. It is a contemptible, pathetic policy. Instead of allowing positive and vigorous competition, both within and between the government and non-government school sectors, which encourages optimal levels of educational achievement throughout the system and free choice for parents within it, the Government is attempting to erect around the non-government school sector a wall which prevents families from exercising their right to choose a non-government school for their children if that is their parental wish. Parents throughout Australia who have been stuck on waiting lists for months, in some cases years, should know that it is the Government which is to blame for their plight, that it is Government policy which is currently preventing them from exercising their legitimate right to educational choice.

On top of the denial of choice, the Government has embarked on a campaign to bring non-government schools which are established and which are receiving Commonwealth funding support more closely under the control of the Commonwealth Government. The accountability provisions which have been foisted upon non-government schools are a classic case of the thin end of the wedge. The Government, through the grilling on accountability grounds of non-government schools which are supposed to be independent and free from the levelling down mentality which emanates from the educational bureaucracy over which the Minister presides, is slowly but surely trying to force non-government schools under the same umbrella of control under which government schools have been labouring for years. If the Minister succeeds in this campaign, if she does manage to bring the dead hand of bureaucratic control over the non-government school community through the Government's accountability policy, it will mean the end of all the things which are the very strength of the non-government school sector-diversity, excellence and competitive vigour. The same restrictive, regressive, tunnel-visioned approach is evident in the Government's tertiary education policies.

One of the scandals of this Government's administration of Australia's education system is that there is an alarming and growing gap between the number of young people academically eligible for entry to higher education institutions, intellectually capable of completing higher education studies, and the number of higher education places annually open to them. In 1985 the Australian Vice-Chancellors Committee estimated that almost 30,000 young Australians were denied the opportunity to undertake tertiary study despite their competence to benefit from it. How can this Government and this Minister maintain any credibility at all while this Government foams at the mouth in its Priority One self-promotion campaign and, at the same time, presides over a policy which is locking thousands of willing and intellectually able young people out of the tertiary system? I understand that the 1986 figures, on knockbacks from higher education institutions, will be of the same order-30,000 young people will be locked out of the system and thrown on to the labour market at a time of still rising youth unemployment. What does the Government offer? Thin and tatty labour market programs, like the Australian traineeship system, which it cannot even get off the ground successfully.

We, on this side of the House, are vitally concerned to see that the Government, as long as it remains in office, gets behind a massive renewal of Australia's education system. We regard the restoration of real choice within the school system as absolutely vital, and until governments provide genuine assistance to families to help them exercise that choice, the words of politicians who speak in this place about a commitment to higher educational standards will be very hollow indeed. The coalition intends to provide that assistance. We regard the resolution of the crisis of capacity presently racking our tertiary education system as essential, not just to ensure the fullest opportunity for life fulfilment in individual Australians but to ensure the optimal development of the nation as a whole. It is vital that the gap between those who wish to pursue higher education and the number of places available be reduced.

This Government cannot deliver the goods when it comes to ensuring real choice in the school system. It presides over a chronically worsening shortage of higher education places for all those who deserve them. It shows a complete contempt for those people concerned to lift educational standards throughout the system, in non-government and government schools. On the matter of education, at both the school and higher education level, this Government has not, cannot, and will not deliver. The Liberal and National parties can and will, and over the next couple of months I look forward to the opportunity to outline details of our plans to revitalise Australia's education system.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mayer Ms H.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for Tangney (Mr Shack) sailed into the education debate on the States Grants (Education Assistance-Participation and Equity) Amendment Bill, the States Grants (Schools Assistance) Amendment Bill and the States Grants (Tertiary Education Assistance) Amendment Bill with his ancient and tattered rhetorical flags flying above the sinking ship of privatisation. I think it is really rather interesting that, in all the discussion, there was not one single idea that was new, not one single idea that was creative and, in fact, not one single idea. We had the abuse of the Public Service as a supporting argument for the benefits of privatisation. There is neither logic nor even good manners in that sort of an argument.

SPEECH.PARA: I think we need to have a look at just what is going on. These Bills, which amend the States grants Acts providing funds to the States for educational purposes, are funding supplementations. They will be providing $93.43m for tertiary education assistance this year. Of that $66.5m is for 1986 and $31.5m is for 1987 as supplementation for unanticipated rising costs.

The supplementation applies to a very wide range of institutions and institutional purposes. The size of the range indicates the enormous flexibility and variety in the tertiary sector, which is funded and encouraged by this Government. If one looks at the schedules one finds universities, colleges of advanced education, technical and further education colleges, building supplementation, resources supplementation and assistance to new courses. We find all sorts of things in the schedules that really put the lie to this argument about grey people being the same, and so on. It sounds exactly like a lot of school uniforms of my acquaintance.

In the context of this legislation, which deals with the funding of tertiary institutions, I would like to have a look at and perhaps comment on an alternative method of funding which has been put up at a Young Liberals meeting by the honourable member for Tangney and I assume it represents something of the Opposition's policy on funding. What we have in this policy about funding tertiary institutions is vouchers. Twenty years ago Milton Friedman thought, amongst other things, that the voucher system in schools in the United States of America would lead to racial tolerance and all kinds of things. In fact, nobody has been really terribly interested in it since then. It has had a few minor trials and has been found to be fairly disastrous. To propose this as a method for funding our universities and tertiary institutions in this country is really rather strange. Not only is it threadbare and ancient, but also it is certainly proposed without any consideration at all of the analysis of that funding proposal over the last 20 years. I think we need to have another look at it. If it is going to raise its dear old grey and curly head again let us find out what would happen to our universities if we abandoned the system of triennium funding with cost supplementation-the cost supplementation that these Bills are about.

The Opposition, not untypically I think, has brushed off this nice, ancient piece of monetarist baggage to present as the centrepiece of its new education policy. I think we have to understand that all the policies the Opposition will be producing will have something to do with the notion that, if the Government does not own it, it will be better run. So far, nobody has provided any evidence for that peculiar and ideologically far-out proposition. What is the terrific idea anyway? Away with State grants, away with recurrent per capita funding, equal opportunities funding, funding for Aboriginal programs and funding for research centres. Away with the system by which students nominate for preferred courses in institutions and receive offers, depending on their results, and the entrance standards required by the institution, and in come vouchers which, for this purpose, can be called scholarships or any piece of paper that we like-even tram tickets.

What do students do with the voucher? They take it to their preferred institution to request enrolment for their preferred courses. The difference is that the student runs around without being able, through the offer system, to be notified of which courses at which institutions the student's results will provide entry to. `Students', tootles the Opposition spokesman on education, `will be able to study where they like. Queensland students will be able to study in Western Australia'. That may be of enormous benefit to Queenslanders; I am not aware of the differing standards there. That is great stuff except for the fact that students can already apply to the institutions of their choice and, if their results are acceptable, receive offers from all of them. A student of my fairly close acquaintance who applied for a course of her choice at two New South Wales universities, two Victorian universities and one South Australian university received offers from all of them. She did not need a voucher; she did not need to shop around. She simply had to have acceptable results for the faculties to which she applied. If a student's results are not acceptable and if there is not a place for that student, no amount of vouchers or so-called scholarships will improve the results or increase the number of places. The problems associated with providing enough places of the right kind in our tertiary institutions are a matter of finance, an awareness of the needs of the nation and the appropriate school programs.

Although this Government has financed an extra 28,000 places in tertiary institutions to be filled between 1983 and 1987-a contrast, I might say, to the previous Government's record of a real cut of 4.9 per cent in tertiary funding-there is a long way to go to achieve an optimum level of tertiary education within the community. This cannot be achieved without rational planning, without considerations of efficiency and without taking into account community needs and labour force requirements. The present system of funding takes these things into account as well as student demand. Funding is predictable and supplemented regularly through the mechanisms of these Bills for cost increases.

What kind of shambles would we have if the Opposition policy were to be implemented? Institutions would be thrown into chaos, having to meet fluctuating student demand, based quite often on the fashion of the moment. Demand, rather than proper forward planning would control courses. In order to make the voucher system work, entrance to all institutions would have to be on a fee-paying basis. Institutions with a high student demand for one reason or another would charge fees above the nominal voucher allowance and student performance would become less important than student pockets. These fees would then be claimed as a tax rebate, adding yet another means of tax evasion to those protected by the previous Government. This policy is all of a piece-ancient, tatty and protecting tax evaders. Where would the cost supplementation end up? Would students be given another voucher to top up course costs? Would we have a major voucher and a few minor vouchers? Would students have a book of vouchers that they tore off if they remembered to keep the book and it went with them, if nobody stole it? What kind of bureaucracy would that involve? I suggest that it would involve about 17,000 times more paper than it does now.

Campuses, say the Opposition, will be able to take in anyone they desire. The result of that is clear. There would be a proliferation of high fee, mickey mouse campuses for kids with full pockets and empty heads. We have seen that so many times overseas. We know that that is the result of that kind of operation. Who eventually pays the price for that kind of nonsense? It is the nation as a whole and every individual taxpayer. Our higher education institutions have a deservedly high reputation. Student merit, tested by mechanisms which are quite properly a matter of continuing debate, is the sole criterion for entry for the majority of students. Some places are provided for students who have not, for many reasons, been able to demonstrate their potential through the standard mechanisms. Mature-age students can gain places based on their experience and potential. Can we provide cost-supplemented, appropriate colours of vouchers for varying kinds of students? Where does this kind of madness end? This is the most amazing paper chase of a policy that has ever been put up under the guise of a plan for improving education and educational access. Where the standards come in this argument, heaven only knows.

It may be instructive for us to look at the flexibility of course design and offering that already exists in the system. We find in Schedule 20 grants and supplements for electrical studies, food science, fashion courses, computing, small business courses, art and design, rural studies and child care courses. That is a small and random sample of the courses which are supported by this Government in technical and further education colleges only. Schedule 20 deals with TAFE and not with universities or colleges of advanced education. Let us consider what we want our higher education institutions to be doing. What we do not want them to be doing is proliferating easy courses for people with doubtful results but the ability to pay for their courses. We do not want the whole system to run totally out of control on some kind of a false market basis where by a person who can pay gets some kind of a tertiary education and a person who cannot pay might get a voucher system which may or may not assist with the costs of his or her course for the length of that course. When one thinks about six-year courses, for example, and the difference in course costs from year 1 to year 6, one begins to see how difficult this whole proposition is.

If we believe that the present three-layer system of tertiary education does not have sufficient flexibility, that the multi-campuses all over this nation-in the cities, the provincial cities and the country-do not provide sufficient geographic flexibility, we are looking at a system that I do not believe the nation could possibly support. To try to put the final halt on the voucher system nonsense, I wish to read a criticism of the voucher system as it was proposed in England by Peter Newsam in the Times `Educational Supplement' of 2 May 1986. He comments that, some time in the 15th century, William of Ockham delivered a philosophical statement to which we all need to pay attention-that entities are not to be multiplied beyond necessity and unnecessary bits should be removed by the process known now as Ockham's razor. He says:
Vouchers are not ends in themselves. They are a means of achieving something . . . . better education for those who believe in education ones . . . .
Education vouchers, the faithful argue, would do three things in particular: they would cause proper financial discipline to be applied to schools-
or in this case, tertiary institutions-
they would increase the power of parents to choose the education they want for their children; and they would improve standards . . . .
With the sound of William stropping away in the background, let us consider each of these important claims in turn.
Vouchers can be in real money or pretend money. Before education vouchers can be real money, the schools-
or institutions-
to which they relate must charge fees.

There are certain political difficulties, as we all know, in making all schools or institutions fee paying, which is probably why the voucher system keeps coming up every now and again but sinking. To discuss real money vouchers without first explaining that they are needed to pay real fees is like introducing people to safety nets before mentioning that one is proposing to throw them off a cliff. I think this Opposition policy, which pretends to add flexibility and choice to the funding of tertiary institutions, is quite genuinely an attempt to throw people off a cliff. Would a real money voucher system enforce financial discipline? It would do so only if the vouchers were to be the sole source of funding. Then what would happen to cost supplementation? The point is made very clearly by Peter Newsam that, if an institution is full and has no places to offer, there is no need for vouchers. If it is not full we will not need vouchers because there will be plenty of applicants for the positions. If it is full no applicants will be accepted, so the voucher system is a nonsense.

Let us consider the proposition that we might even improve standards of education by the use of this privatisation mechanism. I believe that not one piece of evidence has ever been shown to support the proposition that an enormous change in the funding system of our higher education institutions would add anything that is not already there. It is possible for students to go to the institution of their choice. If they are able to support themselves away from home they have that choice already, and they have always had it. It is possible for them to find a course that suits their own particular needs and the needs of the part of the labour market in which they want to get involved. A huge range of those courses exists throughout tertiary institutions in this country. The grey hand of bureaucracy-if such a thing exists-will hardly be lifted by a system that includes masses of individuals running around waving bits of paper at the system.

As for campuses being able to take in anyone they desire, as I have said before that clearly leads to a mickey-mousing of the system such as we find in other countries where it is possible for students who are unable, on academic merit, to enter tertiary institutions of a more reputable kind after six months, a year or two years of so-called study to wave pieces of paper that say Bachelor of Guppy Raising. This country does not need any bachelor's degrees in guppy raising or in any similar field. We need to retain the reputation of our higher education institutions; we need to retain the predictability of funding for those institutions and we do not need to get into the nonsense of believing that if the Government does it, it is bad, and if the private enterprise system does it, it is good. We have far too much evidence to suggest that that is simply an untrue statement.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Miles Mr C.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The House has before it today three Bills-the States Grants (Tertiary Education Assistance) Amendment Bill 1986, the States Grants (Education Assistance-Participation and Equity) Amendment Bill 1986 and the States Grants (Schools Assistance) Amendment Bill 1986. As we are aware, all of these Bills are routine and provide retrospective cost supplementation of the grants made by the Commonwealth to assist schools and tertiary institutions, but they do give us an opportunity to speak fairly generally and broadly about education in Australia. The previous speaker, the honourable member for Chisholm (Ms Mayer) spent most of her time talking about higher education. I want to focus on secondary education and in particular look at participation and equity-that appendage given to educational institutions over the last three years.

SPEECH.PARA: The States Grants (Education Assistance-Participation and Equity) Amendment Bill 1986 involves a program launched in 1983, described by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) as ambitious and by the Minister for Education (Senator Ryan) as one of the cornerstones of the Labor Government's education policy. It was aimed at speeding up the trend of students remaining at secondary school, particularly years 11 and 12, and also enhancing the participation of students in technical and further education colleges. In particular, it was aimed at helping children from low income families, Aborigines, migrants whose English is inadequate for reasonable progress to be made, the disabled and the handicapped. I make it crystal clear that the coalition fully appreciates the difficulties faced by these groups and certainly on return to Government it will, as it has in the past, give high priority to meeting their needs. The Liberal and National parties question whether the implementation of such schemes as PEP is effective in enhancing students' education. To overcome the difficulties faced by the abovementioned groups we need not a special set of programs but rather a thorough restructuring and rethinking of the practices of Australia's present school system.

Let me illustrate what actually happens when, for reasons best known to themselves, political parties-I include both sides of the House-far removed from the classroom scene, from time to time try to tack on a program to meet perceived needs; needs which are often ideologically rather than objectively perceived and analysed. I remind the Australian people of exactly what happens when these types of programs are handed to the schools for implementation. The first approach which can be adopted is one which can generally be described as the content approach. In many cases teachers, often with little reference to others inside or outside of their particular school, frame new or more suitable courses or subjects for those who have not previously stayed at school. Such an approach raises numerous questions. For example, does the creation of the new course incorporate a total review of the existing curriculum and the place of the new course in it? We already have in our schools a curriculum which is supposed to be meeting current needs, but then governments come along and make an extra allocation of money and say that they want a special program which will be targeted at particular groups, and it has to be fitted into the school program.

Quite often teachers are asked one week to prepare for two weeks time a program which will assist these young people. How does it fit into the curriculum? Will it be worth while? Are the courses part of the mainstream offering, or are they really alternatives stuck on for a special few people? Do the new courses have equal status with existing ones? Are they as well resourced? Where do schools get their resources from, over a very short period, to teach these types of courses? Do the students and their teachers have equal status with others in the school if they take those subjects? These are the crunch issues which teachers and students are faced with when they make their choices. Are the new courses to rely indefinitely on special project funds? Do they affirm or challenge existing priorities in the school; that is, the status of technical as against academic courses, those with general as against those with vocational emphasis? Will a single system of assessment be used for these types of courses, and is that appropriate for the ideals of the program-in this case, in particular, the participation and equity program?

There is justifiable student and public suspicion of second rate courses, for second rate students, often taught by second rate teachers, that lead nowhere, and of so-called vocational preparation in schools without the critical and analytical skills necessary to understand the labour market. The teachers are involved with these courses usually at the same time as they are carrying out their other teaching duties. So they have to try to implement these courses which, as I said before, are really tack-on courses in our schools. The situation teachers are faced with in many schools is very different from that faced by many professionals in our society. Teachers' clients go to them because they are legally required to do so. Most teachers in Australia are dedicated and competent, but they are often given a task which is impossible. Programs such as the PEP look nice and politically might be advantageous to the particular government that introduces them, but the real effect at the classroom level is absolutely nil because so much money is wasted. So much of the time of teachers is spent trying to rearrange their program for courses which really achieve very little.

A second approach which can often be adopted by a school is for it to say that it will not change the courses for these children, but that because it has this money to try to get children to go on and participate more fully in education it will improve the personal relationships between teachers and children, which will give students a much more positive feel for education so they will want to continue. However, this approach has largely a cosmetic effect when adopted. How do we know that there are improved relationships after the money has been spent? Is there any evaluation of that? It certainly is a way in which schools often tackle the problem. They rearrange their program slightly and perhaps introduce more teacher contact time outside academic subject time and try to improve the relationships between teachers and students. That is fundamental to improving education. There are many other methods schools can adopt when these programs are handed to them.

I believe that Australia must take a serious look at how it approaches education generally. Australia is presently faced with two enormous challenges, both of which are fundamental to the future prosperity of this nation. Firstly, we must endeavour to strengthen the kinship family as the fundamental social unit. The problem with education is that many children who arrive at the doorstep of the school to be taught have not had a proper education in their own families. Because of the social breakdowns occurring in our society such children have negative attitudes and teachers face a battlefield as soon as the children arrive.

The first place in which to restructure Australia is the home. That must start by mum and dad getting themselves organised, staying together and working through difficult times so that their children can have a secure home background. That is where education starts. In so doing we will dramatically reduce welfare costs to government and the demand on government housing, and poverty among women and children will be substantially reduced if families can learn to stick together. Time wasting and emotionally draining court cases will be avoided and the scares and hurts of children left in uncaring situations will be removed. Once this cancerous disease is overcome, then the energies, ideas and creativity that are required to address the second challenge will be found. It will not be found until that is achieved.

The second challenge is that of productivity. It is not just about money, efficiency and employment. It is also about the quality of our most important resource-people, and in particular young people. As Senator Sir John Carrick has stated:

There was a time-indeed, for much of Australia's history-when parents could plan the educational programs of their children with a reasonable certainty that at the end of the education journey there would be adequate choice of jobs and skills.

There was no need for patch-up schemes such as the PEP and the community employment program, which have used up well over one billion dollars in three years with little to show. How much better it would have been if that billion dollars had been added to the education budget and had been properly structured and planned.

This Government tries to paint a rosy picture for parents and students about the state of the economy, yet many of the basic facts indicate that all is not well. I remind the House that Australia has the highest real interest rates in 50 years, we have a huge overseas debt, and in the last few days the Treasurer (Mr Keating) has been saying that we are heading towards a banana republic. We also have 600,000 people unemployed. The summary of the Economic Planning Advisory Council paper on Human Capital and Productivity Growth stated that one of the more important factors affecting productivity was `the entrepreneurial and skill capabilities of people'. It went on:
By most common measures Australia's labour force lacks the education intensive skill base of many developed countries such as Japan, West Germany and the United States of America.

The level of skill helped by CEP and PEP is virtually nil. They have not added to the skill base of Australia, yet $1 billion has been spent in that area. Our skill base is reflected in poor retention rates, school promotion procedures, certification processes, and poor post-school education performance. To illustrate the blinkered and unthinking approach that some Australians have adopted, Mr Simon Marginson, a research officer with the Australian Teachers Federation, stated about the EPAC report:
. . . it is highly polemical, politically destructive and careless of the consequence of some of its proposals on the non-economic benefits of education.

The simple facts are that we have not yet got our education act together. We must do so, and quickly. PEP will not achieve it. The meeting of that challenge must begin in the home and be built on by our education system. If the flimsy, unthinking and muddled indicates the extent of the problem that exists within our schools, major surgery is required to our educational system. I think that Mr Simon Marginson needs to take that into account.

It is time for a set of national educational goals to be developed that will address the challenge of higher productivity. To sidestep such a task is consciously to allow an intolerable malaise to take over-a malaise that would plunge this nation's living standards into the worst decline for over a century. There must be greater accountability and competition in our education systems. Parents must be given the opportunity to be able economically to send their children to the schools of their choice. If that occurs there will be an increase in the standards in our schools because parents will choose to send their children to those schools that produce the best results. Teachers must be freed from the restrictive and debilitating policies of many of the leaders of the teachers unions around Australia. When this is achieved, our education system will be more responsive, flexible and creative in equipping young Australians. Governments will not be required to intervene in a distorted manner such as in providing a PEP effort. The natural forces will be able to operate effectively in challenging redundant and wasteful activities in schools and colleges as they arise. We do not need programs such as PEP in our schools. We need a total rethink of the way in which we approach education.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Price Mr L.R.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very disappointed that attacks have been made by the honourable member for Braddon (Mr Miles), and also by the shadow Minister, the honourable member for Tangney (Mr Shack), on the participation and equity program. They have not argued for greater equality and equity in our education system but have sought merely to entrench the privileges that come from private school education. The honourable member for Tangney has not advanced a case for the poor diocesan schools that exist in this country but for even greater privilege and inequity in the other non-government schools. On the subject of PEP, I point out to all the parents and citizens associations and the parents and friends in my electorate, whose schools in 1984 received $210,000 and up to 6 June 1985 received $298,000, that if the honourable member for Braddon had his way those funds would not be available. I seek leave to table a list of the amounts of money these schools have received in the time period to which I have referred.
—Order! Is the honourable member seeking permission to table a document or to incorporate it?
—I am seeking leave to incorporate it.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Subject to the ruling of Madam Speaker in relation to suitability for inclusion, leave is granted.

INTERJECT.PARA: St Agnes' High School, Rooty Hill...

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker. On the question of families sticking together, no one can take any pride or satisfaction in the fact that some families are breaking up. In this day and age, all families, whether they involve single parents, spouses who do not have custody of children, or families that are strong and surviving, expect their children to be given the best possible education and a good start in life. I can relate to that attitude, and I think education policy should address that area.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to comment specifically on the campaign for a western Sydney university. Mr Deputy Speaker, with your presence and the presence of the Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism (Mr John Brown), who is at the table, and of the honourable member for Lindsay (Mr Free), we have perhaps a western suburbs mafia in the House! I was very pleased to attend at Macquarie Street approximately a month ago a discussion with the Federal Minister for Education (Senator Ryan), the Premier, the State Minister for Education and State Ministers and members. That meeting agreed to set up an advisory committee to determine the form of the university and the timetable. I think it was an historic meeting. I must say, though, that it is a matter of disappointment to me that my Federal colleagues have yet to be officially briefed on the outcome of that meeting. I certainly hope that that will occur shortly. I have to say frankly to my State colleagues that, whilst I do not doubt their commitment or their determination to see the western suburbs university reach fruition, I believe for it to happen will require a commitment on their part of a financial contribution towards the university. I think it is unreal to expect, in our tight economic situation and restraint on public expenditure, that the Federal Government can advance the priorities of this institution without some reciprocity from the State Government. I hope that reciprocity will occur.

I have another concern which I think I should lay before the House; that is, it is rumoured that the Doonside Overseas Telecommunications Commission site, a magnificent site comprising some 165 hectares and 25 hectares of State Government land, has been nominated as one of two sites for either the fourth main campus or a college. I have in my possession a letter from the Blacktown City Council which advises me that the State Government has appointed some consultants. Craig and Rhodes Consultants Pty Ltd are project managers for the Department of Housing and are doing an evaluation to turn this land into broad acres residential sub-division. I know the Minister for Local Government and Administrative Services (Mr Uren), a staunch supporter of a western suburbs university, will refrain from any negotiations with the State Government which would prematurely exclude this site from consideration. I find this development very confusing, particularly as I happen to know that the Premier of New South Wales has indeed written to the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) seeking an undertaking from him that this land be considered and be held available, as it is, for the site of a university.

The person identified as perhaps the leading opponent of the western suburbs university is-I do not think I am being original in saying this-Mr Hudson, the Chairman of the Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission. I want to take issue with Mr Hudson on some of his comments in response to the Parry report, the report of the Ministerial Committee to Review the Structure of Higher Education in Western Sydney. I want to make it quite clear that I am neither advocating what was suggested in the Parry report, nor am I particularly advocating what the Minister, Susan Ryan, has laid on the table; that is, the development of a college which ultimately will become a university. I do not think it is appropriate to try to pick and choose between those. In the response he suggests that the real need for higher education in the west is for institute of technology-type facilities. I am not saying that we would not benefit from that, nor is it without the realms of possibility that an institute of technology-type facility be developed at one of the fine colleges of advanced education at Nepean, Hawkesbury and Macarthur, which would have an appropriate focus and leaning. However, I do reject the inference that people of the west should not have within their region access to a university.

Mr Hudson also claims that the Parry Committee's terms of reference exclude Sydney's south-west. I think this is one of the most mischievous things he has attempted to do. He has attempted to drive a wedge between various Federal members and various State members on a west versus south-west basis-it is exceptionally mischievous. As the Premier pointed out at the meeting with Susan Ryan, we all know the area we are talking about-that is, the greater western suburbs of Sydney. Irrespective of whether the institution goes to the south-west or west, I am not going to get up here and say it has been a colossal defeat. I think all members are looking for a university in the greater western suburbs of Sydney, and this attempt to divide us has failed so far in the past and will continue to fail in the future.

TALK.START.PARA: —Parramatta.

—As everyone knows, the Minister has a particular penchant for Parramatta. We already have a fine stadium there and we are going to get some Commonwealth offices there. Indeed, Parramatta might be one of the choices. The Parry report said the fourth main campus should be either at Parramatta or at Blacktown. I want to say this to Mr Hudson: If he thinks he is going to pick off State or Federal members on the basis of location, he has been wrong to date and I believe he will be wrong in the future.

SPEECH.PARA: The other thing Mr Hudson highlights in his report-I think it was equally mischievous-is a differentiation between a university and a college of advanced education. He points out that the main difference is that a university undertakes research. What he misrepresents is what was said in discussions with western suburbs members, and Mr Hudson, that we said our priority was to get a university. If he feels that, because of the high cost of research, this should be deferred for a period, certainly we will go along with that. We will try to be reasonable; we will try to facilitate getting a university in the western suburbs of Sydney. If that is what he wants to do, fair enough, we will compromise on that. In his response he bashes us over the head with what I thought was a reasonable position, a reasonable compromise. He also states:

The Commission has stated on a number of occasions that higher education in the west and south-west of Sydney must be related to the future industrial and technological needs of the area as well as to social/personal needs of the population. It is an area with a rapidly growing young population with expanding manufacturing, construction and commercial sectors.

I do not essentially disagree with that, but I do say that people from the western suburbs should have the same freedom of choice as others have about subjects and should not be classified or limited in what they undertake. In making his comments about the expanding manufacturing, construction and commercial sectors I think he overlooks the fact that, notwithstanding that those things are happening, the western suburbs are vast dormitory suburbs of Sydney. In fact, one of the real problems is-I have been involved in local technical and further education and the local hospital-that when we are trying to construct things that have a regional flavour about them or meet a regional need we just do not have the industry to do that.

Essentially we are training young people in the western suburbs for jobs outside the western suburbs. No one more than I would like to see that situation reversed. I would be misleading the House if I suggested it has been reversed-it has not. I hope that Mr Hudson, having expressed these views, will write to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) and suggest to him that we have a regional industry plan. I would go along with that. The problem is that we have not had a car manufacturing establishment collapse or a steel plant collapse; we just have not had enough industry. I agree that an industry plan would be great for the area and that all institutions should try as much as possible to reflect regional needs, be they industry, social or whatever nature.

The other comment in the report that I would like to address is that the move for a university will inevitably dampen any effort that can be made to open up access to higher education for those who succeed in TAFE. Hugh Hudson has made the point quite validly that there is a very strong TAFE presence in the western suburbs of Sydney. At the risk of repeating his figures that do not include the south-western region, there are something like 30,000 TAFE students. I believe that one of the excellent features of the Parry report, which in fact supports Hugh Hudson's view, is the recommendation that we ought to open up colleges of advanced education and universities so that students who have succeeded at TAFE, rather than their having to start back at year 1 at a CAE or at a university, may be given recognition at these institutions of higher learning to the work done and the success achieved at TAFE. I certainly do not see this and the provision of a university as mutually exclusive nor should this initiative be lost. I believe it is one of the most exciting proposals that we have had for a long time, and I am determined to support it to the hilt.

Of course, it is a matter of some notoriety that Hugh Hudson, in his response, made a great deal of low participation rates in years 11 and 12 at the high schools in the western suburbs of Sydney. I have already placed a question on notice asking when he first became concerned about the matter and what action he has taken in relation to it. Personally, I think if one is a supporter of public education, as I am, from time to time one has to make constructive criticism of the system and one has to observe the reality of the facts. Generally speaking, over the last decade in Australia, we have moved from a participation rate of something like 33 per cent to 45 per cent. That is very good. Unfortunately, New South Wales has one of the lowest rates. Mr Hudson, in his report, suggested that in western Sydney the participation rate was something like 15 per cent to 20 per cent, which was denied by the State Minister for Education, who suggested that it was 30 per cent. An argument about correct percentages is irrelevant. What is important is that we ought to do better. Mr Deputy Speaker, I seek leave to table a table of retention rates to year 12 for 1984.

TALK.START.PARA: —Does the honourable member want to table it or have it incorporated?
—I am sorry; I seek leave to have it incorporated in Hansard.
—Leave is granted for that purpose, but it is subject to the usual ruling.

—I thank the shadow Minister and I thank the House. Of the mainland States, this table shows that Queensland is doing best, with a retention rate of 53 per cent. I cannot help but note that the Australian Capital Territory has a rate of 79 per cent. In this debate about education we have to come to terms with what we ought to be aiming for. Should we be aiming for 50, 60, 70, 80 or 90 per cent? I believe, being committed to the concept of people having an equality of opportunity, and because jobs still largely depend on one's success at school, that we should be aiming for higher retention levels.

SPEECH.PARA: There is a distortion in the participation rates for state and non-government schools. The rate for government schools in Australia is 38.4 per cent. For non-government schools it is 65.3 per cent. The relevant figures in New South Wales are 36.1 per cent for government schools and 58.5 per cent for non-government schools. If we break down those figures for New South Wales, on the non-government side, Anglican schools have a 92 per cent participation rate, the Catholic schools have 54.6 per cent and the others 93.3 per cent. It is a matter of regret that the school one goes to largely determines the outcome in relation to one's participation in years 11 and 12. I believe that there is a real need to lift those participation rates. Let us not talk about matching Queensland, which has 53 per cent, or of matching the non-government schools, which have a rate of 58.5 per cent; let us settle on the Australian Capital Territory figure of 79 per cent. Why can we not have an objective of 79 or 80 per cent? I certainly believe that we should.

I am running a little out of time. As honourable members know, I have spoken a number of times about the need for a senior high school. The Australian Capital Territory, of course, has a senior high school set-up which has worked particularly well. I believe that one of the solutions towards lifting the participation rate is to provide a university for the western suburbs of Sydney so that it could be both inspirational and aspirational. I also believe that senior high schools should be developed. I was pleased to read in yesterday's Sydney Morning Herald and in the Daily Telegraph that the Acting Premier of New South Wales, Mr Ron Mulock, has picked up the campaign that has been waged by the State member for Riverstone, Richard Amery, to get a senior high school in the western suburbs of Sydney. I know that Tweed Heads is one of the leading candidates for a senior high school. I am pleased about that. I do not believe that Tweed Heads should be denied that school. But it would be a mockery to ignore one of the largest regions in Sydney-a region with one of the largest populations, whichever one's definition; it could be one million people or one and a half million people-and not set about establishing those senior high schools.

I am confident that the campaign for a senior high school will succeed. I am confident that in my area in western Sydney, with the commitment of my Federal and State colleagues, not only will we get a university but also we will have increasing participation rates, and the real talents and the abilities of the people of the western suburbs will be recognised and developed. Before I close, I want very much on my own behalf to issue a personal invitation to the Minister for Education to come out to my electorate to see the high schools, to have a look at what impact a senior high school might make and at how the TAFE colleges are going and see what a tremendous impact a university would have in my electorate. I know that my colleagues would join me in that invitation. I hope that we hear a public response to it.

—It is, Mr Deputy Speaker. I thank you for your assistance.
