SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hicks Mr N.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The purpose of the States Grants (Education Assistance-Participation and Equity) Amendment Bill and cognate Bills is to provide retrospective cost supplementation to grants made by the Commonwealth to assist the school and tertiary education sector. I would like to raise a number of matters in the House today, but time is short. I know that other members of the coalition have a great deal of important matters that they would like to raise so I will shorten my speech. I would like to speak about non-government schools. I would like to speak about tertiary education but, unfortunately, time does not provide for that.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the greatest assets that a nation has is its education system. Honourable members who have read anything about Germany and Japan, particularly after the Second World War, will be aware of the course those nations took in educating their populations. We know where those nations stand on the world stage today. If we look at the education results-I will talk particularly about New South Wales-many of the names of those students on the list of candidates who scored the highest aggregate marks in that State are names that are not normally associated with the basic Anglo-Saxon names in our country. We see that those people who come from other nations realise the great importance of education to their children. Although some of them may come from low socioeconomic groups, we find that their major priority lies in educating their children. They may go without a motor car, they may go without a new suit every six months, but one thing they will not go without is education for their children.

I believe that the education system in Australia, certainly in New South Wales, is second to none in the world. The majority of teachers in New South Wales are absolutely dedicated. One of the good things about the education system is that it strives for equality. No matter what one's socio-economic background or geographic location, the aim is to provide equality of education. In the main the teachers are dedicated-in the schools I visit, in any case. The parents, in the main, are dedicated. Of course, a good education system needs the dedication of the students also.

We find today that teachers are under extreme pressure because of the breakdown of the family unit and the problem of alcohol and drugs. All of these things are impinging on the education system and making the job of teachers extremely difficult. For example, I visited a school where the principal said to me that he had had a phone call from the mother of one of the boys in his school complaining about the language that that young student was using at home. I can imagine what I would have said to that parent if I were the teacher. Many parents, of course, are abrogating their responsibilities and putting them on to the teachers in the school, making it very difficult not only for the teachers but also for everyone associated with the school.

We also have the lowering of the standard of living in this country, particularly in the case of larger families. Many such families are living just beyond the poverty line. We notice that family allowances have declined in value by around 50 per cent since 1976. This makes it extremely difficult for families. By December 1987 the dependant spouse rebate will have declined in value by about 27 per cent since November 1982. Further financial pressure has been placed on large families by the abolition of the general concessionary rebate in 1984-85 and by the Government's decision last year to abolish family allowances for 18-year-olds. I think we have to remember that today many families have 18-year-old children still attending school.

We see that millions of dollars are being spent in the family law area helping to split up families, whereas very little is being spent on keeping families together. All of this is putting great pressure on our education system-the school system in particular and on families. We see the interference of politicians. Some politicians, believing that there are minority groups from which they may gain a few votes, try to influence the education system in favour of teaching subjects which, when I had a phone around before I came in to make this speech, I discovered many teachers refer to as absolute garbage.

The Australian Teachers Federation does not help. It was designed in part to provide a form of constructive criticism of the education system and to do what it could in that area. What has happened, unfortunately, is that we have a lot of destructive criticism and actions by the Teachers Federation. I note that there does not seem to be as much agitation today as there used to be in a number of these areas-agitation which was destructive of our education system.

As I said, in many schools teachers are forced to teach subjects which they really do not want to teach. What they want to do is get on with the job of teaching the children so that those children can adapt to an ever-changing world. However, we have subjects such as sex education which, I believe, really should be taught in the home. I suppose teachers are forced to teach them because parents will not take on the job. Subjects such as sexism, peace studies, multiculturalism, equal opportunities and human rights are taught. On the subject of the Human Rights Commission, I refer to a booklet, a little beauty, entitled `Teaching for Human Rights', by Ralph Pettman. This booklet was referred to on many occasions during the debate on the Bill of Rights legislation. While we are teaching all these types of things in schools we cannot get on with teaching the children those things that will adapt them and prepare them for their lives in the future.

Of course, the Human Rights Commission is becoming notorious. There is an advertisement in one of its latest magazines for a seminar on how people can stick up for their rights and protest peacefully. I would like to see the Human Rights Commission, for a change, having a seminar on people's responsibilities, not their rights. I think we have taken this thing a bit too far. I think it is about time we accepted that there are responsibilities. One of the agenda items relates to how to picket premises and so on. I think it is about time, in view of the present economic climate, that we stopped wasting money and spent some money on doing something a little more constructive.

In summary, I am sure that, if teachers were allowed to get on with the job of educating their pupils for the future and developing the children by evolution rather than revolution, we would get a lot further. A tendency seems to be developing in the nation to try to socially engineer everyone. I am sure that the parents, in the home, are the people who have the greatest responsibility for educating their children. I am sure that they impart to their children the values and rights that they want to impart. It is not up to teachers to try to socially engineer their students. I am sure that 99.9 per cent of teachers do not want that role. However, we are spending millions of dollars on bringing all this garbage, as I call it, into schools to try to socially engineer the children.

Let us look at some of the more parochial problems facing schools today. As most honourable members would know, I represent a fairly isolated rural electorate. We always have problems trying to get teachers into the west, particularly the west of New South Wales. I think that something drastic has to be done about that. I think that for the sake of the teachers we have to have accelerated promotion and priority of choice. In other words, once teachers have been posted to an isolated area-I do not mean the north coast of New South Wales or an inner city area-they should have some priority of choice when they leave those areas. I think that the Government should be responsible for paying those teachers' moving expenses when they do move.

A teacher I know has been transferred to an isolated area. Apparently, if he leaves that area before the three years are up he will have to pay his own removal costs back to the coast or wherever he came from. I do not think that is fair. We have to try to support these teachers. It is bad enough that they have to leave their homes to go into isolated areas, although I must admit that, in some cases, once they get there they are very reluctant to go back to where they came from. However, getting them there initially is a problem. I believe that in New South Wales last year 45 teaching places in high schools could not be filled. I think that is a little unfair on the students who are trying to be educated. It is unfair to the schools, to the system and, of course, to the parents who are paying their taxes to have their children attend school.

In the west we have a particular problem with school counselling facilities. As I said before, one of the problems facing us today, for many reasons, is the fact that there is a great deal of family breakdown. I believe that governments can do something about that. They can contribute towards keeping families together by supporting the family unit. They can provide some means, through taxation or other measures, to keep families together. We have a bipartisan immigration policy, which I fully support. The Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Hurford) said recently that Australia needs a greater population, that its population is aging. I am sure the population of Australia could be increased if there were some way in which governments could give support to the family unit. As the honourable member for Braddon (Mr Miles) said, the family unit is the basic unit of our society. We must keep that family unit together and try to ensure that our nation grows stronger as a result.

To return to the subject of education, in the west of New South Wales we are short of school counsellors to deal with the many problems we face, such as family breakdowns and so on. I bring that matter to the attention of honourable members. Something needs to be done about that very serious problem. Another problem that was brought to my attention concerns the fact that if students in rural areas want to learn something about, say, the steelworks at Whyalla or jobs in Sydney, it is very difficult for them to go to those places to get work experience. Unfortunately, job opportunities in the bush are very limited. It is unfortunate that young students do not get that opportunity simply because there is a lack of funding for them to do so. Of course, there is also a lack of funding to enable those people who are promoting certain occupations to come into the country to show the students what is available. That is something else that government could look at. We find also when a child eventually goes for a job interview that there are problems with this as well. There are a lot of disabilities for people in rural areas. They are something to be looked at.

In the past, particularly in primary schools and high schools, there have been problems with supplying teachers' aides. One of the major developments that have come about-I think it is a good development-is that ancillary staff are provided in schools to assist teachers. With the many pressures on teachers now when so much has to be learned and so much has to be imparted to the children, those aides play a major role in schools. The New South Wales Government is talking about cutting back on the numbers of aides and staff in schools. That means that teachers will have to return to the bad old days-they will have to do all the work around the place instead of doing what they should be doing and that is teaching children. Teachers need more in-course training in subjects such as how they should respond to certain ethnic groups in their schools. They should be given training on how to respond, for example, if they have a large Aboriginal population in the school. All these things need in-service training.

The honourable member for Braddon spoke earlier about the participation and equity program. I have spoken to many teachers about this program and they think that it is a failure. Certainly it brings money into the school but if we want children to stay on at school in years 11 and 12 in order to further their education, we must start encouraging them to do so earlier. Once they get to year 11 it is too late. We must encourage children to know where they are going and what they intend to do in their earlier years. We must get them into that mode of staying at school. The money that is being expended through PEP should be spent on children in years 8, 9 and 10 and there should be some interrelation between high schools and local technical and further education colleges, if there are such colleges in the area.

Finally, I have been a member of the coalition committee for education and we have formulated a policy. Whether it is announced by the Government or by the coalition does not really matter-it is a good policy and the coalition can be proud of it. It is innovative and I wish to congratulate members of that committee for the great work that they have done. I believe that the Government is on the wrong track in many areas of education. I refer particularly to some of the subjects that are taught in schools. I was in Wilcannia the other day and I read in a newspaper that there would be special courses there to teach Aboriginal people Aboriginal dialects. I do not know how many people in New South Wales can speak any dialect of any particular Aboriginal tribe, but I do not think that there are too many. That appears to be a bit of a waste. I am one of those people who believes in promoting our heritage and I think we should keep it. If people have some spare time, perhaps they should learn Aboriginal dialects, but that is their choice. While I was in Wilcannia I spoke to an Aboriginal gentleman who was sitting next to me. He had a particular problem. I told him that if he gave me his name and address I would send him some information relating to his problem. He said: `I am sorry, Mister, I cannot read or write'. This gentleman was 30 years old. There is something wrong with our priorities when we spend thousands and thousands of dollars on way-out weird schemes yet we have people in our community who cannot read or write and take their rightful place in society. That Aboriginal gentleman was very embarrassed about the fact that he could not read or write. I told him that there was nothing to be embarrassed about, that the problem was with the system and that something had to be done about it. While we are teaching all this other unnecessary rubbish, we still have people in our community who cannot read and write, and there is something drastically wrong with that. I will leave my remarks there but will just repeat my congratulations to the coalition committee on the formulation of its education policies, which, I hope, will be announced by the coalition. However, if the Government announces them, it can be proud of those policies also.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Free Mr R.V.

TALK.START.PARA: —Like my colleague the honourable member for Chifley (Mr Price) who spoke earlier in this debate on the States Grants (Education Assistance-Participation and Equity) Amendment Bill, I wish to address some remarks to the matter of progress towards the establishment of a university in western Sydney and to express some pleasure on the progress that has been made so far. There have been four major developments to date this year. The first was the release of the report of the New South Wales ministerial working party in February. Honourable members will recall that that report recommended the establishment of an autonomous, multicampus university in the western Sydney region. That was followed by the release of the response by the Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission on 14 April of which we have heard something this morning. Two days later this was followed by a Press conference conducted by the Federal Minister for Education, Senator Susan Ryan. This Press conference was a major development in the whole exercise, and because it was so important I wish to quote a little from the Press brief which covered it. It said:

SPEECH.PARA: The western suburbs of Sydney would have their own university by the 1991 triennium, Federal Education Minister, Senator Susan Ryan said today-
that is, on 16 April. The brief continued:

It would probably be in the form of a university college and branch of the University of New South Wales . . . The Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission has recommended the development of the university college in the triennium 1991, Senator Ryan said.
The Federal Government agreed with this proposal but if the NSW Government wanted a university or university college before that time it would need to provide extra funding.
The University of Wollongong and the University of Newcastle both began as university colleges of the UNSW.
Senator Ryan said that the Government had held discussions with the chancellors of Sydney's three universities, the University of New South Wales, Sydney University and Macquarie University.
Further discussions between the Federal and State Governments would establish just how much funding was needed and whether the project for a fourth university in Sydney would go ahead earlier.
However, if the retention rates at secondary schools in the western and south western suburbs did not improve, the chances of establishing a university in the area would be lower.
Retention rates at western suburbs secondary schools are currently far lower than elsewhere in New South Wales.

That is the end of the Press brief. After the Press conference there was a meeting on 23 April between Senator Ryan, the New South Wales Premier and the New South Wales Education Minister. As a result of that meeting a joint statement was issued which contained five very important elements. The meeting acknowledged the very serious educational disadvantage of students in the western suburbs of Sydney and recognised the need to support increased opportunities for all levels of education throughout the region, including a university. Secondly, the meeting supported the strategy of extending the scope and quality of places in colleges of advanced education in the region. Thirdly, the meeting accepted as a matter of urgency the need to plan for the establishment of a university presence in the western area. Fourthly, it was agreed that the Commonwealth and New South Wales governments, through CTEC and the New South Wales Higher Education Board, should co-operate with existing CAE's and universities and the proposed University of Western Sydney Advisory Council to investigate the most appropriate model for the university campus development, to determine the resource implications and to prepare a timetable for the fulfilment of that agreed purpose. Finally, the meeting agreed to keep a watching brief on the work of both the advisory committee and the various agencies of government. Both governments will receive reports arising from the deliberation of those bodies.

I stress the three very important tasks that the advisory council has. It must determine the most appropriate model for university development in the region. It has been asked to report on the resource implications of the preferred model and it must prepare a timetable for implementation. Interest throughout the western Sydney region has been very strong. There has been a lively debate in the local media and the proposals have attracted enthusiastic support from community groups, educationalists and members of the general public. It has attracted some interest from the private sector and strong support from local elected members of the State Parliament, particularly my colleagues Ron Mulock, Peter Anderson and the member for Riverstone, Richard Amery. It has also had support from Labor senators and western Sydney members of the House of Representatives, particularly my colleague the honourable member for Chifley whose interest-as we have heard this morning-is enthusiastic and unflagging.

I also wish to pay particular tribute to the work of the Western Sydney Regional Organisation of Councils and its chairman, Alderman David March. These people have been most persistent on this issue and have pursued it for a long time. I also wish to welcome support from Liberal members in the area. As you know, Mr Deputy Speaker, there are very few Liberal members in western Sydney, they are not terribly thick on the ground. However, I welcome the bipartisan support for this proposal particularly from the honourable member for Mitchell (Mr Cadman) and the honourable member for Macquarie (Mr Webster). Earlier in this debate the honourable member for Riverina-Darling (Mr Hicks) talked about the virtues of bipartisanship in a different respect. I certainly welcome bipartisan support in this regard. In doing so I deliver a gentle rebuke to my friend the honourable member for Macquarie because his support, while welcome, has not been entirely uncritical. I refer to a Press release from the honourable member for Macquarie which appeared in the 30 April issue of the Mountain Gazette. The honourable member in that Press statement welcomed developments towards the establishment of a university. That is fine; I welcome that, too. However, in the statement he also made two criticisms of the Government which I believe are quite unfair. The first criticism concerns the timing of the whole matter. He referred to the `belated recognition of the urgency of the problem of educational disadvantage in the west'. The statement continued:

. . . he was concerned at the ambiguity of the Government's statement concerning a `university presence', stating that nothing less than a new University for the West, even if by building on current CAE facilities, would be acceptable.

I make some comments on the two criticisms the honourable member made. I refer first to the question of a belated recognition of the problems we face. I agree that this move is certainly overdue, but I point out to the honourable member that he should ask himself a number of questions. He should ask himself who was in power federally for 31 of the last 37 years. The answer is his own Party, the Liberal Party. He should ask himself who was in power in New South Wales between 1965 and 1976-those years when western Sydney's population was expanding so dramatically. The answer, again, is his own Party, the Liberal Party. He should ask himself who was responsible for the siting of Macquarie University. Again, the answer is his own Party. It is true that the Liberals when in government consistently served the interests of their supporters on the North Shore. It is a matter of history that under the Liberals, western Sydney did not just run second, it was never in the race.

It is idle for the honourable member for Macquarie to blame the Labor Government for the failings of his own Party over the many years it enjoyed in office. In an editorial on 7 May headed `Going West by degrees', the Sydney Morning Herald made exactly that point:

A crucial decision affecting the present proposal for a University of Western Sydney-or Miles Franklin University as some people want to call it-was unfortunately taken two decades ago when Macquarie University was established. Demographic logic demanded that the university be sited in the western suburbs where an accelerating urban sprawl was taking place. This is even more true now, of course. But the decision finally turned on political considerations. The Menzies Government held the purse-strings, and it was determined to ensure that political benefits would accrue to itself from the decision; hence the foundation of Macquarie University at Ryde, an area set among a cluster of then federal Liberal seats.

If the honourable member wants a clearer illustration of Liberal attitudes to expansion of higher education opportunities in the west-an illustration a little closer to home-let me refer him to the words of his Liberal predecessor in the seat of Macquarie. I refer him to the then member's speech of 20 October 1977 at page 2276 of Hansard. The then member criticised developments in western Sydney on two grounds. He said that expansion had been too rapid and he actually suggested the closure of some colleges of advanced education. The then member, Mr Gillard, stated:

For many years, in fact well before I became a member of this House, I felt that universities and colleges of advanced education were advancing too quickly. The whole attitude of these institutions was expansion with no apparent regard to costs.

When we arrive at a stage when the chairman of a college of advanced education suggests that perhaps it is time for some colleges to close then it is time for this Government and the new Tertiary Education Commission to look closely at what is happening in the tertiary field.

The honourable member was remarkably coy about nominating colleges that he would like to close, but he did have two major complaints. He said that there were some courses that had enrolments that were far too small, and he complained about the proliferation of business courses. As I say, he was careful not to nominate the particular colleges, but if one reads his speech, one will find listed the courses that had small enrolments. The course with the smallest enrolment in New South Wales at that stage was a home science teachers course at Hawkesbury CAE-a college of advanced education in the west-which had 29 enrolments. He complained about the growth of business courses. The business course with the second smallest enrolment in the State at the time was at Nepean CAE-in the west. As one can imagine, this speech horrified the local community and educationalists across the State. It attracted a full page article in the National Times, which was distributed pretty widely locally. In general, I think it helped rid the locality of that member. I remind the present member for Macquarie-he should reflect on this-that if his Liberal predecessor in the seat had had his way, there would be no Hawkesbury College of Advanced Education in his electorate, there would be no Nepean College of Advanced Education in my electorate, and there would be no higher education places in the west.

Another comment the honourable member made in his Press statement was that nothing less than a full university would be acceptable. I take his use of the word `full' to mean an autonomous university that would operate from day one. I suggest that immediate autonomy may not be the most desirable model. In fact, it may not be in the best interests of the region to have an autonomous institution from day one. Indeed, many of the most enthusiastic supporters of the university concept-some of them perhaps not as well briefed as they might be-have become hung up on the Commonwealth's use of the term `university presence', a term which clearly suggests that the new institution should start as an affiliate or a college of an established university.

I ask the honourable member to consider the advantages that affiliation might bring to the new university in its early years of development. I believe there are five very significant advantages that ought to be considered. They concern status, enhanced transfer arrangements, costs, staffing and, finally, the historical success of the affiliation model. Turning first to status, I think we all recognise that new institutions in the tertiary field always encounter problems of status. When the University of New South Wales was established it certainly suffered because of the status gap between it and the other university in Sydney at the time, the long established Sydney University. Indeed, I remember something that an overseas student told me during my years at the University of New South Wales. It is a very telling illustration of how much status can matter. The overseas student told me that in his country a `BA fail' from Oxford or Cambridge was more highly regarded than a degree from an Australian university.

I suggest that the idea of a new autonomous institution granting its own degrees would face at least two handicaps: First, the status gap which afflicts all new institutions; and secondly, an additional status gap which might well arise because of the establishment of a university to meet the needs of a particular disadvantaged region. I recognise that the latter problem cannot really be avoided, but the former certainly can. By affiliation in the early years, by granting degrees in the early years through the parent institution, the graduates of the western Sydney campus would hold qualifications which would be seen to be equal to the best. That to me is a very desirable outcome.

A number of advantages could flow from affiliation in terms of transfer arrangements. I believe that these are important. It has been agreed that some courses are unlikely ever to be offered on the western Sydney campus. Both reports agree that such courses would include at least medicine, dentistry and veterinary science. Under the autonomy proposal, students from the western region wishing to enrol in these courses would have to enrol at the established universities to the east, but if the new campus were linked to an established university at least the first year of these courses could be studied locally.

There are, of course, advantages in cost savings as well if the affiliated model is adopted. We recognise that university places are more expensive than colleges of advanced education places, mainly because of the extra costs involved in the provision of research facilities. We also recognise that the need in the region is for undergraduate places. If this need is to be met by establishing a university without a research capacity, two problems could arise. There is the definitional problem that was raised by the Chairman of the Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission in his response. I believe it is a real problem. If research capacity is the feature that distinguishes between universities and CAEs, and a university is established without a research capacity, clearly, as Mr Hudson said in his response, we will have a university in name only and we compound the status problem.

Problems also arise in respect of staffing. Without canvassing the question of whether the best researchers necessarily make the best university teachers, I would accept the argument that a research capacity is still essential if one is to attract high calibre staff. Offering, as it would, the use of existing research capacities, affiliation seems to me to offer the best prospect of avoiding problems that would arise with costs, definition and attracting staff of high calibre.

Finally, I point to the historical success of development through the affiliation model. As the Minister for Education pointed out in her Press conference, the universities of Newcastle and Wollongong both developed as colleges of the University of New South Wales. The University of New England at Armidale started off as a college of Sydney University. The Australian National University in Canberra also began as a university college. I believe that, given the proper timetable, there is every reason to expect that affiliation would be equally successful in this case.

There are, of course, a variety of models for development, not just the Parry full, immediate autonomy model or the college approach which has been outlined. There is also the possibility of a two-tier model. The new institution could be developed with an undergraduate division and a research and higher degree division, each having its own timetable for autonomy. I trust that the advisory council will give proper consideration to all the possibilities in its deliberations. I agree that there will be problems. These are inevitable, but they should not be self-inflicted as a result of poor initial planning. CTEC and the Minister have both pointed out that participation in the region is a problem. CTEC has very correctly said that the region has the lowest secondary retention rates in Australia. However, I point out that some improvements have been made and I look forward to those improvements continuing under this Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sullivan Mrs K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am grateful to the honourable member for Lindsay (Mr Free) for reminding me early in his speech of who was in power when certain things happened in the education sphere. He reminded me that the great expansion of education at all levels federally has been under Liberal governments. For example, the great expansion in the tertiary area was largely thanks to the late Sir Robert Gordon Menzies, who was a great promoter of tertiary education at a time when it was scarce in Australia. He foresaw the needs of the future and moved very decisively-with a not altogether co-operative Cabinet-to expand mightily tertiary education in the universities and colleges, back in the 1950s and 1960s. I am also reminded, of course, that a former Labor Prime Minister, Mr Whitlam, is credited with great advances in education. I place on record that some advances in education were the result of the Whitlam Government. However, on the election of the Fraser Government, rationalisation had to take place in the organisation of those educational changes. Typically of Whitlam Government policies, the changes in the education area were pell mell and we inherited a great mish mash, a mess, a mindless growth in certain areas, to which the honourable member for Lindsay also referred when he put forward the views of a former member of this place. The real progress in education in Australia, federally anyway, has been made under Liberal governments.

SPEECH.PARA: In this debate today we are debating the States Grants (Education Assistance-Participation and Equity) Amendment Bill 1986, the States Grants (Schools Assistance) Amendment Bill 1986 and the States Grants (Tertiary Education Assistance) Amendment Bill 1986. Such a debate occurs only twice a year and it is rare for any other occasion to arise when the House of Representatives can debate the subject of education. This is a great pity because, in my opinion, the growth, development and future direction of education is critical to the future of this country. We are embarking on a cognate debate which enables us to talk about any area covered by those Bills and gives us the opportunity to put forward some ideas. It is a matter of great disappointment to me, as the seventh speaker after the Minister for Science (Mr Barry Jones) in this debate, that so little has been contributed from the Government side to what one would call an education debate, as distinct from a strictly parochial debate.

I congratulate the shadow Minister for Education and Youth Affairs, the honourable member for Tangney (Mr Shack), for his contribution. He has made a substantial contribution to the education debate in Australia, both in this chamber when the rare occasion has arisen, and outside. He has seen it, as does the Opposition generally, as a major part of the Opposition's role to stimulate debate on education policy-a debate which, if left to the Government, would have become an increasingly sterile one. It is important that we, here in the Parliament and outside the Parliament, contribute to a vigorous education debate because of the significance of the decisions that are made now about education for the future of this country. We are now in what is called the age of technology, when learning skills-the refinement of skills and the development of new skills-we are told, are to be the norm throughout life. It should, therefore, be a time for great expansion of educational opportunity and for the raising of educational levels in Australia. For a variety of reasons, some of which are cultural-partly Australian culture and partly the culture of other countries-Australia has for some time been notorious for the low level of its education compared with those of similar countries.

For some little time now I believe Australians have been aware of the great need to extend maximum opportunity to our young people. Maximum opportunity means not only maximum participation opportunities but also maximum opportunity to have access to the best that our educators can possibly offer. We need to face the challenge of maximum education for the maximum number, of re-educating many people throughout life, and of higher and higher educational skills. Gone are the days when a bachelors degree, for example, was a golden meal ticket for life. Those who are familiar with the education system now realise that a bachelors degree is but a start. Those who are ambitious and wish to progress in their working and professional lives inevitably will have to return again and again to the education system, seeking not just further bachelors degrees but very specialised education and, commonly, as occurs in a number of comparable countries, higher degree training. Australian educational establishments have responded to this challenge and in the 1970s the development of post-graduate degree courses-particularly the masters degree area-in their variety, scope and new form, was very exciting indeed. But there is not much value in educational institutions channelling their resources into meeting that challenge of the community and modern life if those who would partake of them are denied access.

At the moment Australia's education system, particularly in the tertiary area, is extremely inflexible, and to the measure it is inflexible it is irrelevant to the needs of citizens of this country. The effect of a Labor government has been to dampen down tertiary education-to put a dead hand on it as someone said earlier in the debate. Tertiary education has effectively plateaued in this country. This has happened far too prematurely because its base, as I explained earlier, was low for traditional reasons.

The Hawke Labor Government has also moved to strait-jacket schools education. It has attempted to confine the expansion of the private sector where much innovation and exciting educational development has traditionally taken place in Australia. That is not to say, I hasten to add, that exciting developments and innovation have not taken place in the public sector. They have. However, the approach, the starting point and the opportunities that present themselves in the private sector are different from those that present themselves in the public sector. If it should happen, for example, that one had a State government which was not very sympathetic to the challenge of developments in schools we have always had the safeguard of a strong and vigorous private sector to provide an alternative for parents of children in that State.

I well remember my primary and high school education in Queensland which `enjoyed' for some 30 years a State Labor government. I attended public schools for my primary schooling but when I faced my secondary education in the city of Brisbane, then a city with a population of half a million, I found that in the public sector I had an effective choice of three State high schools all of which were grossly overcrowded and under-supported by the State Labor Government. For those who wanted an effective secondary education in Brisbane in those days there was no choice but to go to a private school. Private schools were then extremely expensive because there was no government subsidy. They also suffered from overcrowding and lack of facilities because they attempted to keep their fees as low as humanly possible since they realised the pressures that were on the community for demand for places in secondary schools. That is an extreme position but it is one that could arise again. Without the safeguard of the private school sector, it would be all too easy for a State government to economise in the schools area. The private school system has made a major contribution to opportunities for and to the advancement of education in Australia. To now attempt to confine it, as the Government moves to confine it, in the development of new schools, the relocation of schools, or changes in the nature of existing schools in the private sector, shows that the motivation of this Government on the subject of its private schools policy is not a motivation geared to expansion but to the imposition of an artificial philosophy.

In the couple of minutes left to me before the House has to adjourn this debate, I want to make just this comment about the Hawke Labor Government's tertiary policy: It is expensive and it is exclusive. It is expensive because we cannot afford the loss of opportunity that young people, or indeed anyone, facing tertiary education these days meet with the limited number of places in our tertiary sector. There is no prospect of real expansion. Further, it is expensive because we cannot afford free education for all. It is exclusive because in limiting the number of places provided in tertiary education institutions, it limits the opportunity of having a tertiary education to only a percentage of those who meet entry qualifications. It represents a cavalier denial of opportunity.

I will say a final word on this subject of the coalition's schools policy as secretary of the coalition's policy committee on education and youth affairs. I am very intrigued by this policy that the Government apparently has in its possession. I am not aware that the coalition has yet reached the stage of having an official schools policy as such. I am only aware that certain drafts are around. However, I am also aware that it would not be very difficult to guess quite a few things about the Liberal and National parties' schools policy. I hasten to assure all those who have an interest in it that they can be confident, whatever the final proposals, that it will promote excellence and the maximum expansion of educational opportunity in this country.
