DEBATE.TITLE: GRIEVANCE DEBATE

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Crime-International Terrorism-Kurnell Peninsula-Australian Economy-Unemployment-Sri Lanka: Tamil Community-Government Responsibility

PROCTEXT.PARA: Question proposed:
That grievances be noted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Miles Mr C.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to spend the next 10 minutes having a look at the victims of crime and what we should do with this problem that we face as a nation. During this week the Parliament has focused much of its attention on the ever-worsening economic future of this great nation-and well it should. The Treasurer (Mr Keating) himself has likened our situation to that of a banana republic, and that underscores the seriousness of our overseas debt, our high interest rates, our high relative inflation rate and our large Budget deficits. But I put it to the Parliament and to the Australian people that a far more serious problem that Australia faces is the problem of authority, respect and orderliness in our society.

SPEECH.PARA: It is just over a year ago now that an article in the Australian caught my attention. It was headed `A million victims of urban violence in 1983'. Nobody in Australia can see such headlines and go home at night and forget about them without having serious thought as to where this nation is really headed. Economics-wise, yes, we spend a lot of time in this Parliament concerned about the economy. But what about people, the people in their homes? This year is the International Year of Peace, but what people are really worried about is not a nuclear bomb; what they worry about when they go to bed is whether they are going to be robbed or whether their children, when they go out for an evening to some entertainment, will be mugged. They are the things which people go home to and are worried about in our society.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is the trendies who get all the headlines.
—As the honourable member for Franklin says, every day one can look in the Australian papers and find violence and crime around this nation. That article went on to say:

SPEECH.PARA: Urban violence labelled by police as senseless, meaningless or at best petty is reaching alarming proportions. The new crime wave is marring lives with tragedy and striking fear into people already vulnerable, such as the elderly, children, new migrants and women travelling alone on public transport. In the past week there was a wanton slaughter of 64 animals in the Adelaide zoo-
that was last March, in 1985-
. . . a serious attack on an 86-year-old man and his wife in their Sydney home unit.
It went on:
These are just the tip of the proverbial iceberg in a society psychologists say is getting colder.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about our beautiful State of Tasmania? What happened down there?

—That is certainly the case, as the honourable member for Franklin says, because at the beginning of this year there were eight horrific murders in Tasmania in a space of only eight weeks. That is something quite unknown previously in Tasmania. But all these problems raise the issue of authority, respect and order in our society. Just confirming these paper headlines, the statistics of crime for the period 1972-1982 show the dramatic rise in crime. There is no way in which we can rationalise it away by saying: `Our police are now much more effective. It is because there is a greater proportion of young people in our society, and it is the 18 to 25-year-olds who create most of the crime'. There is no way in which we can rationalise this by assuming that these dramatic increases are caused by those circumstances. Homicide increased by 22 per cent in those 10 years; robbery increased by 63 per cent.
—That is only the reported cases.

—Serious assaults increased by 64 per cent. As the honourable member for Macquarie (Mr Webster) says, that is only the reported cases. Motor vehicle theft increased by 88 per cent; fraud, forgery and false pretences by 94 per cent; breaking and entering by 90 per cent; and, last of all, rape by 116 per cent. But the increase in Australia's population was 14 per cent over that period. We are faced with this major problem as a society, but we seem too scared to address it. Just to bring into focus what is going on in our society, only on Monday night I was talking with a young mother who said: `I am very concerned when I hear about boys in my neighbourhood who had watched a program on TV, on the video, a few weeks before, so when Mum and Dad were out and mice could play, they got the kittens, they dug a hole, they put them in the ground, and then they ran the motor-mower over them to cut their heads off. And why did they do it? They did it, they said, because that is what they had seen on one of the videos and they thought that it would be thrilling and exciting'.
—Horrifying!

—As the honourable member says, it is absolutely horrifying. Yet we turn a blind eye to these types of behaviour patterns, which many psychologists, many teachers and many parents know are developing in our society largely because of the ideas which are coming from videos and TV portraying some of these horrendous activities.
—What is the Government doing about it?

—As a society-it is not just the Government's problem-we must address this type of problem. People say that we have to let adults watch whatever they wish to watch, and largely I go along with that; but the problem that we are faced with in this society is that much of this horrific material is being watched by young people and now it is being expressed in their behaviour patterns. The way in which people model their lives in society is not by reading textbooks; it is by watching leaders in our society to see what they allow to happen and to see what they accept as being reasonable. The leaders of the Australian society since 1970 have said that it is acceptable for us to watch this type of material, and now we are seeing it come to fruition in the young people who have grown up under its influence.

SPEECH.PARA: As I said earlier, people do not go to bed and worry about whether they are going to be bombed with a nuclear bomb, but they do go to bed worrying about violence in our society and whether they will be intruded on that night. They worry about young women being raped, and even older women are not exempt from being raped. A 116 per cent increase in rape in 10 years is absolutely horrendous. What we have to do is to turn our society around from being a society which is materialistic and self-centred, and, as leaders in this place and as leaders in local government and State leaders, along with teachers and parents, refocus the attention of our society on to an approach which I would call `relational'. In other words, people would be given a high prominence, and relationships between people would be regarded as more important than buying flash cars, or building beautiful new homes, or going for overseas trips. That is not the essence of life. The essence of life is about the relationships which we have with each other, and, sadly, in our society these relationships are being degraded. It is about respect for authority, and we in this place, as people on which the younger generations will model their lives, have to show a keen sense of authority, when it needs to be used, and we must know when to back off. In regard to pornography and the violence that appears on some TV programs, we have to take a much firmer stand and take action in this way.

We have also got to take much more positive action in regard to crime, which is rampant in our society. I believe in the use of phone tapping, and there should be greater access to this. I know that civil libertarians will say it is not on, but I think we have to tackle this problem head on, rather than continually backing off and seeing our society slide into a quagmire.

I also believe that in our schools there should be a greater back-up by parents of the teachers towards an orderly approach in the classroom. It is becoming a jungle in many of our schools, and many of those teachers who are thoughtful, caring and sensitive, are saying `It is too much', and they are getting out, and we are leaving the classroom situation to only those people who are very strong, who have a physical carriage sufficient to carry the day in the classroom. That is very sad, because we are losing many of those people who are good models for young people out of the classroom-and they need good models.

Another aspect which arises in this area, and which has been raised from time to time, is capital punishment. I support the view of the honourable member for Franklin, who has called for the return of capital punishment. I think it is part of the solution. Just because other societies do not have it, that does not mean that the cultural background of Australia will support a situation where capital punishment is redundant. I believe it is part of our psyche.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Free Mr R.V.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for Braddon (Mr Miles) referred to the victims of crime. In this grievance debate I, too, want to grieve for some victims-the victims of international terrorism. On 15 April, the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) issued a statement following the American military action against Libya. There were three important elements in that statement that relate to the threat that international terrorism poses to the world community today. The first was the statement of the Australian belief that force is not the appropriate means to resolve international differences. Secondly, the statement demonstrated our understanding of the American predicament, a belief that the Americans were driven by Libyan action to that military response. Thirdly, there was an expression by our Government of a readiness to work with other governments to deal with international terrorism.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe that this response of the Australian Government was a correct and balanced one. I am pleased to observe that there are signs already that parts of the international community are increasingly prepared to look at ways of dealing in a concerted way with the problems of international terrorism. This concern is certainly overdue. There is ample evidence to show that the scale and, therefore, the costs of terrorism have grown alarmingly in recent times.

Last year, in 800 major attacks over 2,000 people were left dead or wounded. There were three major incidents at the end of 1985 which gained world attention. There was the hijack of the Italian cruise ship the Achille Lauro and the subsequent murder of an elderly American passenger in October. There was the hijack of Egyptair flight 648 in November, in which 56 people were killed, including one Australian. There were the attacks on the El Al counters at Rome and Vienna airports in December, which left 18 people dead and l21 wounded. Then, this year, there was the bombing of a Berlin night-club, which, of course, led to the American action against Libya. On 17 April, there was an attempt to plant a bomb on an El Al airliner at Heathrow airport, the so-called `girlfriend affair'. The execution of four hostages occurred in Lebanon. There was the attempted bombing of the American club in Turkey. There was the bombing of the American Express and Control Data premises in Lyon on 26 April, which followed the murder the day before of Black and Decker's principal executive in France.

These are just some of a number of atrocities which form a pattern of behaviour the total cost of which is incalculable, not just in terms of the lives lost and the human misery inflicted, not just in terms of the material costs of destroyed and damaged buildings and aircraft and so on, and in the provision of increased protection, but in the damage that has been caused to the established pattern of peaceful international relations.
Andrew Selth, in an article entitled `Terrorism-No-one is ``innocent'', no-one is ``neutral'' in the latest Current Affairs Bulletin, makes that point when he writes:

Some terrorist groups have no doubt attracted to their ranks followers who are mentally unstable or who act out of purely criminal motives. The majority, however, appear to be individuals (or representatives of states) who see terrorist tactics as legitimate means of pursuing political objectives.

It is this weakening of international order, the existence of two sets of rules or, rather, one group of nations following the rules and another group acting outside those rules, that poses the most serious challenge to us all. An examination of the characteristics of modern terrorism demonstrates some of the difficulties of dealing with it. Because of the essentially symbolic nature of both the target and the act, the modern terrorist operates in an extended battleground, making the location of preventive resources very difficult indeed, and because in terrorist acts restraint is increasingly cast aside, the location of appropriate levels of protection is also very difficult. The escalation of the scale of these attacks can be linked, at least in part, with the growth of state sponsorship of terrorism. As Selth says:
Not only are states providing greater support for terrorist groups around the world, but also to an increasing extent they are becoming directly involved in particular terrorist operations.

Given that the major focus of terrorism, particularly state sponsored terrorism, lies in its links with the Middle East, it follows that solutions must also lie in solving the complex problems of that region. As Selth and other writers have pointed out, these problems are political and socio-economic in nature, and they will ultimately only be solved by greater co-operation between states, continued quiet diplomacy and more imaginative approaches.

One such approach has been offered by Israel's Prime Minister, Shimon Peres. It was offered by Mr Peres to the parliamentary assembly of the Council of Europe in Strasbourg on 22 April last. It was my privilege to be present in the Hemicycle of the Council of Europe on that day to hear his speech, which essentially was an appeal for a co-operative approach on two levels-on the level of prevention and on the level of economic aid. I would like to quote some of that speech. It was, in all, an excellent speech. I would love to quote the lot of it, but I shall quote some of the more significant passages. Mr Peres said:

History has known bursts of religious and political extremism manifested in open warfare as well as terrorism. Their duration was determined largely by the apathy of onlookers. Combating international terrorism should be immediate, comprehensive, constant, and consistent in its application. It must be co-operatively executed. Terrorism is uncompromising in its actions, thus confronting it must be of an uncompromising nature. A firm commitment to such a policy by the free world-the main theatre for their action-and surely by the European countries, can tame the patrons of terrorism and contain the problem.

Coupled with all those difficulties, the Middle East is now faced with the added dramatic threat of economic deterioration. Falling oil prices caused the loss of billions of dollars to the countries in the Middle East. In addition to that direct loss, others, whose economic stability depends on the prosperity of the oil producers, are affected by the consequences. Revenues in remittances by nationals working in the oil countries are falling; direct assistance has been sharply reduced; import capacities have been significantly lowered; and, recently, tourism has declined as a result of terrorism. All these serve to aggravate economic hardships.

The overriding immediate challenge in the Middle East is therefore the alleviation of this looming economic crisis. Its tremors can already be felt under the surface. What should be done under those dire circumstances? Lost income to oil producers is a net gain to consumers. Hence, the industrialised countries are expected to save an estimated $70 billion this year alone. If even a small proportion of this expected saving were channelled to an economic rehabilitation program for the region, it could make a substantial contribution to peace and stability in the Middle East. The countries affected are faced with a high birth rate and have limited natural resources. They face a difficult choice: to submit to uncontrolled bitter forces or to mobilise external support to meet their urgent needs.

There is no hope for a stable peace in the Middle East without a stable economy in the most important countries there. Moreover, involvement in economic development may grow into support for a positive political process. This distinguished Assembly-
he was referring to the Council of Europe--
can assume a leadership position in the launching of an imaginative 10-year economic program, thus promoting stability and peace in the region.

The Peres plan has already attracted support from a number of people-from Helmut Kohl of West Germany, from Bettino Craxi of Italy, and from Prime Minister Nakasone of Japan. Responses from other major industrialised nations have also been encouraging. They might well lead to a political and economic breakthrough. I close by expressing the hope that these constructive developments continue and that we can move towards a more ordered and peaceful world community.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dobie The Hon J.D.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to express my grievance for my constituents who reside in the suburb of Kurnell and who have been getting a very raw deal indeed from the various authorities which have, or which are thought to have, the power to affect their environment, their lifestyles and, literally, their actual lives over many years. These threats are on again. I refer to the growing industrialisation of the region, which has been enthusiastically stimulated over the past three decades by a series of Labor policy decisions based on careless indifference and a total lack of concern for the citizens who live in the birthplace of the nation.

SPEECH.PARA: The rot started when the Cahill Labor Government decided to establish oil refineries nearly 30 years ago. This was compounded in 1962 when Labor Minister Pat Hills advocated the establishment of Sydney's second major airport at Towra Point, a proposal which received the total support of Labor councillor, now Senator, A. T. Gietzelt at that time. It should be recorded that having been a staunch supporter of Towra Point as a major jet airport, Shire President Gietzelt then reversed his attitude and there were some very quaint about-faces after I had won the seat of Hughes from the Australian Labor Party in 1966. I was proud to have played a significant part in stopping the likelihood of any such development at Towra Point by any Federal Liberal-National Party government. Time restraints in this debate stop me from developing this point, which I shall talk on at another time.

The current threat I refer to is the lodging of development applications by three major companies for industrial sites at Kurnell. The chemical giant Bayer is seeking approval to build a formulation plant for crop protection and veterinary products, a $12m investment. AGL wants to produce and store gas. Materials Technology Limited wants to produce a lightweight concrete product, and there is considerable speculation that at least two other companies are interested in sites at Kurnell. One of these is said to be W. R. Grace, which is believed to have purchased land for future development. All of these applications must contain an element of risk for the Kurnell and Cronulla residents.

The zoning of Kurnell has been a running sore for decades and the source of great dispute between the Sutherland Shire Council and the corresponding departments of various State governments. In all this time the residents of Kurnell have been treated like the proverbial mushrooms-kept in the dark and fed on manure. The present dispute revolves around land which is zoned 4 (C) 4, industrial special, and was originally proposed by the New South Wales Department of Environment and Planning as an exclusive petro-chemical zone. Following submissions from Sutherland Shire Council and other interested parties, it was zoned to accommodate a more general spectrum of industries. To my understanding, the Department has won out because the zone still permits petro-chemical industries, and herein lies the problem.

Section 101 of the Environmental Planning and Assessment Act 1979 declares that any authorisation for development must come from the State Minister. The local government authority, in this case the Sutherland Shire Council, cannot approve or reject a development application for the site, but it can express an opinion to the Minister on any development application. Of the three development applications and associated environmental impact studies so far received by Sutherland Shire Council, one has progressed to the stage where the Minister must make a decision. Council refrained from supporting this application, citing a number of unresolved issues relating to transport and safety. The MTL application is currently being considered by Council, and the third application by Bayer has been submitted with an EIS. Council submitted this EIS to the University of New South Wales for an independent evaluation, and I have reason to believe that this evaluation may not be favourable to Bayer, citing unresolved issues and, in particular, that Bayer had not, or could not, justify the proposed relocation from its present site at Botany to Kurnell.

I believe that the New South Wales Minister for Planning and Environment, Mr Carr, deserves the strongest condemnation for his handling of this entire issue. He has been evasive and non-committal. Everything he has said and done simply lends credence to the public perception that he will approve these applications no matter what advice he receives from the Sutherland Shire Council. On top of all this, on 4 February this year, he used his powers to strip the Sutherland Shire Council of its planning powers. He said that his decision was `primarily to underline the Government's concern with the protection of urban bushland as well as at other council activities dredging creeks and estuaries'. While most of these planning powers were subsequently restored to Council, it is interesting to note that an article in the St George and Sutherland Shire Leader of 11 February said:

Late last year (1985) several hectares of bushland in Sir Joseph Banks Drive (at Kurnell) owned by the Industries were bulldozed with the permission of the Minister for Planning and Environment, Mr Carr.
I am not aware of any ministerial denial. Come, Mr Carr; as an old bushwalker, who needed to control whom on this occasion?

While the Minister has publicly said Kurnell will not become a dumping ground for noxious industries, his Department has released the revised draft of the Sydney regional environment plan which says, in part, that it `shall permit potential hazardous facilities to be established only on land at Kurnell and Botany'. So we have the Australian Labor Party Minister saying that it is a nonsense to suggest Kurnell will become an industrial dumping ground, while, at the same time, his Department is saying that Kurnell is one of only two areas in southern Sydney suitable for hazardous industries. Come on, Mr Carr, you must be able to work this one out, too.

I would like to congratulate the people who have led the fight to ward off these industries. They are the Kurnell Action Group, who have maintained a peaceful, strong and effective campaign. If Mr Carr thought he was taking on a bunch of ill-organised locals, he now knows otherwise. Residents of Kurnell fear, with justification, that in the event of a major chemical explosion or fire, they would be cut off and emergency services would not have adequate access to reach them. Quite seriously, they could be faced with a Dunkirk-style operation to get them off the peninsula and away from the noxious gases. This is an absolutely ludicrous situation in metropolitan Sydney.

Mr Frank Bryce, Secretary of the New South Wales Firemen's Union, has been reported as saying that, in the event of a fire or accident, residents would be at risk because of the inadequate access road and the fact that Kurnell is not part of the New South Wales Fire Brigade's operational area. The community, I might add, is served by a dedicated volunteer bushfire brigade whom I congratulate on all their dangerous and selfless work on behalf of not only the Kurnell people but local industry as well.

Mr Carr's Department is said to be conducting a total risk assessment study for the Kurnell area, but this will not be completed until June at the very earliest. I would be interested to know whether this is correct, and, if so, why it is that the public inquiry in the AGL development application has been held before this risk assessment is completed.

The Kurnell Action Group also opposes development of noxious industries in the area on the grounds of ecological damage. The peninsula is unsuitable for this type of development because of its quick water run-off and closeness to nature reserves and oyster farms. The nearby environs host oyster leases which are labour-intensive and represent a significant financial investment. The Towra Point region is now a designated nature reserve, and the Australian and Japanese governments have signed a treaty to preserve this habitat of rare bird life, most notably the Japanese snipe. Surely any noxious development nearby must pose a threat to this finely balanced ecological system.

The State Labor Government has just announced that it proposes an aquatic reserve around Towra Point and into Botany Bay. How on earth can it marry this idea with the development of noxious industries? The main complaints being aired at the moment relate to the Bayer proposal. Bayer claims its atmospheric emissions will be extremely low and conform with clean air regulations. It does admit, however, that some dust containing toxic material will be emitted, albeit only a very small amount. Bayer also says it will not permit contaminated water to discharge to Quibray Bay or any part of Botany Bay. It says that all waste water will be collected and treated and `first flush' rainwater will be similarly processed if necessary. Bayer has included its own risk assessment study in its EIS. Safety studies have been carried out to evaluate the risk to residents from an explosion, fire and exposure to toxic dust. It is interesting to note that a Bayer officer briefed the Botany Bay Sub-Region Community Advisory Committee last November, and under questioning from Committee members, the officer is reported as having conceded, and the Committee remains concerned, that Bayer could not give any definite guarantees with regard to safety. The officer is also reported to have said that Bayer had not considered the cumulative effect of other new industries nearby. For my part, I consider any risk to be too great for the residents of Kurnell.

The Kurnell Action Group maintain that there has been a long list of complaints against the Bayer plant at Botany-a charge that the company absolutely denies. In short, the two parties beg to differ on very many points.

Let me conclude by saying that along with the 1982 report of the Commission of inquiry into the planning of the Kurnell Peninsula, I agree that because of the vast potential of the peninsula for recreation and for tourist uses, the industrial zone must be visually and operationally compatible with those uses. Permissible uses should not be air-polluting or noxious. As we approach our Bicentennial, it would be a crime to bury our birthplace with noxious gases and the like.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baldwin Mr P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to take up a theme that has already been introduced in this grievance debate by my colleague the honourable member for Lindsay (Mr Free), and that is the question of international terrorism. But I intend to deal with a number of other aspects and from a slightly different perspective. I was motivated to speak on this subject by the appearance in today's Sydney Morning Herald of an article dealing with the recent South African raids into Zimbabwe, Botswana and Zambia, in relation to which the Prime Minister of South Africa, P. W. Botha, invokes the precedents of United States action in Libya and Israeli action in the bombing of Tunis by way of justification of these raids. It served to underline a number of long-standing concerns that I have had about the way terrorism is treated in our country and, for that matter, in most other Western countries.

SPEECH.PARA: It goes without saying that international terrorism is a very major concern of all reasonable people. Nobody wants to be shot or blown up at an airport, and these things represent an undoubted problem and one that has to be addressed. However, I think that if we are to address this problem, it should be dealt with in an even-handed manner and that we should opt for a definition of terrorist actions that corresponds with some sort of reasonable assessment of what the term might mean, and that we are equal in condemning terrorist acts from wherever they emanate. That needs to be the first point. I say that because we in the West tend to associate terrorist actions with swarthy, dubious characters of Middle East origin and do not believe for a minute that terrorist actions could emanate from nice, decent Judaeo-Christian democracies of the West. I think that that is a misconception that needs to be dealt with.

I have a number of very serious concerns about the accepted mode of response to terrorist actions. It seems to me-and I will elaborate on this-that we are getting a view that the important thing where terrorism is concerned is that terrorist acts be seen to be responded to in some form, and that retribution is seen to have been delivered. It does not seem to matter that much whether the action concerned is totally out of proportion with the initial terrorist act; it does not seem to matter all that much whether the retaliation is actually effective in bringing about a reduction in the incidence of terrorism. I fear deeply the consequences of the sort of response that we have seen in the United States action against Libya.

I will now go on to elaborate on some of these points. I begin by seeking a reasonable definition of the term `terrorism'. For the reason I outlined earlier, I think that is very important. The Parliamentary Library, in a recent Current Issues brief, defines `terrorism' as follows:

Political terrorism is the use, or threat of use, of violence by an individual or a group, whether acting for or in opposition to established authority, when such action is designed to create extreme anxiety and/or fear-inducing effects in a target group larger than the immediate victims with the purpose of coercing that group into acceding to the political demands of the perpetrators.

That is a definition that is apparently accepted by the leading authority on terrorism in this country. It seems to me a perfectly reasonable definition which, if accepted, brings a whole range of actions not normally considered as terrorism-not in our Western Press, anyway-within the ambit of a discussion. It would include, for example, the actions of death squads in Latin America, often aided and abetted by regimes that actively receive military and other material support from the present United States Administration that professes concern about terrorism. It would certainly embrace the actions of the Nicaraguan Contras, who, according to the former leaders who have given evidence before United States select committees, have engaged in such actions as assassination of Sandinista officials, kidnapping and torturing and killing of Sandinista civilian officials, violent attacks on economic infrastructure in Nicaragua, and, of course, mining of a Nicaraguan port-many of these actions carried out in accordance with directives set out in a manual prepared in the first instance by the United States Central Intelligence Agency. So if one starts to adopt a proper definition of the term, a few additional categories of actions have to be taken into consideration. It is my contention that the protestations of concern about terrorism by the present United States Administration certainly leave something to be desired in terms of moral consistency with its own actions.

To return to the case of South Africa, where the South African incursions are justified in terms of terrorist actions which are supposed to have been committed by the African National Congress, what about the bloody repression perpetrated by the South African authorities-the shooting of unarmed demonstrators, the killing of prisoners in captivity, and so on? These matters, of course, also ought properly to be considered in any discussion of terrorism.

One could take an example rather closer to home-the Rainbow Warrior bombing in New Zealand. There we had the blowing up of a ship and the killing of one person by the agents of a state. In this case it happened to be a friendly Western democracy, so we do not take the action quite as seriously as we would regard the same action had it been committed by a Libyan. The United States State Department, when questioned about its attitude to that action, was distinctly tardy and muted in its response. Again, it just serves to outline my point, that if we are going to be concerned about terrorism, as I believe we should be, we ought to be concerned about all acts of terrorism, properly defined, whether carried out by groups, individuals or the armed forces of a state. I emphasise the latter because in the Middle East situation the Palestinian rocket attacks on northern Israel are unambiguously categorised as terrorist, yet, on the other hand, the flattening of half of the city of Beirut, with thousands of casualties from phosphorus bombs and fragmentation bombs, of course, is not considered to be terrorist at all, because in this case it happens to be perpetrated by the armed forces of a state, rather than a group of individuals acting on behalf of a dispossessed group.

That is the first broad range of points I make. I now discuss briefly the specific matter of the Libyan incursion. I think it should be fairly clear to anybody following the way this matter unfolded that the primary consideration of the United States Administration is not with reducing the incidence of international terrorism but, rather, with serving and playing to a domestic political gallery. There is not the slightest doubt about that. When one considers the retaliation that has been carried out, it is interesting that there is really nothing by way of a substantive argument put forward to the effect that that bombing will reduce the future incidence of terrorism. What we seem to have seen is already an orchestrated build-up of events. I stress that I am not an apologist for the Libyan regime. It is a dreadful regime and I am sure that Gaddafi has been responsible for supporting violent actions against Libyan dissidents overseas and others.

However, looking at the circumstances surrounding this case, firstly, the raid is justified in terms of Article 51 of the United Nations Charter, which provides for the right of self-defence in the case of an armed attack. The question of the legality of that has been dealt with quite extensively in an article quoting Chalice Professor of International Law at Sydney University, Professor James Crawford, who makes the point that in order for that to provide a legitimate justification under international law there would have to exist conclusive proof. In this case, we have not seen the evidence that is alleged to exist, but the fact of the matter is that the United States has a track record of putting out distorted accounts of this sort of thing.

Furthermore, I refer to an article in the Australian of 22 April this year in relation to the bomb attack on a West Berlin club and the United States raid on Libya. It spoke of the West German counter-espionage agency BND having a distinctly different interpretation of the telecommunications intercepts. So, I believe it is dubious under international law--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Slipper Mr P.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to speak in this grievance debate today, and, following the uncharacteristically frank admissions last week of the Treasurer (Mr Keating), I suppose that the main grievance of an increasingly large number of Australians is that the Hawke Labor Government still clings to office after three years of leading us down the slippery path of economic ruin. We were once considered to be the lucky country, but undoubtedly we now are in deep trouble. The situation calls for statesmanship by all people. It calls for an approach to try to solve the very real problems confronting this country. I often wonder, from talking to you from time to time, Mr Deputy Speaker, just where this country is going to be in the next 10 or 15 years. What sort of inheritance are we going to give the children of this nation? I know that you yourself often consider this matter and are deeply concerned by it. We should look at the situation of Australia and look at the situation of Argentina. I believe that it is strongly arguable that we are indeed heading down the same road as that unfortunate South American country.

SPEECH.PARA: Over the past 15 years this nation has not had very much long term planning at all. We have had elections every 18 to 20 months in some cases, and government policy seems to lurch from election to election. Decisions are made, it seems, on the run; they are ad hoc decisions and not decisions taken for the long term benefit of Australia. It seems that there have been far too many easy options accepted by governments on both sides of politics. Unfortunately, I was one of those 19 Opposition and Government members who were ruthlessly chopped from the debate yesterday on the Supply Bills, and I think that the Government should be condemned for the way that it constantly rams legislation through this House and prevents back-bench members from having the opportunity to properly debate it.

We are fortunate that yesterday the shadow Treasurer, the honourable member for Mackellar (Mr Carlton), mentioned that the Government must face up to seven very serious questions, and I am certain that the people listening would be interested to have these seven very important questions repeated. These are the questions that we asked the Government, and the people of Australia will no doubt join us in demanding firm, forthright and honest answers to them. When will the Government do something about the balance of payments problem? What will it do about our massive overseas public debt, which is currently $70 billion and well on the way to $100 billion? How can it reduce the level of inflation from over 9 per cent to the average of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development of 2.9 per cent or less? How can the Government prevent our high inflation rates flowing on to wages and thereby further eroding our international competitiveness? When will it be able to reduce unemployment below the current level of about 8 per cent, and when will it be able to reduce youth employment below its current level of 22 per cent? My own electorate suffers from an extremely high unemployment figure as a result of Labor's economic policies. What hope does the Government hold out for taxpayers, 50 per cent of whom will be paying a top marginal rate of 40c in the dollar or higher by 1987-88 when the full effects of last year's tax package are in place? The seventh question is: What will the Government do about business investment?

These matters, which were raised by the honourable member for Mackellar, are pertinent. They are matters which the Government should consider, and the Treasurer should stop giving his flippant, one-line answers and should sit down and appreciate that Australia is in deep trouble. The Treasurer, last week-I mentioned before that he was uncharacteristically frank-made some very illuminating statements. He said: `We must let Australians know truthfully, honestly, earnestly, just what sort of an international hole Australia is in'. What an admission! He said bluntly that the terms of trade which Australia was now experiencing were the worst since the Great Depression. The terms of trade covers the prices we receive for exports and the cost of imports. He warned that if the Government could not deal with the balance of payments problem successfully, then Australia is basically done for; we will just end up being a third-rate economy. Later he referred to the possibility of our becoming a banana republic. A columnist for the Australian, a very well regarded newspaper in this country said:

Let us send the world a signal that we mean business. We must cut public expenditure mercilessly and show that we can take the consequent pain. We must have a wage freeze and put off for at least a year the productivity superannuation deal. We must summon the courage to do one thing that will really show we are serious about our future and pull our union movement into line. If we are fair dinkum, we will never again hold up an export shipment or ruin an overseas tourist's holiday.

We in the Opposition are 100 per cent opposed to the Government's under-the-table deal with the union movement as far as the productivity superannuation situation is concerned. Australia cannot afford that. We would like to see that scrapped completely. But we must take note of what the Australian is saying. We must consider that the resources of this nation are finite. One of the major problems confronting Australia is ballooning government expenditure on social security. I seek leave of the House, Mr Deputy Speaker, to incorporate in Hansard a table setting out expenditure under the Social Security Act.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the House. The situation is that with respect to unemployment benefits we are now outlaying in the year 1985 almost $3,000m; $2,983.6m to be precise. This has created in many Australians' minds a hand-out mentality. We must consider the unemployment benefit and what we must do to try to improve the situation. No enlightened person would today suggest that we should not have the dole to assist those people who are genuinely out of work. The situation has now arisen, however, where I believe it is right and proper for people to work for the dole, rather than receive it for nothing. Those opposite will no doubt construe what I say as an attack on the unemployed and those genuinely in need of government help, but nothing could be further from the truth. What I am advocating is that fit and healthy persons who are able to work should receive their unemployment benefit through working for it, rather than receiving it for nothing as at the moment. Over the past few months I have spoken to various groups throughout my electorate of Fisher and I have yet to find anybody who does not believe in work value for the dole.

SPEECH.PARA: I wish to stress that only that those people who are fit and healthy would be required to provide work value. Recipients who, for medical reasons, are not able to work, would not be required to do so. There could be certain other exceptions, such as those undergoing training through the community youth support scheme or other programs. I am constantly amazed to see how Australian Labor Party members infer that there is some sort of bottomless pit of money or an inexhaustible supply of funds to meet every real or imagined need in the social welfare field.

Nothing, of course, can be as soul destroying as not to have a job and not to be able to find one. Many people who are on unemployment benefits without work for a considerable period lose their self-esteem, self-regard and self-respect. By working for the dole people would feel that they were contributing something to the community in exchange for the community's help to them in time of need. The policy of work value for the dole would ensure a return to the nation on its welfare payout. No one knows for certain what proportion of people on the dole are members of that group which has previously been called dole bludgers, but under this Government's disastrous policies more and more people have been forced on to Labor's dole queues. If work value were implemented as an essential prerequisite to obtaining the dole, it is likely that only those who were genuinely unemployed would then be on the dole.

Australia must look at the direction in which it is heading. We are in deep trouble. The Treasurer has admitted it. We have known it. The people of Australia understand that firm steps must be taken. They must be taken now. There must be a complete about-face in the Government's approach.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hollis Mr C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Overseas coverage by Australian media over the past few days has, not surprisingly I suppose, been concerned with South Africa's illegal and totally unjustified attack on three neighbouring states. But the past few days have seen a further stepping up of the genocide being committed by the Shengeleu Government of President Jayawardene in Sri Lanka against the Tamil minority, as the Government of Sri Lanka attempts a military solution to a communal problem in Sri Lanka. Like many Australians I am distressed and disturbed that Sri Lankan armed forces have commenced large scale military operations in the Jaffna Peninsula, including indiscriminate aerial bombing and strafing of Jaffna City itself, resulting in a large number of civilians being killed and hundreds wounded. Two wards of the Jaffna hospital were hit and I expect casualties there to be very high. As late as last night the coastal town of Valvettithurai was subject to naval and aerial bombardment. Again, I expect casualties will be high. I am awaiting further details on that. Such continued military operations will inevitably lead to a loss of still larger numbers of innocent civilian lives and only prolong the agony suffering of the people of Sri Lanka.

SPEECH.PARA: How can this massive use of force by the Government of Sri Lanka be justified, especially at a time when Sri Lankan leaders have repeatedly professed their commitment to seeking a peaceful, political solution to the ethnic issue? It is particularly deplorable that such operations should have been undertaken at a time when the governments of India and Sri Lanka were engaged in discussions to find a peaceful, political solution to the problem. Such operations frustrate the process of negotiations. The sequence of events leading up to this abortive offensive must be critically examined.

Firstly, the peace talks with the Indian delegation and the new proposals without substance had an ominous similarity to the ill-fated Timpu talks in Bhutan, when hundreds of Tamils were murdered by the forces. Secondly, the bombing of the Air Lanka jet, which resulted in the tragic loss of lives of innocent tourists, took place during the Tokyo summit on terrorism and the accusation was made-even before the dust settled-that the Tamil militants were responsible. Their vehement denial of any involvement in this cowardly attack of pure terrorism was ignored. The Sri Lanka Government put out transparently false evidence to incriminate them. Now, it is reported that Government employees were involved in the bombing, but most observers have not ruled out the Government's involvement in the attack. The insurers of the aircraft will doubtless investigate the disaster fully before paying out $US25m for an aircraft purchased in 1982 for $14m. Thirdly, the bombing of the central telegraph office in Colombo was likewise linked with the Tamil militants, although the Government now acknowledges that it sees the hand of an outlawed Sinhalese movement which staged a mass insurrection in 1971 behind the attack.

As can be seen, the Sinhalese Government has been setting the scene for this attack, especially with the recent bombing at Colombo airport. I was concerned on Tuesday of this week when the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley) who represents the Acting Minister for Foreign Affairs, Senator Button, in reply to a question in this chamber, repeated a claim made by the Sri Lankan Government that these outrages were committed by the Tamils. The same claim is made in Australia's media this week. As I have said, there is absolutely no evidence of Tamil involvement in this outrage. I have a strong suspicion that these outrages can be seen as part of the scene setting by the present Government of Sri Lanka. We have seen reports about military action recently that was claimed as a response to terrorism, and I suggest that by saying that it was attacking terrorism the Sri Lankan Government was hoping to get international support for its action.

It really follows a pattern of hints over the past months from the President that a military solution would be sought. He is attempting to gain world sympathy for his disastrous policies by blaming these bombing outrages on the Tamils and thus justifying this latest exercise by the Sri Lankan Government. The statements by the President have been more and more extreme and emotive. While threatening military solutions, he talks about the Tamils' attempts to install communist dictatorship-again in an attempt to gain international sympathy, especially, I suspect, United States sympathy.

The President and his Government have refused to listen to wise counsel, especially from India, which has been attempting to mediate between the Government and the Tamils and find some lasting solution. But the present Government appears not to want a solution and especially not a peaceful solution. Attacks on Tamils have been a daily occurrence for many years but these have intensified since the July-August 1983 genocidal attacks. There is daily harassment by the Sinhalese security forces and thugs-rape, murder, arson and killings are a daily occurrence. Over 10,000 innocent Tamils have been killed by the armed forces-forces that were often out of control. Over 200,000 refugees have fled the country. Tamils are now living in countries throughout the world. We must never lose sight of what President Jayawardene meant when he declared that there will only be a military solution to the problems of Sri Lanka. What he means is a complete annihilation of the Tamil people on the island of Sri Lanka.

The facts are well documented by such bodies as Amnesty International, Law Asia, the International Commission of Jurists, and many others. What, I asked in this chamber, can we do? I suggest that time is long past when pious statements can be accepted as enough; and we cannot just wring our hands about it. I appeal to the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Hayden) to raise the genocide of the Tamils at the United Nations Security Council. We should be asking the United Nations to send an international fact finding mission to Sri Lanka to establish the facts. The Australian Government must be putting pressure on Sri Lanka to stop the genocide. We must support the valiant efforts of India to bring a lasting peace to this troubled land.

I remind members of this House that as we sit here in Australia now, the Sri Lankan regime is conducting an intensive bombing campaign on the Jaffna Peninsula, reminiscent of that United States bombing campaign against Vietnam. We cannot leave India alone to do the negotiations for a peaceful solution. We must express our solidarity with the Indian efforts, express our concern and disgust to the Jayawardence Government, and raise the matter in the United Nations. At this stage it should be of concern to Australians that the only thanks India has received for a valiant attempt at negotiations are unwarranted and baseless statements of the Sri Lankan leadership appearing in the Press critical of the Prime Minister of India.

It is my view, and also the view of most informed observers, that there can be no military solution to the ethnic issue in Sri Lanka. The current military operations undertaken by the Sri Lankan armed forces will only lead to further worsening of the situation and add to the suffering of the people of Sri Lanka. It is my earnest hope that, rather than take recourse to the use of force and bloodshed against a significant section of its own people, the Government of Sri Lanka would do well to seek a resolution of the ethnic issue through a process of dialogue and meaningful pragmatic measures to meet the situation and resolve the problem.

Since my last speech on the Tamil issue, I have been approached by the Sri Lankan High Commissioner, I have received a number of abusive telephone calls-which I always get; I will probably get more this afternoon-and now a telegram campaign is being directed against me. Many of the letters and telegrams come anonymously. They are claiming that I am supporting Marxist terrorists. People who know me here in this chamber will appreciate that this is absolute rubbish. What I am opposed to are the disastrous actions of the present Sri Lankan Government. I am opposed to the impact that they will have on the Tamil minority. What I am working for, as are many other members in this chamber, is a peaceful solution-not a military solution but a political solution to this problem, so that the island of Sri Lanka can return to its normal happy state and so that-as is everyone's right-the Tamils there can live in dignity and peace in their homeland. I will continue to pursue that cause in this Parliament and I will continue to speak out for the Tamil cause.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Halverson Mr R.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —John L. O'Sullivan, the noted nineteenth century American writer and editor, once observed that `The best government is that which governs least'. I believe his observation was, and still is, demonstrably correct. I also believe that my agreement with his views is shared by the vast majority of those who are governed. Unfortunately, it appears to be largely ignored by the vast majority of those who currently have the responsibility of providing government. It is, therefore, perhaps understandable why many of those who find themselves in the latter `governors' division are held in such questionable esteem by those who, for better or for worse-and at the moment it is mainly for the worse-come within the `governees' category.

SPEECH.PARA: It is very obvious that sometimes members of parliament forget that they have been elected to serve, although I suppose it could be argued, if one favours the use of colloquialisms, that the Hawke Government is certainly giving the people of Australia a serve at the moment. We are becoming increasingly overwhelmed by, and subjected to, a plethora of unnecessary and unjustifiable government legislation, regulation and intervention. We are being force-fed an overdose of J-curves, trilogies, accords, summits, and concepts of so-called consensus, which really means capitulation to powerful pressure groups which are far from representative of the Australian community in general. This socialist inspired, government promoted prescription is for a brand of medicine we do not want, do not need, and which is not providing any identifiable, positive, curative effect on the ills which are currently causing a rapid and potentially terminal degeneration on the economic, social and moral health of this great nation.

Many of the problems now threatening the welfare and well-being of Australia and Australians are the direct and inexcusable result of over-government. Challenges which were once regarded as legitimate and necessary testing procedures, which could be easily overcome with a little determination and initiative, are fast developing into insurmountable obstacles around or over which there appears to be no possible way. Instead of concentrating on ensuring easier, better and less restricted opportunities for people to develop themselves and enhance their contribution for the common good of the community-either individually or collectively-this Federal Labor Government and its State and even local government counterparts are devoting their energies to implementing more complicated, less efficient and totally ineffective methods of dampening the inherent Australian characteristic of `having a go'. In other words, increasing interference by all levels of government in matters which are and should be of no real concern to them, because they have no positive contribution to make, are stifling the inventiveness, creativity, intelligence and adventurous spirit of a naturally enterprising people.

Australians need and deserve to be encouraged to develop their potential and the potential of their nation. They cannot do so if they are continually hampered by the intervention of governments who appear to believe their own existence can be justified only by the imposition of restrictive and unnecessary legislative measures which serve only to limit and complicate the pursuit of the objectives and ideals of others. Ask anyone involved in small business what is the greatest stumbling block to his success. Almost without exception, his response will be: Government red tape, over-regulation, and the enforcement of pettifogging bureaucratic requirements which are of no practical benefit in assisting or enhancing their business prospects, profits or the development of greater employment opportunities.

It is a fact that this country relies heavily on small business for its current and future economic growth and stability, but our increasingly desperate Treasurer (Mr Keating), in calling together his advisers for yet another summit meeting, has chosen to deliberately ignore not only the importance of small business but also the rural sector. Both are major and vital contributors to our economy. Both are currently suffering major problems and setbacks, mostly the result of actions of this Government, which will have enormous and potentially disastrous ramifications for all Australians if left unsolved. But the Treasurer neglects to act on the facts and continues to punt on the improbabilities. There is little point in consulting with only some of the people some of the time. If one persists in adopting this method, one invariably ends up with only some of the answers to some of the problems.

Another aspect of the dangers inherent in the current approach of these harbingers of socialist theory is that they are actively encouraging people to depend not on themselves and their own initiative but on the benevolence of government. Unfortunately, the Government-being, as it is, a non-productive entity-can only continue to be benevolent so long as it can obtain sufficient funds from outside sources. These outside sources are, in the main, the long-suffering Australian taxpayers. On the one hand, we have a government which implements and promotes measures designed to effectively limit the growth and profitability of the private sector-and therefore effectively limit the creation of additional tax revenue through reasonable means-whilst at the same time it undertakes massive spending sprees on all sorts of ineffective measures which have no relevance or bearing on the real needs of the community as a whole. The Treasurer now looks at the results of his handiwork and informs us that we are rapidly approaching banana republic status. He tells us that some belt tightening is needed. At the same time, we read of millions of dollars being frittered away on useless schemes which are meant to be solving the problems of the nation but are in reality only helping to create them.

Australians have a right to expect more from their Government than this litany of disaster, which is the record of the Hawke-Keating-Crean administration. The people have a right to expect decency, honesty, compassion, morality, understanding, encouragement and a fair deal for all. They should not have to tolerate a system which rewards hard work, initiative and enthusiasm with diminishing rewards, whilst at the same time giving increased protection and encouragement to the non-contributors in our community. They have a right to expect a government which takes credit for its own achievements, rather than depending for publicity on the rather shallow boast that it is the receiver of goods obtained through treacherous and immoral means.

I do not believe that the Australian farming community will derive much pleasure from seeing a smiling Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) whose delight is caused not by any upturn in the rural sector but because he has managed to obtain a copy of an Opposition policy document. If the Government thinks it will obtain mileage with the Press or the electorate as it continues on its merry way of leaking already-leaked documents, then it will find that the vast majority of people are not very impressed with its involvement in such below-the-belt and undesirable activities. I have no doubts whatsoever that in the final analysis, the contents of the leaked coalition policies will reflect very creditably on the Opposition plans for getting Australia back on the right track. But it will never reflect creditably on the Hawke Government that it was forced to stoop to such sneaky and malicious depths in its efforts to get its own appalling performance off the front pages of the newspapers. All that it has achieved, and could hope to achieve, will be to highlight to the public that there are always people who can be bought, and there are always people prepared to buy them.

It is time this Government got back to the business of governing-not through the implementation of further restrictive legislative measures; not through the introduction of more taxes or other imposts on certain-often very vulnerable-sections of the community; not through threats or promises that cannot and will not be kept; but through the re-establishment of some much needed dignity and decency in the manner in which it carries out its duties and responsibilities. Yesterday in this House the Treasurer suggested that the Opposition had sunk to incredibly low depths. I would like to suggest that if we have, then we are most assuredly sharing the available space with the Government. The difference is, as it is sinking even deeper, we are looking to the stars.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Maher Mr M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thought today that in the few minutes remaining before the grievance debate terminates, I would talk about poverty, as we find it as members of Parliament, because we all have to interview constituents who are out of work. I was a member of this House in 1982 and I remember the collapse of the economy after the 1982 Budget, when a million Australians were put out of work, and how sad it is to meet people who want a job, people who have a family or those who might be single, men or women, who want to work and have no opportunity to find employment. I say that today because the greatest boast that this Government can make, and the hallmark of this Government in years to come, will be that it did create, not half a million jobs, which it had promised to create in the 1983 election policy, but 600,000 jobs. It is a great credit to the Ministry, to the parliamentary Leader, Mr Hawke, and to the entire Government, that these 600,000 jobs have been created, and they are substantially in the private sector. Only the private sector can employ Australians. We cannot put people who are out of work into the Public Service ad infinitum; we have to stimulate the private sector, and that is what the Government has done.

SPEECH.PARA: Being in Opposition here, I remember how reluctant the National-Liberal Party coalition was to launch any sort of job creation scheme. The only job creation, of course, was in the tax avoidance industry, which was a growth industry under the Liberals. Even with the Commonwealth Employment Service, which was the only token they had to help the unemployed, there were moves, under the razor gang, to cut back the activities of the CES. The present Government is to be congratulated because it has stimulated the labour market; we have got 600,000 Australians into jobs, and they are essentially not with the big employers, such as Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd, with 50,000 employees, but in the small firms. Three-quarters of the work force in our nation in the private sector are employed by small business. Job creation has been a major success, a major part in getting this turnaround in employment. In its first Budget in 1983-84, the Government contributed nearly $600m to job creation schemes. This has tapered off, so that in the 1985-86 Estimates we see $446m for job creation schemes.

The notion of the deserving poor, that we should not pay unemployment benefits and to people who are out of work, is something that I find appalling. I was sorry to hear the honourable member for Fisher (Mr Slipper) talking about the unemployed having to work for the dole. It is all very well for the honourable member for Fisher to say these things; they are heady notions, perhaps, to Liberal Party and National Party branches. But in my electorate the long term unemployed are essentially middle-aged males, men in their late fifties or sixties, who are non-English speaking and often on light duties-they have had an accident at work, they have been retrenched, they are put off. These people cannot work for their dole, they cannot do heavy work. They want to work. They come to see me, as they see us all. They would dearly love a job. This notion that we give the dole only to the deserving poor is so much nonsense and rubbish. It shows a lack of understanding as to who is out of work.

The other group out of work, in all of our electorates, is young girls-15, 16 and 17-year-olds. They want to work, but the CES cannot send them away fruit picking. Who is going to supervise them? It is just farcical nonsense for the honourable member for Fisher to talk about getting the unemployed to work for their dole. One has to have people to supervise. The Government is spending $446m on job creation schemes. I pay credit to local governments for getting involved in these schemes; but they say to me: `You must have people to supervise. You have to have people to train the unemployed. You have to have people to keep records.' It is a very expensive exercise to create jobs, and the Government is easing out of that as the economy picks up and as the private sector employs more and more people it sops up the unemployed.

To be poor is a sad state. Most of the poverty in our nation, as we all know as members who see the poor and meet them in our offices every day when we are there, comes from sickness or from unemployment. It is a terrible situation, in any country, for any family to be touched by poverty. When we came into government there were a million Australians out of work, a million families stricken with poverty-and we hear all this nonsense that the unemployed should work for the dole. That is an absolute insult. All honourable members here know who is unemployed in their areas. They see people in their offices who want a reference for a job, who want some direction, or just some encouragement, some reassurance that they might get work.

In this grievance debate it is important that we touch on this issue of poverty. The Government is in the process of reducing taxes, of helping the unemployed and of creating jobs, and I think it is to its credit and I think it will go down in history as the Government that got Australians working and Australians back into jobs.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 2 p.m., in accordance with standing order 106, as amended for this session, the debate is interrupted.

—Will the Treasurer give a firm guarantee to Australian taxpayers that tax cuts, as promised, will be delivered on 1 September? If not, why does the final draft of the Australian Labor Party's new 1986 platform, to be debated in Hobart in July, state that Labor is committed to income tax cuts in two stages from 1 September 1986 and 1 July 1987? As the Minister for Finance, Senator Walsh, the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and Minister Assisting the Treasurer and the Treasurer's own staff helped write the new platform which has just gone to the printer, has the Treasurer made any last minute attempt to have that commitment withdrawn?

—I might say that we throw these draft platforms around like confetti, so if the Leader of the Opposition thinks he has discovered anything there, to use an expression of a former Labor Treasurer, it is as though it might be something that could have been left on a tram. These are draft documents; they have to go to the conference, and, of course, they reflect the position which obtains. I made it clear yesterday that tax cuts will proceed this calendar year. There is no question of that. We will not be doing as the former Treasurer did-promise them at an election and snatch them back entirely the following May. I make it quite clear that we are unequivocal about that. While I have said that this matter was discussed at the Advisory Committee on Prices and Incomes meeting a week ago and will be discussed at the future meeting, the Government, at this stage, has made no decision to alter the timing.

DEBATE.TITLE: DISTINGUISHED VISITORS

TALK.START.PARA: —I inform the House that we have present in the gallery this afternoon the Hon. Eddison Zvobgo, Minister for Justice, Legal and Parliamentary Affairs in the Government of Zimbabwe and Mrs Zvobgo, a member of the Parliament of Zimbabwe. On behalf of the House I extend to them a very warm welcome.

—Is the Minister for Health aware of a number of Australian children with growth retardation recently proven to be due to pituitary growth hormone deficiency are not being given access to biosynthetic human growth hormone, even though it is readily available and despite their having been formally approved for treatment on medical grounds by the Human Hormone Sub-committee? Is it proposed to allocate funds so that new patients can be accepted without delay into the trial of biosynthetic human growth hormone? If so, when?

—As the House is aware, because of problems with the pituitary growth hormone, the program was ended in the middle of last year. We immediately sought to get into this country a biosynthetic substitute which we were able to get by the end of the year. All the children being treated under that original program were then treated under the current clinical trial of this biosynthetic human growth hormone. We have now decided that, in addition to those already on the program, all new approved candidates will be accepted for treatment during this clinical trial process. I can assure the honourable member for Fraser that we have now approved the inclusion in the current clinical trial of the biosynthetic human growth hormone of additional patients not previously approved for treatment who meet the criteria of the Human Pituitary Advisory Committee for growth hormone therapy. I understand that involves some 27 new patients who have been approved. Any further applications will be received, considered by that Committee and, if recommended, given access to the clinical trial.

DEBATE.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN LABOR PARTY'S 1986 DRAFT PLATFORM ON TRADE, EMPLOYMENT, INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS, THE ECONOMY AND TAXATION

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to table the Australian Labor Party's 1986 draft platform on trade, employment, industrial relations, the economy-including taxation-and also, for an additional piece of confetti, the minutes for the last meeting of the Australian Labor Party's national economic policy committee.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations. Does the Government propose, first of all, to give immunity to trade unions and their officials from common law actions concerning illegal industrial disputation; secondly, to force independent contractors to work under union awards; and, thirdly, to repeal all penal provisions directed at unions and union members as is set out and proposed in the Australian Labor Party's draft industrial relations platform-a copy of which has been so thoughtfully provided to the Opposition by a public-minded citizen within this House?

—These are all matters which will be addressed by the Government in the context of responding to the report of the Hancock Committee of Review into the Australian Industrial Relations Law and System. When we bring forward legislation in respect of that, the House will know the answer to those questions.

—Does the Minister for Housing and Construction endorse the views of the Executive Director of the Australian Bankers Association, Mr Alan Cullen, that a resurgence in the housing industry is under way and that housing interest rates should trend down?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: West The Hon S.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very pleased to hear the optimistic views expressed by the Executive Director of the Australian Bankers Association regarding current lending levels by savings banks and his optimistic predictions about the future levels of housing interest rates. Like Mr Cullen, one appreciates the linkages between the balance of payments, the exchange rate, monetary policies, and budget and tax policies and their impact on future interest rates. I will make just a couple of points in relation to what Mr Cullen said. In the current economic situation one feels that interest rates are, of course, more sensitive to monetary policy than anything else. Secondly, it is obviously important to people who want to borrow for new housing loans, whether it be from savings banks or permanent building societies, that Mr Cullen be proven correct. I think the indications are that there is a good chance that he will be proven correct with regard to interest rates. If honourable members look at the history of 90-day bank bills over the last few months they will see that in December they were at a level of 19.75 per cent and today they are at a level of 14.7 per cent. As for the trading bank prime rate, back in December it was running at 21 per cent and today at least a couple of banks have it at 17 1/2 per cent. I say for the benefit of the Opposition that I understand that at least one major trading bank actually reduced its prime rate after the news of last Tuesday week, which I think is a heartening decision.

ANSWER.PARA: Also with regard to Mr Cullen's comments on savings bank lending rates, I am also heartened by results since the housing package was introduced. Lending levels have gone up since I reported to the House several weeks ago. Savings banks are now lending at a rate in excess of $600m a month. The Commonwealth Savings Bank of Australia is currently lending about $150m a month, the State Savings Bank of Victoria about $125m a month, the National Australia Bank Ltd over $100m a month, Westpac Banking Corporation about $90m a month and the Australia and New Zealand Banking Group Ltd about $95m a month. If any member of the Opposition is thinking about drawing attention to the level of bank lending for the month of March, the figures which were released today by the Australian Bureau of Statistics, I suggest that he or she is way beyond the times and ought to look at the figures to which I have just referred.

TALK.START.PARA: —I make the point, if the honourable gentlemen on the dissipated, and disintegrating front bench opposite will listen for a moment, that there is one minor qualification about the future level of lending. Mr Cullen reportedly said that the banks would have no trouble reaching their target of $6,000m lending for 1986-87 providing that the demand was there. On this point I should say that the private savings banks in particular have a current repayment to income ratio of approximately 25 per cent. This makes the future level of low start lending extremely important because the availability of low start loans influences the level of demand. This Government is encouraging all lenders, particularly the savings banks, to educate the public about the benefits of low start loans. A low start loan can mean that even though interest rates are currently 15 1/2 per cent-

—Opposition members are not interested in hearing about the benefits for home borrowers which are emerging from our housing package. I make it clear to them that the Government will be pushing the benefits of low start loans in future. It is extremely important to take pressure off public housing and to make home ownership available to both low and middle income earners. So whilst I am very pleased to hear that the Australian Bankers Association is optimistic about the future level of lending activity and the future level of interest rates, I say to the House and to honourable members opposite that as we conclude our written agreements with the banks we will be seeking firm assurances about the future level of low start lending for the future of home loan borrowers.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Communications. What steps will the Government take to ensure that television licensees seeking immediate aggregation have made an independent judgment on commercial grounds regarding broadcasting and are not acting as stalking-horses for other interests?

—A certain subtlety in the question may have escaped me; but, insofar as I was able to follow it, I say to the honourable member that if he cares to read the ministerial statement he will find that an indicative plan will be published which will then go out to the industry. That indicative plan will have in it financial projections. If a licensee in an approved market, on the basis, I would have thought, of a normal commercial judgment, decides that he wants to aggregate within that approved market aggregation will take place. If the honourable member is suggesting that in some way the Government looks behind that decision, I am unable to indicate how one would do that. It will be a matter for the judgment of the licensee concerned. I would have thought that, having regard to the fact that licensees of commercial regional stations over a period of 10 years have shown a revenue growth of between 9 per cent and 13 per cent and an average growth of around 11 per cent, they are obviously, to say the least, reasonably astute in a business sense. I would not think they would be electing for aggregation other than on commercial grounds.
—Has the Special Minister of State received any requests for the assistance of the Australian Federal Police for investigation of the recent leaking of confidential documents?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Young The Hon M.J.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: SPECIAL MINISTER OF STATE; LEADER OF THE HOUSE

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for his question. Obviously the newspapers today express concern by some members of the Opposition that certain documents that had been circulating among them for discussion, known as policy draft documents, had been leaked.
