As of the time of coming to the House, I can inform honourable members, I had received no requests for the assistance of the Australian Federal Police but I must say that it would be quite a challenge to the Australian Federal Police and quite a mystifying experience to sort out exactly who is doing the leaking. Apart from the fact that some authors have described the coalition as `the good, the bad, and the uglies'-I think the honourable member for Melbourne described the uglies a couple of weeks ago in the House-it is basically a fight between the wets and the dries. Do the dries leak? That has to be the question. Or is it only the wets who can leak? Or is there a closet wet in the dries? That is another question that must be answered. I was told, when we saw the draft policy on communications and Treasury, that at a meeting of a mixture of dries and wets, when the question of selling off the Commonwealth Bank of Australia and Telecom Australia came up, even a couple of dries wet themselves. So it would be quite a challenge to the police in an intensive inquiry and investigation into the Liberal Party of Australia to find out exactly who was doing it.

ANSWER.PARA: One will notice that, corresponding with this avalanche of information which has come forward to the Australian public this week, the new opinion polls are out. Andrew has gone up 80 per cent. The honourable member for Denison has gone up 100 per cent-from one to two-which just shows that more than one person in Australia uses vaseline! Now comes the question: What would be the penalty for the person discovered as leaking these documents? There it is this morning, on the front page of the Sydney Morning Herald: The Liberal Party is going to bring back the cane. Everyone who gets caught leaking documents is to be flogged. What we are going to do at our Federal Conference in July this year is consider an amendment to the Commonwealth Electoral Act to drop the voting age to five years.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the attention of the Attorney-General been drawn to the recent comments of the Deputy Chairman of the Human Rights Commission, Mr Peter Bailey, that it was the Commission's view that severely handicapped new born babies should be given drug overdoses to save resources? I ask the Attorney-General: Does the Government believe that such a view is representative of the community? Does the Attorney-General wish to dissociate himself from the views of the Human Rights Commission? Finally, in light of such views, does the Government remain confident that the Human Rights Commission will enforce the proposed Bill of Rights in line with accepted community attitudes?

—I am not aware of the remarks allegedly made by Mr Bailey. If they were made, he made them in his own right and they do not represent the view of the Government, nor, I would think, the view of many people in Australia. Of course, the proposed Bill of Rights and the proposal for a reconstructed Human Rights Commission are still before the Senate. The Bill has been debated there for 36 hours-an Australian record for debate-and I hope the Senate will soon deal with that measure. We will then have an opportunity to re-form the Human Rights Commission, which will be a very worthwhile body, comprised of people who are well aware of Australia's responsibilities under the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights and mindful also of the rights of individuals. The honourable member asked me whether I had seen some remarks attributed to a particular person. I have not, but I think I can say that those remarks express that person's individual view but they in no way reflect the view of the Government.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Primary Industry. Given the economic difficulties in the rural sector, can the Minister comment on significant aspects of policy proposals being put forward by various organisations?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The National Farmers Federation has been putting forward its policy proposals, many of which reiterate the demands of its many State-based affiliate organisations. Some of the views being expressed by rural organisations reflect beliefs that are patently untrue-for example, that the Government is running a dirty float. These organisations have the view that if only we ran a clean float, interest rates would drop by 6 or 7 per cent and the farming sector's problems could be settled because the lower value of the currency would solve all the problems. The Government has been intent on showing-it was in our economic and rural policy statement-that there is no dirty float, and that the relationship between interest rates and the floating of the dollar is not the relationship that farmers ascribe to it. All members of this House have to take into account the words of the Treasurer on the terms of trade. Quite frankly, when we have a drop in the value of the dollar of the magnitude of 25 or 30 per cent while in the wool industry, for example, the price of wool has risen by between 1.8 and 4 per cent, that drop in the value of the dollar does nothing but add to inflationary forces, thereby destroying international competitiveness even further in the longer term.

ANSWER.PARA: The Liberal Party and the National Party have been coming up with various policy proposals over the last few months. The Leader of the Opposition had a five-point plan, and then there was a 14-point plan, an 18-point plan and a nine-point plan. Now, strangely, we have the Opposition's own policy document. The only significance of this is that under the leadership of the present Leader of the Opposition senior members of the Opposition Executive now leak. So deep is the disloyalty, so venal is the skul-duggery on the other side of the House--

TALK.START.PARA: —You are a receiver of stolen property.

—The honourable member is helping him, too. I heard him yesterday. He is trying to help the Leader of the Opposition. So venal is the skulduggery that the Opposition now stabs itself in the front. That is what is happening. The first thing I want to make absolutely clear is that the Opposition parties have absolutely no obligation to implement any policy when in government. That is in its platform, in its philosophy. This means that no platform or policy document produced by the Liberal or National parties is ever worth the paper it is written on. Nobody-no voter, no farmer-can ever seriously regard any policy document from the Opposition parties in this House as being anything more than the roughest guide to what they might do when in government. After all, Mr Fraser and the leaders of the two major parties opposite are past masters of doing exactly what they like in government, of breaking every promise, all in the name of expediency but never in the name of long term, sensible and rational policies. There is talk about the coalition splitting. There is always talk about that. It is not just a matter of the wets and the dries in the Liberal Party. We know that the Liberal and National parties fight like cat and dog in every State, except perhaps New South Wales.
—What about the Labor Party and its left wing?

—Let us talk about Queensland. The eccentric Premier of Queensland is worshipped by every National Party member in this House, even the young ones. I find that amazing. Yet he has one electoral ambition in Queensland-to wipe out the Liberal Party. That is the reality. They have all this festering inside-no wonder the Executive leaks.

ANSWER.PARA: As I have said, I welcome some aspects of the Opposition's policy, because the Opposition has never really taken agricultural policy seriously. I have not had a chance to examine the document closely, but I suspect that those clamouring for lower deficits-that is one line being run by the Opposition-will be horrified. The dry Liberals have never had anything in terms of policy. Look at the Liberal Party's present policy document. There is about five lines. The wet Nationals tell farmers what they want to hear and rely on bullying proposals through coalition Cabinets. That is the way they work. That is why the National Party conspicuously failed to implement sensible, rational, long term policies in the many years it was in office. That is why this Government has had to implement sensible changes for the dairying industry and the sugar industry, for example, statutory marketing reform. I welcome this document also because it does accept many of the constructive, rational policy initiatives of the Hawke Government which I spelt out in this place a month ago. The Opposition is actually acknowledging that we can do what it could not.

I would like to ask what is the status of this latest document? What is the status of the former National Party 14-point plan? That would have cost between $3 billion and $6 billion. Will we have an Opposition policy on agriculture for the first time-which I may welcome-or will we have the National Party running a separate policy near election time? We really do not know because the parties opposite have never taken agricultural policy seriously. The significance of this document lies in its public appearance. It shows the splits, perhaps chasms. I am sure the Opposition Leader now knows how Caesar felt. I understand he wants to know the number on this document. I will do a deal with him. We will hand it out about three weeks before the next election.

TALK.START.PARA: —On a point of order, Madam Speaker: Would the Minister care to table the document from which he was reading?
—I call the honourable member for Riverina-Darling. The Minister has refused. He did not take advantage of the offer.

—I rise on a point of order, Madam Speaker. The Minister cannot refuse to table a document that is not classified as confidential. There is nothing confidential in that document, and I ask for your ruling. He has to table it.
—If they did not hear it and want to read it, that is fine.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Defence. Following the Government's decision to drop the Bathurst-Orange area as a site for an Army training college and in the light of information that has been received by the Senate committee of inquiry, will the Minister alleviate the worries of landowners in the Cobar area by giving an assurance that the Army manoeuvre impact area will not be established in their region?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The decision not to proceed with the Army training facilities was not made in the light of any Senate committee discussions; it was made on the basis of advice given to me by the Chief of the General Staff. At the same time as he gave that advice to me, after I sought his advice on whether or not he wanted to proceed with the acquisition of land for a manoeuvre area at Cobar, he also advised me that he still wished to proceed with that. My view is that the environmental impact study ought to be permitted to proceed and then when the result of that study is known the Government will make up its mind on whether or not it wishes to acquire the land. There has been a lot of speculation about whether or not that land is required, given developments in the force structure of the Australian Army. As to the cost of the acquisition of the land that would actually be required, only some 190,000 hectares would be needed, although the Army would be seeking special access to a much larger area than that. The area to be acquired is minimal, in accordance with whatever level of priority might be assigned to particular armoured capabilities that would be exercised within it. Whether or not the force structure of the Army is changed, amended, or whatever, there is still a substantial requirement in place in the armed forces for a manoeuvre area.

ANSWER.PARA: The issue as to whether that land is acquired is different. As I have said, I expect an environmental impact study would give us some useful advice. A great deal of information has been provided to this point by those who argue against the Cobar facility, which suggests that it would be environmentally damaging were we to proceed with it. I would say to landholders in that area that if that is their belief and if they have that substantial advice, it will be very much in their interests to permit that environmental impact study to proceed to a conclusion. As I understand it, they have not yet arrived at that determination themselves. I believe that in not permitting the study to proceed landholders conceivably are materially damaging their interest.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Acting Minister for Foreign Affairs. The South African Government has stated that its pre-emptive attacks on centres in Zambia, Zimbabwe and Botswana are its response to the need for the Western world to act against international terrorism. Because this is a similar justification to that used by the United States following its pre-emptive attack upon Libya, is it possible that the action of the United States encouraged, or pardons, this action by South Africa? If the Western world condemns South Africa but does not condemn the United States, does this mean that there are good terrorists and bad terrorists?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —To answer the question simply before I deal with it in detail, my answer would be: No, I do not see an equivalence in the situation that occurred in relation to United States action in regard to Libya and that which occurred in the recent attacks by the South African Government across its borders in neighbouring states. I would say, as was said by the Prime Minister at the time, that this Government is not committed to the view that inter- national issues should be settled by resort to violence. But the situation that occurred in Libya was a product of a chain of political initiatives by the United States to attempt to get a resolution of the problem-to secure support for allies and to engage the Libyan Government in a process of discussion, hopefully to achieve a conclusion of removing Libyan support for terrorist activity. It was a decision taken by the US very much against the background in which a political settlement had been sought.

ANSWER.PARA: An entirely different situation applies in South Africa. A plethora of possibilities are open to the South African Government to address the real political problems in that area. All those opportunities have been set aside by the South African Government. It is not without significance that it undertook that action at precisely the point of time when the Eminent Persons Group happened to be visiting South Africa. It represents a sincere initiative on the part of the Commonwealth to attempt to find a settlement whereby the South African Government can enter into a process of negotiation with the majority of the people of South Africa to secure a political settlement which will secure both stability and democratic rights in that country, and in so doing substantially advance Western interests.

All those opportunities have been set aside by the South African Government, both by its actions in this instance and by its general response to the political situation in which that Government finds itself. The South African Government is resorting to resolving its political problems, both internally and externally, by military means, not by negotiation. It has not put forward any proposition that could be seriously entertained by those who seek majority rule in that area and the South African Government has given every indication that it intends not to proceed on that course. In addition, South Africa attacked the territory of our fellow Commonwealth members. It did not sustain a case that substantial terrorist activity had been undertaken across its borders; it simply asserted it. The political context, as I have said, is totally different in those two situations.

To conclude, I would reiterate what Senator Button, as the Acting Minister for Foreign Affairs, said when the raids took place. He was totally condemnatory of them. I understand that the Opposition spokesman on foreign affairs was condemnatory in similar terms. I notice that he is nodding his head in agreement, and that is very welcome indeed. Such actions are insupportable; they are not only damaging to the process of achieving political settlement but-I make this as an ancillary point-they are also damaging to Western interests. We have friendly relations with all the countries that have been attacked. Those friendly relations are important to us, they are important to the Commonwealth. The rogue actions of the South African Government have moved beyond the area of creating a difficult political situation within South Africa; they have moved onto a plane where that Government is directly attacking and threatening Western interests.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: UNITED NATIONS EDUCATIONAL, SCIENTIFIC AND CULTURAL ORGANISATION

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister representing the Acting Minister for Foreign Affairs able to confirm that the Australian Ambassador to the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organisation, Mr Whitlam, has been responsible for the unauthorised disclosure of confidential Geneva Group documents to the UNESCO Director-General Mr M'Bow? If so, was this disclosure of Geneva Group documents approved by the Minister and, if not approved, what action has been taken to censure the Ambassador?
—I am not aware of the circumstances to which the honourable gentleman alludes. I will refer the matter to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and he can answer it directly when he returns next week.

—Is the Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism aware of a recent article by Mr Max Harris in the Australian newspaper which was highly critical of the Australian Tourist Commission's current Asian advertising campaign?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon J.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of that article. It strikes me as a pity that somebody of Max Harris's pre-eminence as a writer of the English language should seek to lower himself to this form of intellectual snobbery. The article purports to say that the recent Tourist Commission campaign in Asia is ockerish to say the least and an insult to our Asian neighbours. One must measure it in terms of Max Harris's capacity to be a judge of tourism advertising, because he was one of those who, together with some rather snobbish members of the present Opposition, were critical of my attempts to use Paul Hogan to promote Australia in the United States. Mr Harris fell flat on his face then, as he will in this instance.

ANSWER.PARA: The campaign is about portraying Australia as a friendly, laid-back, easy-going country, which is something our marketing investigations showed Asians did not support. While Mr Harris might see this advertising campaign as ockerish, in fact it is highly successful. He claims that this would be insulting to our Asian neighbours. I assure Mr Harris that this campaign was put together by Monahan Dayman Adams Ltd, one of the most important advertising agencies in Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —Adams again!

—Yes, Adams again. In fact, the copy was written by a mixture of Caucasians and Asians. The campaign is funded jointly by the Australian Tourist Commission, Singapore Airlines and several other local tour operators, who I think would have a fairly good idea of what is acceptable to the Asian population.

ANSWER.PARA: Enough of Max Harris and his article. I note with interest a number of documents that are floating about, having fallen off trucks, about Opposition policies. I hope that the shadow Minister is very quick to release his policy. In some respects mimicry is the highest form of flattery. It is nice to find the Opposition, which has never had a policy on tourism because it did not think tourism worth looking at, now taking the Australian Labor Party policy and embracing it as its own. It is very kind of Opposition members to do that. I do not think the tourist industry will be very happy about their views on taxation. I note with interest that the Liberal candidate for Nerang, which is the State seat in the shadow Minister's own electorate of McPherson, has now come out with the policy that the tourist industry should be taxed. `It is big enough to pull its own weight', says the Liberal candidate.

Honourable members might be pleased to know that one of the reasons why we have been able to make tourism a great success in Australia, is that we took off it a couple of the stupid taxes that the Opposition members invoked. First of all, we have pegged the price of tax at $20. It has not moved since we have been in office but Opposition members doubled it in a year; we took the tax off the building of tourist boats; we have increased depreciation by 2 1/2 per cent to 4 1/2 per cent. It is no wonder the tourism industry loves us. It would be very happy to find that Opposition members are thinking about a few new taxes for it. That is a clever way. If those opposite would like us to drop their policy, I am happy to do it, but I think it would be much more proper if they did it themselves. Those opposite had better get these ideas of new taxes out of their policy before they drop it. If they just embrace ours they are on the right track, but if they start putting these in, they are going to be considered an even bigger goose than they are.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister representing the Minister for Veterans' Affairs aware that the Minister for Veterans' Affairs is currently conducting a political function at the Australian War Memorial associated with a ceremony in relation to the proclamation of the controversial Veterans' Entitlements Act? Is he aware that that function is only taking place because of an absolute ministerial direction and therefore could well have been over the objections of the management and Council of the Australian War Memorial? Will he take this opportunity to apologise to the veterans and to all Australians for this misuse of the Australian War Memorial? Will he assure the House that this will never be done again?
—I understand that there are certain ceremonies going on at the War Mem- orial. I regret that the shadow Minister's regard for them is political.

—Is the Minister for Health aware of Opposition claims that the national campaign against drug abuse is funding bureaucrats rather than going to those who are actively engaged in the battle against drug abuse? Can the Minister inform the House as to the true extent of the extra funding going to drug workers, educators and researchers under the national campaign against drug abuse?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Blewett The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think that he is referring to some of the further nonsense emanating from this so-called coalition drugs task force. About a fortnight ago its task seemed to be to do its best to try to discredit the advertising campaign we were engaged in now. We have had a 91 per cent recognition of the drug offensive pamphlet-that was registered by McNair Anderson Associates Pty Ltd, a professional survey unit-rather than the kind of Liberal gossip which that group had relied on. This week apparently the task force is suggesting that the program is not going to the streets, that somehow it is going to bureaucrats. That is completely deceitful nonsense.

ANSWER.PARA: The overwhelming bulk of the $100m being spent over the next three years is going to the community level organisations, whether they are private ones such as the Life Education Centre which is getting nearly $1m this year or whether they are schools, health centres, and other government agencies. A total of $78m will be going on education, treatment and rehabilitation; $9m will be going on much needed research and the $13m on the information campaign will be used in many cases by the toll free information telephone system, for educational packs for schools, for parents, for teachers and for health professionals. I think that all of those people should feel insulted to be told that they are not at the coal face in this business. The Opposition has a highly distorted idea of the coal face in this question. For instance, does the Opposition really regard the expenditure of $2m on drugs and prisons as somehow not being directed at the problem even though that is operated by the bureaucrats in the prisons? Again, does the Opposition really think that the $700,000 we are spending on providing a street kids program in Kings Cross, even though that will be run by government agencies in New South Wales, is not a street face answer to the problem? According to the honourable member for Gilmore the $1.7m being spent on programs with teachers in our schools is somehow not a street face program because it is using teachers and bureaucrats.

The whole attack by this extraordinary committee is highly manipulative. Some people noticed that in the last four weeks approximately 16 letters had been written by a single individual called D. A. Johnston, nit picking about the national campaign against drug abuse. Last week we found out that D. A. Johnston was, in fact, the Press officer of the honourable member for Gilmore. Poor Mr Johnston protested. He said: `I did it off my own bat out of working hours as a concerned Australian citizen'-out of working hours to 16 newspapers, making the same nit-picking comments.

This coalition task force does not realise that it is attacking its own political colleagues. I have got to say that in Queensland and in Tasmania excellent street face programs are being run by the bureaucrats of the Queensland Government and the bureaucrats of the Tasmanian Government. All this task force has done is to produce 16 nitpicking letters by a party-paid hack. I suggest to the Leader of the Opposition that the most constructive thing he could do about the drug campaign would be to get rid of the task force.

DEBATE.TITLE: INDUSTRIES ASSISTANCE COMMISSION

TALK.START.PARA: —For the information of honourable members, I present the Industries Assistance Commission's report on vegetables and vegetable products.
—Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows and copies will be referred to the appropriate Ministers:

PETITION.PRESENTERS: BROWN; BROWN; CHYNOWETH; CONNOLLY; GRACE; MAHER; MARTIN; O'NEIL; RUDDOCK; STAPLES; WEBSTER
PETITION.NAMEIDS: OD4; 5A5; JF4; QF4; ZG4; GP4; 8I4; DE4; 0J4; KJ4; WJ4
PETITION.TITLE: International Year for Repairing the Earth
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
This petition of concerned Australian citizens respectfully points out:

That, for our survival, an effective Worldpeace Initiative needs to be established to work towards mutual understanding, world disarmament, economic well-being for all and full employment. This Initiative will help to ensure a sustainable society conserving natural resources, and revitalising soils essential for growing a plentiful and healthy food supply and tree cover for the needs of present and future generations. By working for these objectives, Australia can set an example for the rest of the world.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that your Honourable House will:
1. Propose to the United Nations General Assembly that 1989 be declared International Year for Repairing the Earth.
2. Implement action programs leading up to 1989 which will include:
(a) Actively supporting the International Year of Peace in 1986 by reallocating at least 10% of our military expenditure to fund environmental repair programs.

(b) Implementing National Recycling Programs to reuse water, and to compost into hygienic humus all presently wasted organic garbage and sewage-sludge mixed with fine ground powder from mineral-rich gravels and rocks, to use as a natural fertiliser in revitalising impoverished soils;

(c) Developing National Employment Programs giving priority to the planting and growing of healthy forests, food-producing trees and other crops and vegetation including environmentally sound use and reuse of water to assist the greening of Australia.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr John Brown,Mr Robert Brown,Mr Chynoweth,Mr Connolly,Mr Grace,Mr Maher,Mr Martin,Mr O'Neil,Mr Ruddock,Mr Staples and Mr Webster.

PETITION.TITLE: International Year for Repairing the Earth
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
This petition of concerned Australian citizens respectfully points out:

That, for our survival, an effective Worldpeace Initiative needs to be established which will work towards mutual understanding, world disarmament, economic well-being for all and fulfilling employment, a sustainable society conserving natural resources, and revitalising soils essential for growing a plentiful and healthy food supply and tree cover. By achieving these objectives, Australia can set an example for the rest of the world to follow.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that your Honourable House will:
1. Create an Australian Ministry for Peace specifically devoted to peace-building and the non-violent resolution of conflict
2. Convene a national Summit for Survival to discuss the issues of world disarmament, security and national and international co-operation;
3. Fully support the United Nations World Disarmament Campaign by allocating the equivalent of at least 10% of the defence budget to fund peace activities:
4. Actively assist the International Year of Peace in 1986 by initiating programs for peace education, self-help development and environmental repair;
5. Develop National Employment Programs to give priority to the planting and growing of forests, food-producing trees and other crops; and

6. Implement National Recycling Programs to reuse water, and to compost all presently wasted sewage-sludge and organic garbage into hygienic humus, a natural fertiliser, for use in rehabilitating impoverished soils;
7. Propose to the United Nations General Assembly that 1989 be declared International Year for Repairing the Earth.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Blunt,Mr Burr,Mr Steele Hall and Ms McHugh.

PETITION.TITLE: International Year for Repairing the Earth
PETITION.PARA: For 1988 to be proclaimed the ``First International Earth Repair Year'' (FIERY) as a vital action to ignite global co-operation for Worldpeace and as an international aspect of the Australian Bicentenary.
To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
This petition of concerned Australian citizens respectfully points out:

That deterioration of the total global environment is continuing at an increasing rate; that important environmental resources vital to human livelihood such as trees; soil and water are decreasing at an alarming rate; that there is a need for educating all people to assume a greater responsibility for the conservation, sustainable use and maintenance of vital resources; that dynamic and active initiatives are needed to conserve and renew the total environment; and that protecting, conserving and repairing the Earth can unite all people and nations in co-operative action for survival.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Australian Government will: Propose to the United Nations General Assembly at its 41st Session in September 1986 that 1988 be proclaimed the ``First International Earth Repair Year''.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Connolly,Mr Ruddock and Mr Sinclair.

PETITION.TITLE: Changes to Veterans' Entitlements
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.

The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that persistent rumour suggests that the Hawke Government intends to reduce Government expenditure by contracting or eliminating programs for war veterans and war widows.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the Hawke Government honour its commitment and that of previous Governments to ex-servicemen and women by:
Ensure no additional cut-backs will be made to the portfolio of Veterans' Affairs.
Review the previous cut-backs in such areas as the travel allowances, dental scheme and repatriation pharmaceutical benefits scheme.
Proceed with abolishing more stringent conditions applying to the granting of the TPI pension.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Drummond and Mr Halverson.

PETITION.TITLE: Changes to Veterans' Entitlements
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Richmond electorate respectfully showeth that:
Persistent rumour suggests that the Hawke Government intends to reduce Government expenditure by contracting or eliminating programs for war veterans and war widows.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, urge the Government to:
Honour its commitment and that of previous Governments to ex-servicemen and women by:
Ensuring no additional cut-backs will be made to the portfolio of Veterans' Affairs.
Reviewing the previous cut-backs in such areas as the travel allowances, dental scheme and repatriation pharmaceutical benefits scheme.
Proceed with abolishing more stringent conditions applying to the granting of the TPI pension.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Radioactive Substances
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth. We most strongly oppose the process of food irradiation by radioactive Cobalt 60 or any other radioactive substance.

We oppose the introduction of regulations that will facilitate the food irradiation process by State Governments. We express our deep concern at this attempt to extend the use of radioactive substances and exposure of workers to radiation.

We call on the Government to immediately ban the importation of radioactive Cobalt 60 or other radioactive substances and to immediately disallow the regulations that permit the irradiation of food here in Australia.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Ms Jakobsen and Mr Milton.

PETITION.TITLE: Nuclear Free Zones
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The humble petition of citizens of Australia shows-

That the people of New Zealand and the New Zealand Government have given an example to the world in their efforts to achieve a nuclear free South Pacific, and such decision being endorsed by the people at a general election.

Your petitioners therefore pray that the Australian Government support the principled stand taken by the New Zealand Government and urges it to condemn any efforts by the U.S. Government to impose economic or other sanctions on New Zealand in retaliation for their stand on nuclear vessels.
We further urge the Australian Government to urgently implement its policy to promote the development of zones of peace and nuclear free zones in the Indian and Pacific Oceans.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Kent and Mr Staples.

PETITION.TITLE: Pensions
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The humble petition of the undersigned citizens respectfully showeth that your petitioners are gravely concerned at the failure of the Government to honour its election promises to pensioners.
In particular those promises relate to the following commitments:
1. That within three years of its election to office, a Hawke Labor Government would raise the level of the standard pension to 25% of Average Weekly Earnings;
2. That the lag time between the announcement of the Consumer Price Index figures and the subsequent adjustment of pensions would be reduced to one month, and
3. That the disproportionate tax burden borne by low income earners would be lifted.
None of these promises has been honoured to date.

Your petitioners are extremely angry at the failure of the Government to live up to its commitments and as in duty bound will ever pray that these serious omissions will be given the attention they deserve.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Ian Robinson and Mr Webster.

PETITION.TITLE: Fuel Prices
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned shows that the Hawke Government should:
pass on the full benefit of lower international oil prices on 1 March 1986;
not increase or extend fuel taxes; and
maintain its tax cut commitments.
And your petitioners humbly pray that the Hawke Government honour its commitment to the Import Parity Pricing policy.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Nuclear Weapons Tests
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled; and to the Australian Government.
This petition of concerned Australian citizens respectfully points out that a comprehensive ban on all nuclear weapon tests in all environments for all time would be a vital first step towards:
inhibiting the addition of more and more sophisticated and destabilising nuclear weapons to the world's arsenals;
arresting the extension of the arms race to outer space;
upholding the provisions of existing treaties and agreements.
Your petitioners humbly pray that:

1. The Australian Government-(a) take new initiatives to encourage all member states of the United Nations-especially the governments of nuclear weapon states-to conclude at an early stage a treaty banning all nuclear weapon tests in all environments for all time; (b) call on all nuclear weapon states to declare an immediate moratorium on all nuclear weapon tests pending conclusion of a CTB.
2. All Federal members of parliament and senators make strong representations to the Australian Government to act towards these goals.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia showeth that whereas:
1. They are completely satisfied with the design of the existing Australian National Flag.
2. They are aware it properly reflects the immutable characteristics of Australia, namely:
(a) The Union Jack, itself the creation of three Christian Crosses, represents the nation's historical origin and the source of its language and law;
(b) The Southern Cross on an azure blue background signifying its geographical location on this planet Earth;
(c) The large star depicting the advent of Federation in 1901.
3. They know the Flag has been a source of inspiration to generations of Australians in peace and war. Men have died for this flag to keep it flying.
4. They recall that millions of native-born Australians and newcomers to these shores from other parts of the world have become united under its proud symbolism.
5. They are certain that any change to the Flag will produce divisions in the Australian community.
Your petitioners therefore pray that your honourable House will:
Propose and pass a motion that ``the existing Australian National Flag be changed only with the approval of the Nation as expressed in a Referendum''.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Discrimination against Women
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That numerous provisions exist in industrial legislation and awards which purport to provide special protection to women workers but which have been shown to be detrimental to their achievement of equality in employment. Noting the relevant provision in Article 11 of the United Nations Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination against Women to which Australia is a party your petitioners request that urgent action be taken to ensure that these legal barriers to equality be removed.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Prescription Drugs for Pensioners
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
(1) That we the undersigned are totally opposed to the introduction of a $2.00 fee on prescription drugs for pensioners;
(2) That the impact of such a fee will be particularly felt by the chronically ill elderly who will be faced with a $2.00 burden with the purchase of each Pharmaceutical Benefit Scheme drug;

Your petitioners therefore urge the House of Representatives and the Government of the Commonwealth to ensure that prescription drugs continue to be provided to the pensioner population without the $2.00 fee on each prescription.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Superannuation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia showeth:
That many Australian wage and salary earners and self-employed persons do not enjoy secure retirement incomes provided by superannuation; and

that the Government issued in December 1985 guidelines for the implementation of the proposed productivity decision by the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission and draft operational standards for superannuation schemes.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Government:
1. Guarantees to every employee the right and freedom to select the superannuation scheme of his/her choice.
2. Protects the individual exercising that freedom of choice from any coercion, influence or other pressure which may be applied by any employer, association or trade union.
3. Will recognise only those schemes which provide genuine superannuation and reject those schemes which do not provide for-
preservation of benefits to retirement
vesting of employer contributions on a reasonable sliding scale
equal employer and employee trusteeship control to ensure security of investments.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Identity Cards
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned shows:
That the proposed introduction of compulsory identification (ID) cards should be reconsidered and rejected because the system:
(a) is not a cost-effective method of reducing tax evasion and social security fraud and, to the contrary, in the form proposed will facilitate such evasion and fraud;
(b) will constitute an unwarranted infringement of individual privacy by the aggregation of a wide variety of personal information of a private nature;
(c) will cause a further large and costly growth in the bureaucracy and burden on the taxpayer; and
(d) cannot be guaranteed against misuse for purposes other than for which their introduction is stated to be intended and in fact provide the opportunity for blackmail and other forms of misuse.
And your petitioners humbly pray that the problems which identification cards are intended to reduce should be attacked by other, more effective and less obnoxious methods.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Namibia
PETITION.PARA: To the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.

The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that the humble petitioners respectfully believe that the representatives in Australia of the African National Congress and the South West Africa Peoples Organisation should not have to suffer unending financial problems related to the cost of rent, food and clothing, and the maintenance of two small offices run on the most austere basis.
Your petitioners therefore pray and urge the provision of:
1. Official recognition of ANC and SWAPO as the legitimate representatives of the people of South Africa and Namibia.
2. Financial support to the offices and representatives of the African National Congress and the South West Africa Peoples Organisation to promote the anti-apartheid cause.
3. Additional financial support for the official representatives of the ANC and SWAPO to assist the humanitarian needs of Namibian and South African refugees who are victims of apartheid.
4. Scholarships for South African and Namibian refugees. These to be provided through the ANC and SWAPO education departments.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and the Honourable Members of the House of Representatives assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia sheweth that whereas:
1. The present Australian national flag is not distincitively and uniquely Australian and is confused with other national flags.
2. The people of Australia have never had the opportunity to express their views on an appropriate Australian national flag in a referendum.
3. The present Australian national flag does not properly represent Australia as a sovereign independent nation.
4. The present Australian national flag falsely proclaims Australia as a colony, homeland, protectorate, dominion or government department of Great Britain.
5. The first condition in the flag competition of 1901 required that the design should show Australia's loyalty to the British Empire. The British Empire no longer exists.
6. A public opinion poll held in 1984 using the Gallup Method revealed that 52% of Australians surveyed wanted a competition for a new design for the Australian flag.
7. There is no inherent link between Australia proclaiming a unique and distinctive flag and the political issue of Australia moving to a republican form of government.
8. The adoption of a truly Australian national flag would serve as a focal point for Australia's bicentennial celebrations in 1988.
Your petitioners therefore pray that your honourable House will:
(a) Appoint a Committee of the Parliament with representatives from both Houses and all parties to invite and consider proposals for the design of a new Australian national flag, and

(b) Require that Committee to make recommendations on the form of a minimum cost referendum at the time of the next general elections, in which the electors will be given the opportunity to vote for a flag from a selection of at least three designs which will include the present Australian national flag and the winner of the Ausflag-Bulletin-2MMM.FM competition of March 1985.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Tamils in Sri Lanka
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.

We the undersigned are deeply concerned that under the guise of ceasefire the Government of Sri Lanka has largely militarised Tamil regions and has now resorted to airship attacks in highly populated areas and indiscriminate killings of civilians which is seen even by the Indian Foreign Minister as having genocidal tendencies.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled will call upon the Government to:
1. Intercede with the Government of Sri Lanka to desist from airship attacks and seeking a military solution;
2. To offer refuge under humanitarian and compassionate programs, to Tamils who are fleeing from the violence;
3. Abandon all direct and indirect forms of repatriation of any Tamil who has sought refuge in Australia and grant them meaningful assistance to resettle;
4. As a member of the Commonwealth, persuade the Government of Sri Lanka to pursue a political solution which will allow the Tamils to live in peace and dignity.
Your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Koalas

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that your Honourable House declare that the koala may not be exported from this country and that urgent re-vegetation of their habitats be carried out. Your petitioners also humbly pray that Commonwealth Government funds will be made available for research into the disease Chlamydia Psittaci which is killing the koala.
And your petitioners, and in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Housing Related Poverty
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. This petition of citizens of Australia shows that-
Approximately 100,000 Australians live on the verge of homelessness, dependent on Government resources to survive, or sleep out of doors or in refuges.
Over 700,000 households, or in excess of 2 million Australians are living below the poverty line after paying their rent or mortgage costs.
In addition, there are thousands of households with special needs, such as the disabled, who are not well catered for in the private sector but who nevertheless require suitable housing.
Waiting lists for public housing have almost doubled in the past five years to 146,000 by June 1985. The list is expected to grow to some 250,000 by 1990.
We therefore ask that the Australian Government, as a highest priority:
undertake a campaign to bring the issue of poverty and, in particular, housing-related poverty, to the attention of the Australian public,
increase expenditure on public housing through the Commonwealth State Housing Agreement, by at least 15% annually in real terms,
increase rent relief payments for those on low incomes in the private rental market,
use its influence with State and Territory governments to encourage them to increase their expenditures on public housing.

PETITION.TITLE: Nuclear Weapons Tests
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. This petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia shows that:
in this International Year of Peace, 1986, the world needs a nuclear test moratorium by the United States, the Soviet Union, France and other nuclear-testing powers,
that such a moratorium would create a favourable climate and basis for the negotiation of a Comprehensive Nuclear Test Ban Treaty,
that such a Moratorium and Comprehensive Nuclear Test Ban Treaty would-
be the first vital step to nuclear disarmament,
impede the development of new nuclear weapons,
decrease the reliance upon an unstable nuclear strategy,
inhibit the spread of nuclear weapons.
Your petitioners therefore ask that the Australian Government be urged to-
1. Use its influence with the United States Government to encourage it to join the moratorium on nuclear testing begun by the Soviet Union on 6 August 1985.
2. Use its influence in all forums to encourage other nuclear nations to join the Nuclear Test Moratorium.
3. Use its influence in all forums to encourage non-nuclear nations to demand the establishment of a Nuclear Test Moratorium and Comprehensive Nuclear Test Ban Treaty.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Bill of Rights Bill
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That the proposed Australian Bill of Rights Bill 1985 will endanger the Federal system in Australia, the State and Federal criminal justice systems, the State and Federal Police Force, the State and Federal education systems, the independence of the churches and religious associations, marriage and the family, children, the unborn, the handicapped, the aged and the infirm, employer and employee relationships and Australian society generally.

PETITION.TITLE: National Life and Democratic Institutions

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Bill of Rights Bill
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The petition of certain electors of Dawson shows that the proposed Bill of Rights:
overlooks basic rights concerning union membership, education, and private property,

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Bill of Rights Bill

DEBATE.TITLE: ECONOMY

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Madam SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr N.A. Brown) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The public concern at the Government's mishandling of the economy as most recently shown by its incompetent handling of the National Wage and Productivity cases.
I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of members required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —This matter of public importance gives the Opposition an opportunity to make three basic, simple points about the economy of this country and the way in which it is being handled by the present Government. Each of these points arises out of the current case before the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission for a national wage increase and a productivity rise. The three basic points that we make are: First of all, the Government has engaged in the grossest deception of the Arbitration Commission as to the real truth about the Australian economy. Secondly, the Government's cover has now been blown and it has been exposed for the deceptive and misleading government that it is. Thirdly, the Government, its cover having been blown, has participated in a complete and absolute shambles of irresponsibility in its handling of the proposed summit and the presentation of its case to the Arbitration Commission.

SPEECH.PARA: We go further than making those three simple points. We say to the Government that there is no need to have another summit. It is clear what the Government should do. It is clear that, in the first place, it should argue before the Arbitration Commission that the present national wage case should be deferred at least until September of this year. Secondly, it should argue for full discounting for the effects of the devaluation of the Australian dollar. Thirdly, and most importantly, it should argue that the three per cent productivity case should be deferred for at least 12 months, if not abandoned for the foreseeable future. We are not simply drawing the attention of the Australian people to the shortcomings of the Government's presentation; we are being positive and saying that there are clear, obvious, essential matters that the Government should attend to and very clear positions that it should put to the Arbitration Commission if it does not want this country to continue to go down the drain.

Let us look in a little more detail at each of those three clear, simple points. The first is that the Government has engaged in the grossest deception of the Arbitration Commission in the presentation of its economic material to the Commission. It has attempted to deceive the Arbitration Commission first on the basis of what it has not put to it and, secondly, on the basis of the sparse material on our external trade that it has put to the Commission. One would think on looking at the Government's submission to the Arbitration Commission-over 1,000 pages of transcript and of duck speak and gobbledegook-that at least one would find some warning about the dangers confronting this country if we continue to trade at a loss as we are now. But one would look in vain for any clue or indication whatsoever that the Government has the slightest understanding of the economic dangers facing this country.

At least seven out of the 1,000 or so pages of the submission are devoted to the external sector. One would be excused for thinking that at least in those seven pages one might find some inkling of an understanding and an appreciation by the Government of the very difficult trading situation with which this country is faced. One would also expect to find the Government arguing that this situation would have consequences with regard to the decisions that the Arbitration Commission should make on wages and productivity. But one would look in vain for the slightest indication of understanding by the Government on those matters.

The second point we make is that not only did the Government fail to put forward to the Arbitration Commission any evidence or material showing that this country is in a desperate situation with regard to trade and the effects that that trade should have on wage decisions in this country; it has gone further than that and actively misled the Arbitration Commission in its presentation of the economy. Let us look at just a couple of extracts of what the Government has said to the Arbitration Commission. We can say to the Australian people: `This is what your elected government has said when it has gone to the Arbitration Commission in the context of the current wages case'. I ask honourable members to listen to this gem to be found at page 609 of the transcript. It states:

The Commonwealth submits that our assessment of economic conditions and prospects and of productivity growth demonstrates that the economy has not only recovered substantially but has the capacity to sustain an increase in national wage beyond CPI adjustments.
What the Government was saying to the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission--

TALK.START.PARA: —How long ago?

—This was when the Government made its submission in the current case. This is not some piece of ancient history. It is the Government's current submission. It is saying to the Arbitration Commission: `We have assessed the economy of this country and what we say you should do is take the inflation rate and not do the sensible and economically responsible thing but add something on top of that'. That is an utterly irresponsible attitude for the Government to take because it means that if that sort of approach is embodied in wage decisions in this country we will continue to have high inflation. Our inflation rate will continue to increase as the inflation rate of the rest of the industrial world continues to go down. That means that there will be horrendous consequences in terms of investment in this country, in terms of economic growth in this country and in terms of the expansion of employment in this country. That is the first piece of misleading and utterly irresponsible information that the Government put to the Arbitration Commission. After analysing the economy and the economic statistics the Government then gave the Commission this gem. The Government stated:

SPEECH.PARA: Therefore, it seems at the very least, the improved competitiveness of Australian firms-
that is absolute nonsense-
has resulted in the import competing sector enjoying an improved market share.

What absolute nonsense! There is no basis for that whatsoever. It represents an utterly irresponsible economic presentation by the Government. The Government then went on to give a final gem which I suppose sums up the presentation the Government was putting to the Commission. After analysing the parlous statistics the Government put to the Commission it stated that on this basis Australia would substantially retain last year's improvement in competitiveness and that that would be a good outcome. That is the economic presentation that this irresponsible Government is putting to the Arbitration Commission. We say it is actively misleading the Commission in the presentation it is putting to it on the basis of the economy. However, it is not only that the Government is misleading the Arbitration Commission but also it is misleading the Australian people. Believe it or not but as late as 9 May this year the Treasurer (Mr Keating) in his speech to the Economic Planning Advisory Council said:
. . . some encouraging signs are beginning to emerge in recent balance of payments statistics.

He said that this month. He said that it is encouraging that trade is getting better. He must have thought that we could sell a few more shipments of bananas and trade our way out of the problem that way. Furthermore, the Treasurer said that the value of imports was going down. That is good news. Finally he said:
. . . the Government is confident that we are also seeing something of the expected volume response to the depreciation, and that we will see more of it in the period ahead.

We have not seen more of that in the period ahead. What we have seen is more deterioration of the economy of this country under the economic policies of this irresponsible Government. We say first of all that it is clear beyond any argument at all that the Government has misled the Arbitration Commission both in regard to the economic material it has not put before the Commission and in the way in which it has presented the parlous statistics it has put to the Commission. Our second point is that that attempt to mislead the community and the Arbitration Commission has now been exposed. The Government's cover has been blown.

The Government's cover has been blown by two things. Firstly, we must give due credit to it, it has been blown by the presentation of the National Farmers Federation to the Arbitration Commission which exposed all this nonsense and falsity. It is as a result of the National Farmers Federation submission that the Commission is now asking the Government to come back to the Bench and explain and defend itself. Secondly, the Government has had its cover blown by the extraordinary balance of payments figures that came out last week. What do they show? We can dress it all up in economic big words and complicated sentences but what we say to the Australian people is this: You can understand this because it is a simple, clear proposition; the proposition that emerges from these figures is that Australia is pricing itself out of world markets and is pricing its people out of jobs. Unless we take a firm hold on that, unless we understand it and unless we implement very promptly sound economic policies, this country not only is going to become a banana republic but this country will be doomed. We make that perfectly plain.

Furthermore, we say that the situation is getting worse. The Government has now produced a current account deficit which, believe it or not, is at an annual rate of $14 1/2 billion. Let us see how the Government thought the deficit was going to work out. At the time of the Budget the Government said that the deficit would be $10.7 billion for the whole year. The Government is now saying that currently the deficit is $14 1/2 billion-an annual rate of loss of trade for this country of $14.5 billion. We are only 10 months through the financial year. Of course, the Government takes great pleasure in denigrating the Fraser Government. Let us look briefly at what happened to trade under the Fraser Government. Of course there were trading problems but the average deficit for those seven Fraser years of government was $4.7 billion. After 10 months of the present financial year all that this Government can do is drive this country into hock to the extent of $14 1/2 billion. We say that this attempt to deceive has not succeeded. We say that the Government's cover has been blown.

The third point is simply that this Government, its cover having been blown, has embarked on a policy of complete and utter shambles showing its economic incompetence and showing that the only way it can handle a national crisis is by panic. What was the Government's response? First of all there was the cry of disaster, and the money markets reeled. Secondly, there was the cry: Have another summit. If this Government asks for more summits it will have to install ski lifts up here. Thirdly, of course, when the shambles became apparent the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) got on the telephone and summoned his minions into the office. It was a case of Tiberius on the telephone trying to get some order into his unruly troops. Suddenly, we did not have a summit but we had a mini-meeting of some sort. However, yesterday, the Treasurer elevated it again to the level of a summit. What we say about these summits simply is that the Government should show some responsibility, face up to the real decisions that have to be made before this country goes down the drain and implement those policies. We say that, if those decisions require the Government to go to the Arbitration Commission and make it plain to it what economic decisions must be made for the welfare of this country, it should do so.

I said-I must make it plain-that we are not being negative about this matter. We have clear and concrete proposals which obviously must be implemented. What we say to the Government is this: It is clear in the first place that it must renegotiate the prices and incomes accord with the unions; secondly, it must postpone, for at least 12 months, the superannuation productivity deal of 3 per cent; thirdly, it must delay the current national wage case at least until September this year; fourthly, it must abandon its absurd and outrageous taxation changes, which will simply drive business down and make it more difficult for business to employ people and invest; fifthly, it must argue for full discounting for the effects of devaluation; and sixthly, it must provide more flexibility in our industrial relations system. If we continue with the industrial relations system that we have, if the Government tries to implement full wage indexation or, indeed, as we know now from what I have read to the House today, the Government tries to implement a level of indexation above the consumer price index level, we will perpetuate inflation, dry up investment in this country and do very severe damage to the employment prospects of the Australian people.

The lasting monument to the Hawke Government is a level of unemployment which is now over 600,000 people. According to the Commonwealth Employment Service statistics there are now 840,000 people unemployed. It is clear what the Government should do. It should take hold of the economic situation, forget about having summits or mini-summits, forget about getting up on to the foothills, and face up to the economic disaster confronting this country. The Government should take the positive decisions that we have outlined and which I have just read out. The Government should do its job and go off to the Arbitration Commission and argue for those policies. What this country needs is responsibility. It needs a sensible industrial relations system. Above all, it needs a new government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Willis The Hon R.

TALKER.NAME: Mr WILLIS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations)

TALK.START.PARA: —The speech to which we have just listened was strong on indignation and fulmination and grossly lacking in rationality, common sense and honesty. The accusations made by the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr N.A. Brown) simply are not true. There has been no deception of the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission and no deception of the Australian people. Indeed, I would have thought that what has happened over the past week has been clear evidence of the fact that the Government, rather than deceiving the Australian people, has been putting the position to them very starkly. There is a serious problem brought about by the decline in the terms of trade and this nation must face up to that. This can hardly be said to be deception. If anything, it is brutal honesty about the reality of the situation and the fact that adjustments must be made. I reject completely any suggestion of deception on the part of this Government. The Government is in no way seeking to deceive anyone about the problem relating to the balance of payments current account. However, that problem is not the fault of the Australian people, the trade unions, Australian business or this Government. It is due to the fact that 90 per cent of our exports are basically commodities, the prices of which are set on international markets, not by the sellers of those goods, and the prices of those items have deteriorated significantly on external markets in the past year. They have continued to deteriorate this year. That deterioration is continuing at the same time as we are seeking to redress the balance of payments problem through devaluation. While we are making some gains on the imports side by reducing the level of imports through devaluation-and we are obtaining a greater share of the market for Australian manufacturers-that is being more than counteracted at present by the deterioration in export prices and also the effect that some of that deterioration has had on volumes, particularly in relation to the export of oil. We have a problem on the export side of the terms of trade of our balance of payments which is not in the control of the Government. Nevertheless, we as a nation must face up to that.

SPEECH.PARA: There has been no attempt by this Government to hide that fact or the necessity for an adjustment in wages policy-or indeed, any other aspect of policy. Let me return to the question of wages policy under this Government. We came to government at a time when the previous Government had so mishandled the state of affairs in this country that there had been an enormous wages blowout in 1981-82. This had led to a great surge in inflation, increased unemployment and the worst recession in 50 years. We instituted a wages policy which was centralised. It was not as centralised as the policy which the previous Government, in its dying moments, had adopted in a panic stricken manner-an absolute wage freeze-but it was a policy of adjustment through indexation and a long term increase in real benefits to wage and salary earners through a productivity case. That is what we argued for in the Arbitration Commission and that was what the Commission awarded in terms of setting up principles. What we have seen since has been a wages system that is fair and reasonable to all wage and salary earners. Basically it has maintained the real level of wages until now and it has held out prospects of some real improvement through a productivity case. As we neared the end of 1985 we saw the need, as a result of problems developing on the external account, for an adjustment to our wages policy. That adjustment was negotiated by the Government with the Australian Council of Trade Unions. We wanted the unions to accept that there should be an adjustment to wages policy; we did not want that wages policy adjustment forced on them by substantial increases in unemployment. That would have been the process that the previous Government would have implemented had it still been in office. As an alternative, we negotiated an acceptance by the union movement of a reduction of 2 per cent in the indexation increase. That case is before the Commission at present.

The Deputy Leader of the Opposition has made some absurd statements in this debate, but it must be understood that in the discussions continuing before the Commission the basic underlying factor is that there is an acceptance by the Government and the ACTU that much less than full indexation should apply in this case. It has been accepted that there should be 2 per cent less than the full consumer price index. That is the basis on which the case is proceeding. There is a marginal argument between the Government and the ACTU about whether the percentage is 2.5 or 2.3, but basically there is an acceptance of about a 2 per cent discount. That is the whole basis upon which the case is proceeding. In other words, the case is proceeding on the basis that there will be a reduction in real wages-and that is with the agreement of the trade union movement. The Deputy Leader of the Opposition cannot say that there is some absurd process which will give more than a maintenance of wages through more than full indexation. There is not even full indexation in this case because the Government and the ACTU both say that there must be much less than full indexation. That is the underlying point that must be understood by all those who are listening to this debate. The whole basis on which the Opposition pursued its quarter-hour long rant and rave is false. There is no attempt to have full indexation. A case is being pursued on the basis that there will be a reduction in the level of real wages.

It is also true that the outcome of this case will come considerably later than would normally occur. Normally the outcome would be in early April. Obviously there will not be an outcome from this case until some time in June. That means we will have a delay of between two and three months-certainly a couple of months at the minimum. That means that, in effect, there has been a 100 per cent discounting for the last couple of months on top of the fact that there is agreement to a substantial discount whenever any increase is given. This all leads to the fact that wages are increasing at a rate substantially less than prices. That is the reality. I am not saying that it it wrong; I am saying that it is the reality. The adjustment that must be made because of the problems of our external account is being made.

That is not to say that that is all that needs to happen. Indeed, the situation is becoming more difficult as a result of continued deterioration in the terms of trade. At present, however, we are seeing a substantial reduction in real wages. In the past 12 months real money wages, award rates, have increased by 3.8 per cent. At the moment there is very little leakage in terms of increases in wages outside the national wage case. Essentially we have had wages increasing in the past year by about 4 per cent. At the same time prices have increased at a rate of 9 per cent. Certainly, with an adjustment in the national wage case, that rate of increase will move up a little and probably the next consumer price index figures will see inflation moving down a little. We expect it to be something like 8 per cent over the 12-month period. But we are still looking at a substantial gap between the level of wage increases, which by then will be up to around 6 per cent, and the level of prices, which are increasing at a rate of about 8 per cent. Thus, there is a significant real reduction in wages occurring at present.

Part of that adjustment was that there should be a delay in the outcome of any productivity case. In fact that case has been postponed in its presentation, and it was agreed that there should be a two-year implementation of any outcome. That is the basis upon which the claim is proceeding. The Government is supporting it on the basis that there is a long period of implementation over a couple of years. That is not the basis upon which any increase has ever been awarded by the Commission previously. In that respect, there is a very substantial diminution on the previous claim and there has been a significant adjustment in wages policy following events connected with our external account. That is the sensible reality upon which this debate should be based, rather than the absurd posturings of the Deputy Leader of the Opposition. That is not to say that that is all that needs to happen. Indeed, in the Arbitration Commission yesterday counsel for the Government said quite clearly in respect of this matter that there was still a problem on the external account and that further adjustments would have to be made. The Treasurer (Mr Keating) has been saying that quite clearly and quite starkly for the past week. We do not need the Deputy Leader of the Opposition to tell us that. The principal economic spokesman for the Government has been saying for at least the last week that we have to make a further adjustment if we are to proceed satisfactorily on a basis upon which we can overcome that problem on our external account. Again, I stress that that is not necessarily of the making of anyone in Australia, but it is a problem that we must face.

We will make those further adjustments. The question is how those adjustments should be made and where they should fall. Those are difficult decisions but they are not ones from which this Government will shrink. That was the matter which was before us during the Advisory Committee on Prices and Incomes discussions last week. It was a matter which led to considerable intense discussion and, as everyone knows, to the suggestion which basically stemmed from the employers that there should be more tripartite discussion on the issue, and the offer by us of a further meeting at which these matters could be considered. The situation at present is that the Government recognised last year that there would have to be an adjustment to wages policy. We achieved that significant adjustment to wages policy with the agreement of the ACTU. We achieved that adjustment to wages policy without having to crunch the economy through the floor, which is what the Opposition would have to do because it would not have available to it that kind of negotiated process, which is available only through the accord. It would not be available to the Opposition. In the same situation it could achieve that adjustment only by foisting upon the Australian economy a severe recession, and greatly increasing unemployment, in order to squeeze out of the system the inflation flowing from the devaluation. We are able to avoid that. We have achieved that through the discounting, through the delay in the productivity case outcome.

What we are saying now is that it is clear from the latest balance of payments figures that a further adjustment needs to be made. That adjustment can occur in various ways. We are prepared to discuss that with the parties and the parties will willingly accept those discussions. There is nothing irresponsible about that. There is no deception. The Australian people are being told the absolute stark truth about the situation. The Commission is not being deceived; no one is being deceived. In fact, part of the criticism of the Treasurer last week was that he was being too brutal and too frank. At least he was telling it like it is-that there is a problem that needs to be faced.

The situation at present is that, through the forthcoming discussions, there is a capacity to try to reach further agreement. Of course, in the end, if agreement cannot be reached, it will rest with the Government to make the appropriate decisions. The Government will make the appropriate decisions when it comes to consider what should be done following the ACPI meeting. In the end, it is a matter for the Government and we will take the appropriate decisions. We have not shrunk from them before and we will not shrink from them in the future.

Let me contrast that situation with the position of the Opposition, whose Deputy Leader in this debate said that what we needed was the Opposition's wages policy. If we had its wages policy, we would have no capacity to hold negotiations with the ACTU, as I suggested. We would have no centralised wages system that would be worth anything. Every man and woman would seek wage increases outside the centralised system. There would be nothing to stop that happening. It would be encouraged through voluntary agreements.
