People would be encouraged to rush out and do what they could for themselves because there would be no centralised system to provide protection. Everyone would have to do what he could to ensure that he stayed ahead of the game. There would be a wages free-for-all which could only be stopped by recessing the economy.

The previous Government found in 1982 that the only way in which it could control a wages explosion was to bring about the worst recession we have had for 50 years, to crunch the economy through the floor. That is what would happen again if the Opposition were in office at present. That kind of policy response can be avoided by the kinds of policies and actions being pursued by this Government. The policies we are pursuing are bringing about those adjustments which are necessary. The policies we will pursue after the ACPI meeting will certainly continue in that vein-that is, they will make the appropriate adjustments, and will do so causing the minimum amount of pain to the Australian people.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fischer Mr T.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations (Mr Willis) would have us believe that all is rosy, that the Government is relating to the situation, that it will make a series of adjustments and that it will alter its submission to the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. All of this sounds very much like too little, too late. Late last year it became self-evident that the terms of trade were deteriorating as far as Australia was concerned. There was no action from the Minister at that time. There was no statement in fundamental terms from this Minister. There was an intimation, but the Treasurer (Mr Keating) and the Minister sailed merrily on until finally, last week in Sydney, the Treasurer let the cat out of the bag and referred to the banana republic syndrome. It was only at that time that the Government came clean and informed the nation that there were fundamental concerns and very real difficulties facing our economy at this time. Of course, again, that is too little, too late.

SPEECH.PARA: I assure the House that there is massive public concern over the Australian economy, heightened by the banana republic syndrome. I point out to the House that Australians have suffered long enough from the inflexible, highly centralised wage fixing system pursued by this Government. They have suffered long enough from the machinations and manoeuvres of the industrial relations club which exists in varying degrees in this country. They have suffered long enough from outrageous demarcation disputes and industrial lawlessness, aided and abetted from time to time by actions of Ministers of this Government. The Government might like to challenge that. I remind the House that in the Mudginberri dispute the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) failed to act, failed to direct his Commonwealth meat inspectors in a way which could have led to a much earlier solution to that dispute and could have saved a massive loss of export income for Australia.

The House should not forget that one of the real culprits in this matter is that man in China, the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), since his time as President of the Australian Council of Trade Unions. The honourable member for Fraser (Mr Langmore), who is present in the House, might like to respond because it was the Prime Minister who was the man most responsible for the abolition of the junior wage award and the consequential damage that this has caused in so many industries and the damage that that has caused to the opportunities of so many young Australians. We have seen the implementation of Priority One: Young Australia programs and the lack of success that they confer on young Australians. But nothing did more harm to the employment prospects of so many young Australians than that action by Bob Hawke when he was President of the ACTU.

Strikes in key industries cause an enormous amount of difficulty and concern, notwithstanding the statistics which show an overall downturn in industrial disputation. Of course, those statistics do not pick up disputes which are less than 10 days in duration. They do not take account of the degree of difficulty caused by those strikes-the degree of cost imposed on other industries by those strikes. Let me give the House an example. Just a fortnight ago five foremen in the Grain Handling Authority of New South Wales went on strike. That resulted in a loss of five export days for the Australian wheat industry at a cost of over $2m a day and a sum total in excess of $10m. Yet the Government preaches to us that all is reasonably under control on the industrial relations front and that it is satisfied with the submissions that it is making to the Arbitration Commission at this time. Again, I say that nothing could be further from the truth. The response of this Government is very much a case of too little, too late.

I say in respect of the much vaunted prices and incomes accord, and the possibility of accord mark 3 being launched, that the accord has a lot to answer for. Let me give one quite extraordinary example of the impact of the accord.

TALK.START.PARA: —There have been great achievements.

—The honourable member for Fraser came in hook, line and sinker. He should tell that to the 20 veterans a week who are being turned away from the Repatriation General Hospital at Heidelberg in Melbourne and the Repatriation General Hospital at Concord, because the Government cannot straighten out the Federal nursing award, which is over $2,000 less than the State nursing award. As a consequence, 133 of the 504 beds at the Repatriation General Hospital at Heidelberg in Melbourne are closed at this time and veterans are being turned away. Another triumph of the accord! That is not speculation on my part; it is what I saw as shadow Minister for Veterans' Affairs when I visited the Repatriation General Hospital at Heidelberg in Melbourne. It is high time that this country, this nation, and this Government, saw a more flexible approach so far as the wage fixing structure of this country is concerned.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to commend the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, the honourable member for Menzies (Mr N.A. Brown) who is the shadow Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations, and all members of the committee for the production of the industrial relations policy of the Liberal and National parties. I want to commend the two key thrusts of that policy which are very germane to this matter of public importance on the economy. We advocate a greater use of voluntary agreements between employers and employees, commencing with small business employing 50 or fewer employees. The use of voluntary agreements will be extended progressively as circumstances justify it.

The second approach of the coalition will be to encourage more flexibility within the awards of the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. This involves the Commission taking into account as principal criteria the capacity of industry to pay. The effect that its decision will have on employment, inflation and the international competitiveness of the Australian economy will be taken into account. This is the sort of approach that this country needs. The National Farmers Federation played a very key role in trying to lead the Arbitration Commission and the Government to a measure of reality in respect of the current hearing. As the Deputy Leader of the Opposition pointed out, a series of most excellent questions were forthcoming yesterday. The NFF did its homework and calculated that if we use the Government's methodology we find that in fact there is no cake to distribute consequent upon the deterioration of our terms of trade. The Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations tried to tell the House that the Government had responded adequately to the queries raised by the NFF. However, again, nothing could be further from the truth. Once again, the response was a case of far too little, far too late.

The industrial relations policy of the Liberal and National parties represents a great leap forward and has been widely endorsed by a range of bodies too many to enumerate, representing big business-bodies such as the Confederation of Australian Industry and the Business Council of Australia, which are not at all times necessarily friends of the conservative side of politics. The policy has also been endorsed by bodies such as the Small Business People's Movement and the Australian Small Business Association. The Opposition has the support of a great range of bodies right across Australia. The Business Council of Australia said:
In summary, the broad direction of the Opposition's policy is consistent to the long term industrial relations objectives of the Business Council and is welcomed by us.
The Australian Tourism Industry Association said:

The Coalition policy initiatives are a positive step towards the kinds of employment initiatives members of regional tourism bodies keep saying are essential for them to develop the full potential of their tourism resources.
Even the media, which are not necessarily friends of ours indeed-often not-have had something to say on this matter. The editorial in the Sydney Sun of 15 May stated:
The Opposition's new industrial relations policy looks better by the day, in fact, Australia's slumping trade figures make it seem positively prophetic in diagnosing this troubled economy . . .
The Daily Mirror of 12 May stated:
The Federal Opposition is to be commended for attempting to resolve the thorny problem of national interest versus union interest.
By offering small business the chance to formulate private employment deals without the rigid impositions of union regulations the word `incentive' could move back into the marketplace.

This is the type of direction this country needs if we are to be saved from the highly centralised, highly unionised approach of this Federal Labor Government. Of course the public is concerned. It is concerned about the introduction of the fringe benefits tax; it is concerned about the capital gains tax; and it is concerned about this Government that does so much of its governing from Lygon Street, Carlton, and Sussex Street, Sydney, and the out of touch corridors of the Caucus and Cabinet rooms. What this country needs is leadership. It needs the adoption of genuine, realistic and comprehensive policies to ensure that the forthcoming recession and the banana republic syndrome can be avoided and that the rural sector and the whole economy will survive.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Langmore Mr J.V.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank goodness the country has got leadership and that is being demonstrated in the national wage case. The Deputy Leader of the Opposition, the honourable member for Menzies (Mr N.A. Brown), said that he wanted to make three basic simple points. These points were simply hollow rhetoric. The Government has frankly presented full details of the economic situation to the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. It did so both in February and again yesterday. The Deputy Leader's comments are simply untrue. One wonders whether he has really read the Government's submission to the Commission. The honourable member for Menzies was really making a self-interested attempt to whip up emotion where there is no justification for doing so. He made plenty of wild claims but offered few facts and completely neglected analysis. The honourable member for Farrer (Mr Tim Fischer), who has just spoken, continued that empty rhetoric. The honourable member mentioned some other irrelevancies, some of which are worth debating some time, but not in the context of this discussion of the national wage case.

SPEECH.PARA: This is really a strange matter of public importance. What does the Opposition mean? It was hard to find any reality in what the previous Opposition speakers said. The Opposition does not seem to be taking exception to the national wage case. Of course, nor should it, for that case is part of a national incomes policy which, despite what the previous speaker said, has delivered a stable industrial relations environment. Industrial conflict has fallen to the lowest level in Australia since the late 1960s. That is profoundly important because it has contributed materially to a faster rate of economic growth and to improvements in employment and living standards during the last three years. The prices and incomes policy has also led to wage predictability and has guaranteed employees that the real value of their after-tax incomes will be maintained. It has also allowed real unit labour costs to fall to levels not seen in Australia for 15 years to the great benefit of employers. So the prices and incomes policy has worked in the interests of the whole community.

The Opposition seems to think that there is never an occasion on which wages should be increased and that very self-serving extremism makes its claim implausible. So the strategic framework for the national wage case that is being heard at present is absolutely sound and the Government's submissions also have been entirely responsible. The Government's submission in February took account of the state of the economy, the framework of the prices and incomes policy and the agreement reached between the governments and the unions in September. That agreement is very significant because, as the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations (Mr Willis) said, it involves voluntary wage restraint by unions in a way that previously has not been seen in Australia. It allows for the effects of the devaluation to be absorbed without encouraging inflation. The unions agreed not to claim full wage indexation in this early 1986 case, but to discount for the impact of devaluation on prices in return for cuts in income tax later in the year. The Government's intervention yesterday was essential. This action is conventional towards the end of every national wage case. The Government's advocate intervened because some additional data had become available. (Quorum formed) I hope that the people listening realise that calling a quorum is simply a way of cutting off debate, of stopping the facts being heard.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order. I submit that under standing order 76 all imputations of improper motives and all personal reflections--
—Order! There is no point of order.

—This is just another way of wasting time. I think the Opposition is afraid of the facts. Honourable members opposite in their own speeches could not deliver any facts; they simply spoke empty rhetoric. It is important that the facts be heard. The Government was obviously acting responsibly yesterday in again intervening in the national wage case, because it was essential to update data and to present clear analysis of the state of the economy. The Government emphasised yesterday that its submissions were broadly unchanged and that the strategy recommended to the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission in February is still the best strategy. The picture of the economy presented in February also has not changed substantially. Quite contrary to the Deputy Leader of the Opposition's comments about deceiving people, what the Government said in February and what it said yesterday were very much the same.

SPEECH.PARA: The fact of the matter is that the state of the economy is relatively healthy, that there has been substantial growth-in fact, very strong growth-in the last year. For example, private final domestic demand rose by 3 1/2 per cent last year. I emphasise that that is private final demand. From the way the Opposition is talking, it would have us believe that there was no private sector growth at all. It is trying to mislead the community. Private investment has also been growing strongly. Employment growth has been extraordinarily fast. It has grown by 4 1/2 per cent in the first 10 months of this financial year. The outlook is for continuing substantial growth and a decline in inflation.

It is true that the balance of payments current account deficit was $12 billion in the first 10 months of this financial year but there were a number of reasons for that, which were spelt out in the Government's submission yesterday. It is due in part to increases in imports but most of those increases have concerned investment goods which are used for building up the capacity for growth in the economy. There has been some decline in the value of exports. As the Treasurer (Mr Keating) has so clearly shown, the terms of trade have deteriorated quite substantially. They have deteriorated by 9 per cent in the last 12 months, and it is not possible for governments to overcome that instantaneously. However, devaluation is starting to work. Endogenous imports, that is, those imports that are directly affected by the level of economic activity, have been falling in the last three months. The depressed state of commodity exports suggests that the current account deficit is likely to remain relatively high next year, but that is why the Government has introduced a large number of important policies. For example, when the Treasurer was overseas he strongly advocated expansionary policies to other Western governments. If their economies grow faster our exports will increase in both price and volume. That will be the most important factor in getting out of the fix that the balance of payments has fallen into because of the decline in export prices.

The Government also has an active industry policy which is building up both our exports of manufactured goods and our import replacements. So the devaluation is starting to work; it is starting to improve the balance of payments and that improvement is likely to continue. There is no crisis, despite what the Opposition attempted to argue in its presentation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable gentleman's time has expired.

DEBATE.TITLE: STATES GRANTS (EDUCATION ASSISTANCE-PARTICIPATION AND EQUITY) AMENDMENT BILL 1986[COGNATE BILLS:STATES GRANTS (SCHOOLS ASSISTANCE) AMENDMENT BILL 1986STATES GRANTS (TERTIARY EDUCATION ASSISTANCE) AMENDMENT BILL 1986]

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed.

DEBATE.TITLE: STATES GRANTS (EDUCATION ASSISTANCE-PARTICIPATION AND EQUITY) AMENDMENT BILL 1986

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Snow Mr J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I get on to some of the matters in the States Grants (Education Assistance-Participation and Equity) Act 1983 I make it clear once and for all that this Government rejects unequivocally the proposition floated by the honourable member for Tangney (Mr Shack) for privatisation of education. On 2 October 1985, as reported in the Australian, he stated:

SPEECH.PARA: I am convinced that the solution-
he was talking about education problems-
lies with exposing the system to market forces . . .

This Parliament as a whole ought to reject that proposition. The honourable member for Tangney has suggested allowing universities and colleges of advanced education to offer unlimited additional places to any student who is willing to pay full fees. When will he talk about students who cannot pay full fees to CAEs and universities? He has spoken also of providing a loans scheme which such loans to be repaid from the future taxes of the working graduate. This has been tried and has failed in other countries such as the United States of America where it has been found that it is extremely difficult to get loans repaid by people once they have graduated because, naturally, they have many other commitments, such as mortgages. The system has failed. For that reason that proposition was not adopted in the United Kingdom and we can ill afford to adopt it in Australia. The honourable member for Tangney spoke about another proposition whereby vouchers would be made available to people to use as they wished for private or public education. He is reported in the Canberra Times of 30 September 1985 as having said:

. . . educational institutions should not be bound to administrative bodies and suggested as an alternative the voucher system whereby parents or, in the case of higher education, students are given an amount of money to `go shopping' for the school of their choice.

It is quite significant that Mr Robert Bluer of the Australian Teachers Federation said that the honourable member for Tangney's method of freeing up the education system is to starve it of funds and abuse academics and teachers, the vast majority of whom are dedicated, highly competent and hard working. This sort of proposal can only increase the gap between government and non-government schools. At this time expenditure on non-government schools is less than half the expenditure on government schools. The honourable member's system would make funding more or less equal for both systems. What will happen to schools such as those in the poorer areas of our metropolitan capital cities? What will happen to country primary and secondary schools which will be forced into existing on the same vouchers that the private school parents receive? If that happens, the standard of education in our government schools must drop and students will start to leave school earlier, with the result that there will be fewer skilled people in the work force and unemployment will go up. I remind the coalition that other countries are worried about not producing enough good scientists and good mathematicians from their sources-the people in their schools. This problem will only be exacerbated if the Opposition's policy is followed.

I want to dwell for a moment on the participation and equity program which relates to one of the Bills. This program aims to encourage all young people to participate in education or training at schools or at technical and further education institutions until they have completed a full, secondary education. In Eden-Monaro, the participation and equity program has been an important factor in reducing unemployment. I was present at a graduation of PEP students from the Bega TAFE which was held in Eden two years ago. It has been interesting to observe the fortunes of those students, all of whom were unemployed at the time. The courses covered personal presentation as well as skills in art, secretarial duties and the hospitality industry. The graduates were keen to get going when they completed the course, and that is what has happened. Those with whom I have made recent contact all have full time work and one is a motel manager-a person who had lost self-confidence before doing the participation and equity program and who regarded herself as chronically unemployed. So the program has offered all young people, rich or poor, equal opportunities to develop their individual talents and abilities.

I think the great thing about the program is that it has recognised that the ability to pay is not and never has been a measure of talents and abilities. It is significant that the Minister for Science (Mr Barry Jones) has frequently reminded people in Australia-it is well worth reminding them again-that when he asked leaders in Japan just what they saw as their greatest resource they did not talk about minerals, things in the ground or water, but said that people were their greatest resource. There has been a growing trend in Australia for us to ignore young people-arguably our most valuable asset-who leave school early. This was particularly and very strongly evident of young people from poorer families.

It is a measure of the success of this Government that a number of Ministers-the Minister for Education (Senator Ryan), the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations (Mr Willis), who is in the House today, the Minister for Trade and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Youth Affairs (Mr Dawkins) and a number of other Ministers--

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Science.

—These Ministers and the Minister for Science have pooled their talents and come together to present programs to government which recognise that people are our most valuable asset. It is a reflection of the unemployment and the declining economy of the late 1970s and early 1980s which hit particularly poorer families in Australia that the Government has turned the tide both in regard to unemployment and the economy through the types of measures that we have taken.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not want to omit mentioning that many other groups, apart from the poorer people, can be identified as getting less than their share of education. They include ethnic groups, females and those from rural areas. So the system had evolved to the point where only young, Anglo-Saxon, city-based males, who were from average income families, could obtain full secondary training. This was observed as a gross waste of our resources and as a recipe for future failure. The participation and equity program has been part of the Government's wide range of policies in reversing those trends and in offering equality for education. Let us increase our investment in our greatest resource-people. Let us not downgrade it. Through the legislation that we have before us today, let us upgrade the standards of education for our young people and, as a result, upgrade our economic development and employment in Australia.
Debate (on motion by Mr Everingham) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: TARIFF PROPOSALS

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jones The Hon B.O.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Excise Tariff Proposals (No. 4) 1986 and Customs Tariff Proposals (No. 6) 1986.

The proposals I have just tabled relate to proposed alterations to the Excise Tariff Act 1921 and the Customs Tariff Act 1982. Excise Tariff Proposals No. 4 (1986) and Customs Tariff Proposals No. 6 (1986) formally place before Parliament, as required by law, tariff alterations made by notices published in the Commonwealth of Australia Gazette during the recent recess. The proposals, operative on and from 17 May 1986, provide for additional duty on certain refined petroleum products resulting from the Government's decisions on the pricing of indigenous crude oil and related issues. The decision was announced by my colleague the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Gareth Evans) in a Press release of 28 April 1986. Excise Tariff Proposals No. 4 (1986) increase the excise duty on the relevant petroleum products. Excise duty on motor spirit and diesel is increased by 0.812 cents per litre. The increases for aviation gasoline and aviation kerosene are 0.684 cents per litre and 0.649 cents per litre respectively. For other kerosene, fuel oil and heating oil the increase is 0.168 cents per litre.

Customs Tariff Proposals No. 6 (1986) make complementary changes to the Customs Tariff Act in respect of duties applying to equivalent imported refined petroleum products. Summaries of the alterations contained in these proposals have been prepared and are being circulated to honourable members. I also advise honourable members that the rates of diesel fuel rebate increase in conjunction with these duty changes. The new rebate rates for currently eligible use of diesel fuel will be 19.200 cents per litre in respect of primary productions, 16.812 cents per litre for mining operations and 14.620 cents per litre for other prescribed use in residential premises, homes for aged persons, nursing homes, hospitals and other institutions providing medical or nursing care. Honourable members will note that the rebate for eligible primary production is, in fact, a 100 per cent rebate of the excise duty. The new rebate rate for eligible mining operations will also effectively mean no increase in excise duty payable. I commend the proposals to the House.
Debate (on motion by Mr Porter) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: STATES GRANTS (EDUCATION ASSISTANCE-PARTICIPATION AND EQUITY) AMENDMENT BILL 1986[COGNATE BILLS:STATES GRANTS (SCHOOLS ASSISTANCE) AMENDMENT BILL 1986STATES GRANTS (TERTIARY EDUCATION ASSISTANCE) AMENDMENT BILL 1986]

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before the debate is resumed on the States Grants (Education Assistance-Participation and Equity) Amendment Bill I remind the House that it has been agreed that a general debate be allowed covering this Bill, the States Grants (Schools Assistance) Amendment Bill and the States Grants (Tertiary Education Assistance) Amendment Bill.

DEBATE.TITLE: STATES GRANTS (EDUCATION ASSISTANCE-PARTICIPATION AND EQUITY) AMENDMENT BILL 1986

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Everingham The Hon P.A.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have certainly had an interesting debate on the States Grants (Education Assistance-Participation and Equity) Amendment Bill, the States Grants (Schools Assistance) Amendment Bill and the States Grants (Tertiary Education Assistance) Amendment Bill which are before the House today. I have listened to the contributions made by different members who obviously have divergent points of view but who all have a genuine desire to contribute constructively to what I think is one of the most critical areas to the future of our country.

SPEECH.PARA: Since these Bills deal with additional funding for all levels of education in the States and the Northern Territory, the debate provides the House with an opportunity to consider the whole question of Commonwealth responsibility for and funding of education in Australia today. I want to start by picking up on the words of two people whose experience and expertise within education matters are undoubted. What they have to say should jerk awake the proponents of big government on the other side of the House. I do not suppose it will, though, since it is apparent that this Government is determined to inflict upon Australia the costs, the wet blanket effect, and the interference and intrusion of big central government wherever it can. I understand, of course, the idealistic imperatives that drive socialist governments along this course of ever larger bureaucracy and ever greater supervision. I do not hold with them, but I do understand them.

In the area of education-the preparation of Australia's next generation of decision makers-it is vital to ensure minimal barriers to the development of free thought and initiative. Yet in a no doubt benign effort to expand and develop education in Australia and to co-ordinate that effort across the States and the Territories, the system has expanded to fulfil exactly the opposite effect. That should not come as any surprise. Educational institutions in Australia are being suffocated by an ever larger, top heavy hierarchy of bureaucracy. Individual institutions, in the name of co-ordination and centralised control, have been robbed of their independence of thought and action. They are subject to, and beholden to, Commonwealth bodies whose job is not to teach, not even to administer in the schools and colleges of the nation, but merely to supervise, co-ordinate, and generally meddle in the affairs of such institutions.

The educators and those undergoing education are, like it or not, able to carry out their work and their studies only beneath the weight of a large and multi-faceted Commonwealth bureaucracy which is suffocating the initiative and freedom of thought that ought to exist in our educational establishments. Having conformed with, or negotiated their way around, the priorities and whims of State co-ordinating bodies, school and college level educators must co-operate with a Commonwealth sectoral bureaucracy, education commissions, the Commonwealth Department of Education, the Australian Education Council and others, including a gamut of education specialists in the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet.
That situation has created increasing protest among those who must work to educate, out in the real world of face to face contact with the young people who are their charges.

Last year the Director of the West Australian Institute of Technology, Dr Donald Watts, sounded a note of warning. It would serve well the advocates of central control and big government opposite to note his words. He said that the education bureaucracy was `addicted to the game they play, committed to their own survival, and removed from the task and realities of the delivery of education'. Attacking government for its concentration on `dogma and rhetoric' Dr Watts said:
More money is wasted in control of Australian education than will ever be wasted through the errors derived from enthusiasm, freedom and enterprise.

It is clear that in Australia today those at the work face of education are being frustrated rather than assisted, hindered rather than helped, by the controlling successive levels of education administration which seek to make the rules from the top, rather than letting national education policy grow from the needs and ambitions of the people beneath its charge. It is equally clear that the first objective of any reorganisation of Australian education must be to hand back power to State governments, which are much more in touch with education priorities and those running and teaching in our institutions, and more accessible and sensitive to their needs. Education control as it is practised today is wasteful and stifling, but the tragedy is that there can be no real chance of reform while the people that cause the waste and impose the controls remain all powerful.

I said I wished to pick up on the words of two acknowledged experts in the educational area. My second source is the past Chairman of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation and well known academic, Professor Dame Leonie Kramer. She points out that the ability of universities both to serve the community and to expand the frontiers of knowledge relies on their independence. But as more and more people depend on the Commonwealth for funding, their criticism of the system is necessarily muted. To use her words:

Above all we need to improve the educational standards of young people so that they will be able to contribute in an informed way to tackling our many problems. But the fact is that who pays the piper will call the tune.

We all know who pays the piper-since the Federal Government took over the full funding of universities and tertiary institutions in the Whitlam years. At all levels in the education process-from primary to tertiary-the Commonwealth has intruded and imposed the views, ideals and policies of its top heavy bureaucratic elite. As Professor Dame Leonie Kramer has said:
There is increasing evidence of government desire to influence the direction of education, even in matters relating to research, teaching, staffing and admissions policies.

In short, we have a costly bureaucracy telling other people how to do their jobs. If we look at this education bureaucracy from another angle it may assist honourable members to realise that before the Whitlam Government got its fingers into the education pie in 1972-73, the Commonwealth Budget outlay for education was less than $450m a year. The 1985-86 forward estimate for education outlay is better than ten times that figure. It is estimated at $4,745m. The big cost increases are a result of payments to the Tertiary Education Commission programs, Schools Commission programs, student assistant programs, and such areas as the so-called participation and equity program. This has led to fairly wide agreement among education commentators, of whom I have quoted just two, that we are not getting good value from the education dollar being collected and disbursed by the Commonwealth. The money is going into funding the bureaucracy and its artificially created and imposed programs, which have much more to do with power wielding than with education delivery.

I have no doubt that these senior education industry professionals and administrators have good intentions, but their very existence diverts funds and effort from the delivery to the administration and control of education. It may seem strange, having said that, that I should follow up these remarks by seeking the appointment of a representative of the Northern Territory on the Schools Commission. However, as the old adage goes, `If you can't beat them, join them', and I will be approaching the Minister for Education (Senator Ryan) requesting such an appointment. It is a fact that every State and the Australian Capital Territory, has representation on the Schools Commission, but the Northern Territory, with its very special problems, in being excluded is suffering real disadvantage. It is an unfortunate fact of life that if one is unable to dismantle top heavy administration one had better try to influence its course.

The Territory, being the only region of Australia without representation on the Commission, and having particular, even unique, education service delivery problems to handle, must be represented on the controlling bodies. The Territory's experience of special problems and difficulties in education would be enlightening to the Commission. It might even prevent the responsible Minister from going off half-cocked, and without question, for political rather than sound educational reasons, on matters educational in the Northern Territory. I have in mind the appalling performance by the responsible Minister when she took it into her head to attack the Northern Territory on its Aboriginal education program. I do, however, thank the Minister for her subsequent retraction of those remarks in another place, but the incident demonstrates the dangers of placing perceived political advantage before the necessity for accurate information.

The Minister and the Commonwealth authorities would be forced to admit that the Northern Territory has a fine record of achievement in Aboriginal education, particularly in setting the standards for national bilingual teaching, since the Territory took on the education responsibility in 1979. Yet a willing and gullible Minister was led to believe that the Territory was selling Aboriginal students short. There is a huge irony in this chain of events because the facts are that it was the Commonwealth's cutbacks to Territory funding that created the problem. Like all Northern Territory Government areas, the Education Department was forced to reduce costs due to Commonwealth cutbacks, which meant a reduction of some 50 staff-only two of these from Aboriginal education.

The Northern Territory is already placed at a considerable disadvantage in educational funding by comparison with other States because of a number of unavoidable additional costs. These are best stated in the Commonwealth's report on the funding priorities in Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander education, produced jointly by the National Aboriginal Education Committee and the Schools Commission. That report clearly identifies the additional funding needs of the Territory in Aboriginal education. It recommended additional expenditure of $25m nationally to be devoted exclusively to Aboriginal education. But this Government, which has shown itself to be only too ready publicly to chastise any perceived shortcoming in Aboriginal education management in the Territory, has never acted upon its own report. In 1985 the Government deferred the report's recommendations, and this financial year has provided a paltry $1m for the whole country. What hypocrisy for this Government to dare to criticise, on the basis of misinformation, the Territory's performance, while pushing under the carpet the recommendations of its own advisory bodies.

That gives the lie to those high-sounding phrases about Aboriginal education which emanate from the Commonwealth Minister's office. It demonstrates the continuing lack of understanding by Commonwealth officers of the special difficulties of the Territory's responsibility in providing education for Aboriginals. That responsibility must be carried out in very special circumstances. For instance, is the Minister aware that 47 per cent of non-English speaking Aboriginals are Territorians? Is the Minister aware that there are 600 homelands or outstations in the Northern Territory, compared with about 25 in South Australia, a handful in Western Australia and none to speak of in other States? Of course it was the Commonwealth which initiated and has encouraged and continues to encourage the outstation or homeland movement. Is the Minister aware that the Territory Government is the only State level government that has the responsibility, and the experience, of providing education to urban, fringe dwelling, rural and traditionally oriented Aboriginal children? If she is, she has a duty not just to correct her totally erroneous past comments but also to provide a special level of funding to allow the Territory Government to meet its responsibility to Aboriginal education.

In short, when the Territory attempted to deal with sudden-I might even say vindictive-funding cut backs in all areas as best it could, it found itself under attack from a misinformed Minister claiming that Territory authorities had attempted to rob Aboriginal students of their educational entitlement. It is because of incidents such as this that the Northern Territory must gain representation on the Commonwealth Schools Commission. The Northern Territory Council of Government Schools Organisation has begun the lobbying necessary for Territory representation on the Commission, and I trust the Minister will give the approach a most sympathetic hearing. The Northern Territory's experience-particularly in providing education in isolated and remote communities, in fringe camp communities and among urban Aboriginals-will contribute a great deal to the work of the Commission. It might even prevent the responsible Minister from making sweeping statements for political effect and, in doing so, undermining both the morale and the excellent work record of the many dedicated people who are discharging their responsibility in Northern Territory education matters. Education, together with health, is a vital area for Aboriginal people-much more important, in my opinion, than, say, Aboriginal land rights. Without proper support and funding from the Commonwealth of Australia those Aboriginal people in the Northern Territory and elsewhere simply will not have a fair chance.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gear Mr G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I appreciate the chance to join in the debate on the States Grants (Education Assistance-Participation and Equity) Amendment Bill, the States Grants (Schools Assistance) Amendment Bill and the States Grants (Tertiary Education Assistance) Amendment Bill. Of all the portfolios in government education must rank as one of the most important, mainly because of the impact it has on our young people and on the prosperity of our nation. I have listened with great interest today to some of the debate, when I have had the chance. It seems to me that we do not need a copy of the Opposition's policy on education to figure out what it is. I believe that the Opposition, if elected, would just go back to what it did before, certainly in relation to primary and secondary education. It is fair to say that we would be hearing a lot about freedom of choice. Certainly that is not a bad principle but the Opposition should be pointing out to the Australian people that freedom of choice really only means freedom of choice to those who can afford it. Obviously if schools charge fees, that immediately knocks out a lot of people who may wish to attend those schools. Before students get into schools that charge fees their families have to be able to afford it.

SPEECH.PARA: Of course that does not stop these schools from asking taxpayers to fund them. A basic principle that we in the Australian Labor Party hold is that people should not be able to buy a better education for their children, because if they can pay money and get a better education for their children than somebody else there is something wrong with the system. Education then becomes a vehicle for ingraining inequity. Obviously the people who have more money can afford to send their children to private schools to get the so-called better education, and the results are cumulative and not offsetting.

The policy of the former Government can be measured by the amount of money it spent on government and non-government schools. I am talking only about the Commonwealth Government now. I realise that we should also consider State governments, but we are talking now about Federal spending. A comparison of the figures on money spent in the government and non-government sectors in the period of the Fraser Government gives a clear indication of where the Opposition would spend its money. For instance, in 1977 there was a real increase of 2.3 per cent in funding for government schools, compared to an increase of 4.4 per cent for non-government schools. Moving along, the picture does not change a great deal. Possibly 1980 was the worst year: There was a cut in real terms of 10.6 per cent for government schools and an increase of 6.3 per cent for non-government schools. In 1982 there was a real cut of 1.2 per cent for government schools and a real increase of 16.6 per cent for non-government schools. Those figures just go to illustrate where the Opposition's priorities lie.

If we look at the previous Government's policy at that time we see the crazy situation of approval for the establishment of non-government schools being given by State governments yet the majority of funding for those schools being provided by the Commonwealth Government. It was a great open cheque for the States to make big fellows of themselves and say that private schools could be constructed, whether they were needed or not, and then just pass on the bill to the Commonwealth. That stopped as soon as we came to power. We recognised that in any planning for education on a government and non-government basis there must be some rationale. We cannot have a glut of schools in one area and an open door policy for new non-government schools to open their doors virtually wherever they want to. I believe the policy we have now, of looking at the applications for non-government schools on the basis of need, particularly in newer suburbs, is the correct one from both a fiscal and an educational point of view because, as I have said before, if we have too many schools in one area we have a lot of small units not operating in an efficient manner.

One Opposition member-I cannot remember who-touched on a very important point, with which I agree. A lot of the education that children receive is out of school-that is, it is provided through their parents and peers. Certainly this out of school education is important because it sets the whole tone for the advancement of any kid through school. It goes without saying that kids in higher socio-economic areas do very much better, because of that, than do kids from lower socio-economic areas, and particularly migrants. It is because of this that a report of the Commonwealth Schools Commission entitled `Quality and Equality' stated in recommendation 18:
That the Basic Learning in Primary Schools Program-
otherwise known as BLIPS-
be continued as a specific purpose program until the end of 1987, and that the activities presently proposed by education authorities for this period continue.

I know that we are trying in that area to overcome some of the deficiencies that children from those poorer areas, including migrant children, suffer because of where they live. I think that the Minister for Science (Mr Barry Jones) expressed it quite succinctly. He said he could forecast the future advancement of a child not by his intelligence or the like; all he had to do was look at the postcode. It is easy to see that what the Minister for Science was saying is quite true. The policy of the present Government, in ensuring that funds from this Government are targeted in areas where they are needed, is the correct one and I reject totally some of the accusations made by the Opposition that what we are really trying to do is strangle the non-government sector and promote the government sector. We are trying to get some rationality back into the system and not have that crazy system we had before whereby the States approved non-government schools so that they could make the announcement and then passed the bill to the Government.

Of particular importance to the education debate is higher education. It is again plain to see where the priorities of the former Government lay. We have heard a lot about proposed voucher systems and proposed ways of getting more people into higher education, and I agree with Opposition spokesmen that we should be getting more people into higher education. It is an absolute tragedy that not enough people are getting into higher education. The present policy we have of fully funding tertiary institutions was adopted and followed by the former Government, under Mr Fraser. A look at the priorities he attached to that policy, by way of the amount of money he spent on higher education, is illuminating. In 1976, his first full year, Mr Fraser cut the amount by 3.5 per cent; in 1977, the lead-up to the election as we all remember, he increased it by 3.1 per cent. In 1978 there was a drop in real terms of 0.6 per cent; in the following year there was again a drop of 1.2 per cent; in 1980 there was yet another drop of 1.2 per cent; in 1981 yet another drop of 1.4 per cent; in 1982, another drop of 0.7 per cent. The figure did not rise again until this Government came to power in 1983, when there was a rise of 0.6 per cent, in 1984 one per cent; in 1985 we have increased the figure by 2.9 per cent; in 1986 by 1.9 per cent; and the prospect for 1987 is a real increase of 1.3 per cent. One can see that the priorities attached by the Fraser Government to higher education were reflected in funding. That Government cut funding at a time when this country needed more people in our higher education system.

In talking of higher education, one should not forget that a lot of people never go on to higher education, or on to the technical and further education system or into apprenticeships. They are the people who up until now have been neglected. They are the people who do not come out as tradesmen or technicians but who, by and large, make up the bulk of our unemployed, particularly the young unemployed. It is to those people that this Government has addressed a lot of attention since we were elected.

When the Government took office it asked a committee of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development to come out to Australia to review youth policy, to recommend to government ways in which we could enhance the prospects of our young people gaining jobs and meaningful employment. Parallel with that committee, the Government also set up a committee within Australia headed by Mr Peter Kirby, the Director of the Technical and Further Education Division in Victoria. Both reports were presented to government, and as a member of the Caucus education committee I know that we spent a lot of time examining those two reports and compiling many of the recommendations that they contained into what has now become known as the traineeship system under Priority One. It is a very adventurous system of which we shall see the fruits in years to come. Certainly there are obstacles to overcome within the trade union movement, within the TAFE system and other agencies which will deliver the training necessary for these young people in areas where training has not been given before.

Once we have overcome those problems, such as the wages and conditions under which our young people will fit into these traineeship systems, I believe that it will be one of the great innovations of the Hawke Government. That stands in stark contrast to what the Opposition is claiming as the answer to youth unemployment-that is, to cut their wages, give them the dole but two days' work to go with it. All those crazy systems have never worked and will never work.

I conclude by saying that I believe the education system in this country is one of the most important areas of government expenditure. I have expressed my support for the Government's endeavours in this field, and I know that the Caucus education committee, and also the education committees of the Australian Labor Party, will play a significant role in making sure that we advance education consistent with the policies I outlined earlier.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McVeigh The Hon D.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —Because of some woolly thinking that seems to permeate some members of the Government, I wish to place on record my personal philosophical approach to education. Put simply, it is that the parent has the prior responsibility for deciding what type of education his or her child shall or shall not receive, and in return it is not unreasonable for that parent, as a taxpayer and citizen, to expect to receive some government contribution consistent with the amount of money government would be ploughing into the government education system. It is wrong for people to criticise a government for acknowledging the right and responsibility of the parent and standing up for the prior right of the child, rather than the Government usurping that role by contributing to the input through financing the cost of private education. It is wrong that people should be criticising the dual approach to education and trying to create an environment in which the Government will take over and condition the type of education that a child shall or shall not receive.

SPEECH.PARA: The basis for education is the never ending search for excellence. The acceptance of mediocrity as a safe but stultifying state of existence should be totally rejected. It is from this premise I address the States Grants (Education Assistance -Participation and Equity) Amendment Bill, the States Grants (Tertiary Education Assistance) Amendment Bill and the States Grants (Schools Assistance) Amendment Bill. The pursuit of excellence is a philosophy instilled into each and every one of us from the time we enter the classroom. Our teachers are given the shared responsibility to create the future and give it direction by offering students a set of values with which to assess their newly discovered knowledge. They are called to bring professional competence and a high standard of excellence to teaching. For it is through them that students must come to see and know the richness and joy of life, and formulate a response to the challenging demands of existence.

To teach means not only to impart what is known, but also to reveal who we are by living what we believe. It is this latter lesson which tends to last the longest. The value of education can never be underestimated. It is the centrepoint from which we view life, ourselves and others. Without education, life is made more difficult because the learning experience must be made alone, without the benefit of one who accepts the mantle of an educator. Since the beginning of history the value of education has been recognised; it is something which has not been lost with time.

However, in these changing times, education for some is viewed as an ordeal which one must get through before being able to join the ranks of the employed or, as in some cases, the unemployed. For others, education is seen as the key which opens doors and broadens the scope of opportunities for the future. This group knows the value of the learning experience and embraces its challenges. These are our future leaders, industrialists and union spokesmen. The need for good leadership has never been greater or more urgent in Australia. We are poised on the precipice of new technologies, new frontiers and new challenges never placed before us as a nation.

The education system is not the sole agency responsible for preparing our youth for the twenty-first century, but merely one facet of the total. Others which should and must be involved include the church, community organisations, business firms, trade unions and the family in encouraging our graduates to exercise leadership. In order to fuse all of these agencies we need to take seriously our regional education systems throughout Australia. For it is at the regional level all interested parties can come together and work towards attaining our goals.

Regional colleges have a specific function-to serve their region. Their brief is to provide high quality education, extend educational and occupational opportunities and encourage community participation in education. Regional needs and interests are quite different from those of cities, yet they still provide diversity, complexity and opportunities in the education provided. They seek not only to train graduates to carry out jobs currently identifiable, but to prepare them adequately for important roles in the continuing development of our society and our nation.

Higher education develops an ability to perceive relationships which afford understandings in many contexts, not only those presently known but also those yet to occur. Creative intellectual skills are mastered when students discover new contexts in which to apply their understanding and perceive a familiar pattern in unfamiliar events. At the same time, education provides students with the opportunity to develop their ability to communicate effectively, to understand, value and believe in our and other societies' social history and a keen awareness of what is happening now in the twentieth century.
All institutions of learning have a common goal-to preserve, expand and transmit knowledge. At the same time they achieve understanding and develop a vision of what is best to do with this knowledge.

That gets me back to the theme of this speech-the pursuit of excellence, the rejection of mediocrity. We will never develop our potential as a nation if we do not develop our people. The fate of Australia rests firmly on the shoulders of our young, and their fate is determined by the education they receive and how they can apply it to their understanding of their work and position in life. We have only one viable long term resource in our favour which will not run out, which is self-generating and which can adapt to any situation. That resource is our people, especially our young people, for in them our future is sealed as a member of the community of nations. We must nurture and care for them, like any resource, as precious objects, encourage them to make the most of their time in school and inspire them to continue the learning process. It is my belief that this is best done on a regional basis, for it affords all students the opportunity to remain in the close proximity of their homes, families and friends at the same time as they are studying. The support of the familiar will encourage the student to complete his or her studies and then make a valuable contribution to the community, the State and the nation.

My home State of Queensland has made significant progress over recent years in retaining the highest percentage of year 12 students in school. Over 53 per cent of our high school students complete their final year. Consequently, the demand for higher education has never been so high. However, the positions available for them to continue their studies are not keeping pace with this demand.

It has been estimated by the Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission, an independent Commission, that 3,000 additional positions at colleges of advanced education, technical and further education colleges and universities are needed in Queensland so students will be able to continue their education. The Minister for Education (Senator Ryan) in the other place has made some progress towards redeeming this situation, but unfortunately there is still a long way to go. Demand still outstrips supply and, until we see a significant change in opportunities available for our potential students, Queensland will continue to be disadvantaged when compared to other States.

The United States of America has come to terms with the concept of continuing education for everyone interested in keeping up with the current trends and demands for new skills. Predictions are being made that by 1990 most American adults will be working a 32 hour week and when not at work will be preparing for their next job. While the adult working week will be shorter, the student school week will become longer. Schools will be providing services to the community, to business and to young students who will use the recreation facilities, computer labs and job simulation stations. Job simulation stations are modules which combine computers, video discs and instrumentation to duplicate job or work environments.

It seems to me that Australia tends to follow American trends, and I can see the same situation occurring here. Therefore, it is vital for our young people and mature age citizens to be given opportunities to further their education. We need to broaden our education system so the system can cope with the expansion of subject matter and market-place demands of the future. Curricula need to be devised which will seize and retain the interest of many students whom the present curriculum does not cover. Teaching methods may have to become more individualistic and co-operative; changes in school atmosphere may have to be made in order to encourage students to remain in school longer; and structures may have to be created which are not school-like but more relevant to society outside the classroom. It is important that we consider these changes if we are to keep our young people in school and at the same time prepare them for a different lifestyle in the twenty-first century.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wright Mr K.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome the Government's initiatives in the grant arrangements that we have with the States. Like the honourable member for Groom (Mr McVeigh), I express some concern as to the participation in higher education in Queensland. I will make some further comments about that. I believe this Government deserves commendation. It deserves the congratulations of the people of Queensland and, for that matter Australia, for the way it has adopted a very broad policy and, I think, a very positive philosophy of education in Queensland. It has understood that young people are our most important resource and we need to cultivate and care for them. I am also very pleased that the Labor Government has realised that our philosophy in education should be one not just of preparing young people for a university education, but of preparing young people for life.

SPEECH.PARA: I have noticed as I have travelled around my electorate and other parts of Queensland how young people now work within a different school environment as we involve their skills in the participation and equity program. I note also that the non-government schools, the Catholic schools in particular, are most commendatory about this Government's attitude in giving a lead in solving many of their complaints about funding. It has given certainty to those non-government schools, and we have done it legislatively. I am most pleased with what is taking place.

Whilst I give credit where credit is due, I believe there is an aspect that is being forgotten or overlooked. I refer to the cost of education for people who just do not have the privilege of living in the capital cities or provincial cities; in other words, in areas where there are education facilities. Recently I met with a group of people in a small township called St Lawrence. I also met with people in another small township in central Queensland called Marlborough. I am trying to bring together the human and political resources of that area to convince the powers that be that there is a need for a different approach to people who live miles and miles from the populated areas. In my opinion, there is a need for a new recognition of the problem of rural Australia as it relates not just to tertiary and higher education and to adult education, but even to ordinary secondary education.

I use this opportunity to call on the Federal Government to review the present tax deductions available to people in rural Australia. There is a need also for a review of the distance factor. Young people living in St Lawrence and wishing to get a secondary education in the town of Sarina travel for 2 1/4 hours and make three different changes in buses. Again those south of St Lawrence who travel to Rockhampton travel enormous distances. Travelling 2 1/4 hours in a bus to go to school not only is a huge physical burden but also deprives young people of the many advantages that others take for granted in high schools, such as playing in sporting teams and taking part in cultural pursuits. But this does not happen for many young people in our small townships. We need to have a hard look at what is taking place.

The correspondence system works. That is okay for parents involved in primary school teaching. It is all right for parents to help their children in primary school, but it is a different kettle of fish when parents are trying to help young people who are undertaking high school subjects. In Queensland, as in other parts of Australia, we have a back-up tutor system under which the principal of the local primary school will give that support or, in some cases, education officers will move around. But it is very difficult to undertake a correspondence course at high school level. Admittedly, there is a need for the State Government to accept its responsibility to decentralise further the education facilities of Queensland and supply more high tops. But much of the task stays with this Government, and we cannot walk away from that. It is my personal view that it is ridiculous these days to have a tax deduction of $250 for the education of a student. That nowhere near covers the costs of educating a young person today, particularly at high school, but more so if one is living outside the populated areas.

I commend the Government for the special opportunities that it has given to the Aboriginal and Islander community of Australia. I welcome this because these people were being deprived, but I suggest to this Parliament that many low income whites and poor whites also need sensitive consideration. Just as we are making places available in our residential high schools for Aboriginal and Islander children so that they can go, say, to Rockhampton from the outskirts of the central Queensland region and live in these high schools we need to understand that the same types of financial, social and educational problems that the black community faced are now being faced by many low income and poor whites. We need to redress that situation; we need to address the problems.

Families in the small towns need special assistance. So I take this opportunity to call for a review of the tax advantages or, should I say, the tax disadvantages. I spoke recently with some people living in the townships. I stress that I am not talking about wealthy farmers; I am talking about the ordinary people who live in our towns. They estimated that if they wanted to send a young person to a high school away from town it could cost $4,000 to $5,000 a year. That expense is not allowed as a tax deduction. There is a need for a new approach and for the children of those low income families to be given special places in our residential secondary schools. I am sure that this would be a low cost measure. An approach could be made to the various residential colleges throughout Queensland and the rest of Australia and find out how many spare places exist. We could suggest to the school administrations that a number of places be made available in each school and that they would be paid for by the Commonwealth. I think we also need to review the education allowances to help these people meet other costs. It may well be that residential colleges cannot cope with the numbers. If families were given some support-some sort of financial backup-the costs of a young person staying in the town could be met. This Government has introduced a special accommodation program. (Quorum formed).

Before I was rudely interrupted and the attempt was made to stop me from speaking, I was making a number of comments about the problems facing people in country areas and in the small towns. For the benefit of those who listen to these debates it is probably important to note that members of parliament have many other duties and they cannot always be sitting in this chamber listening to speakers. We on the Government side are very heavily involved in committee duties. We work many long hours. Unlike the members of the National Party and the Liberal Party who do nothing except sit in the bar or play billiards all day long the Government members work hard. I think it is about time that some honourable members opposite came into the House to listen to some relevant comments that affect their areas.

Getting back to the comments I was making, I stress the fact that while I support the very important initiatives that have been taken by this Government in raising the educational opportunities of the Aboriginal and Islander people there is a need for a recognition that many low income whites and very poor whites need the same types of advantages. I am calling for a different approach at a secondary level. This Government could, with the help and co-operation of State governments, make available the necessary moneys to provide places in the residential secondary schools to allow young people disadvantaged by distance and the cost involved to get a secondary education.

The honourable member for Groom mentioned that he had some figures which showed that some 53 per cent of young Queenslanders were able to finish their secondary education. My figures show that in Queensland only something like 43 or 44 per cent of those between the ages of 15 and 19 are still at school. That is a very small percentage compared with America, where the average is about 74 per cent and with Japan, where the figure is about the same. I think we match only Ireland when it comes to the low numbers of students between the ages of 15 and 19 still at high school and availing themselves of educational opportunities.

There is a desperate need to recognise the special problems of people in country areas-people who live some distance from education facilities. There is a need to carry out some type of in-depth study of people in country areas. I believe that there is a need for a special study on country town education. When carrying out these studies, we need to have a hard look at the present zone allowances because so many of these problems could be overcome if there was financial backup and assistance. Some time ago in this House I suggested that there was a need for a different zone allowance. Instead of introducing all types of assistance programs, if we were to review the zone allowances throughout Australia and link them to local government and also allow for a distance factor I believe that we could overcome many of these problems. However, it is simply ridiculous to ask a person in a country town to meet the cost-some $4,000 or $5,000-to send a student to high school. People simply cannot meet that cost. When one realises that many families will be faced with an ongoing problem in that they will have two or more children, the costs become very burdensome. We have a responsibility as a Federal Government to try to overcome those problems. I hope that as we consider and recognise the difficulties of the poor whites, the low income whites, the middle income whites and, in fact, anyone living in the small towns and also on the cattle properties and in rural areas, we will start to appreciate that there is a need for a different approach when it comes to costs.

I was told recently about some of the problems that young people have in the employment area. I recognise what this Government is doing with its Priority One program, but most of the problems come back to rural and country Australia. That is where there is the lowest participation in education of students between the ages of 15 and 19. That is where there is the worst job opportunities. Because of the high cost of living that is where the greatest problems exist when it comes to family income. We probably need to say over and over again to those who live in the cities that there is a great difference between spending an income of $23,000 in Brisbane or Sydney and spending the same sort of money in Mount Isa or in far western Queensland.

There is a need for this Parliament to review these cost factors. I am very much aware of what the Government has been doing. As I said before, I commend the Government for giving certainty to non-government schools and for writing into legislation the financial assistance available to non-government and Catholic schools. I appreciate what has been done with regard to the participation and equity program. I am very much aware of the expansion in the amount of technical and further education moneys given to the States. Even though the States get the credit this Government has been giving them money and making sure that they have a financial backup. But when it comes to country people I still think they are missing out. When it comes to small towns, again, those in small towns are suffering. So I reiterate my call that there is a need for a special study of country town education. There is a need to review the present tax advantages. There is a need to rethink through the system of assistance that is given to people who live in those areas so that their children can go and live in the residential secondary schools and get a decent education.

TALK.START.PARA: —Joh does not care about education in Queensland.

—The Premier of Queensland does not care. The other day, I read a very interesting speech by the Queensland Leader of the Opposition, Nev Warburton, in which he simply outlines the economic ills of the State. He outlined very clearly the fact that Queensland was spending less than any other State of the Commonwealth on education, welfare, police, health and all these matters. The Premier, Mr Bjelke-Petersen, said that that was untrue. I was most pleased to note that only the other day a very senior member of the National Party of Australia by the name of Sir Roderick Proctor, said how badly Queensland was performing. I only hope now that those in the National Party who really care about people will start talking about the lack of expenditure in Queensland on health, welfare and education. Obviously, only when there is recognition by the Government of the day of the problems do things get done. Only when the National Party in Queensland-which still holds power there and which I hope will not be in power for much longer-realises that the people are suffering will something be done. It is not just a political question. It is not just a matter of scoring on the Australian Labor Party Opposition in Queensland. It is a matter of the suffering of people. That is what has to be brought home to the people in Queensland, the voters of Queensland.

SPEECH.PARA: Last election the Australian Labor Party missed out by only some 9,866 votes out of 1.5 million. It was not very many votes.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not next time.

—However, we want to improve that, so that this time round we can get some decent government in that State-a government that really cares about people. May I say to the honourable member for Griffith (Mr Humphreys), who made that very worthwhile interjection, that the thing that concerns me about Queensland is that the National Party Government of that State, a Party which is said to be country orientated, has given up the country people. The Ministers in that Government are the people who when one writes away about a high top in Queensland provide no answer. If one asks about improving the health facilities in country towns in Queensland one gets no answer or one gets a no from those people. It is that Government which has just taken away the speech therapist from the highlands of central Queensland. It is that Government that has removed a number of specialist teachers in those areas, teachers who are vitally important to maintain education standards. That National Party Government really does not care, and that is a great pity. Because of that, because the Queensland Government is not doing anything, we cannot say that we should do nothing. We therefore have to carry a greater burden as a Federal government.

SPEECH.PARA: We need to realise that country people have great burdens to carry, burdens that are social, cultural and educational. It is up to this Government to understand that. Just as we have recognised that problems exist in so many other fields we need to recognise that problems exist for country people. I make this plea because I meet with these people in the country. I see the dilemmas they face, so I can come to this House and make a plea that we, as a government, should. We as a government must review the education deductions. We must try to give financial assistance to bridge the gap that is preventing many hundreds of young Queenslanders and other Australians from getting a decent education. The Queensland Government obviously does not care. The Queensland Government will do nothing about it. It is up to the Federal Government to act if the quality of life for those young Queenslanders is going to be changed and upgraded.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rocher Mr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The States Grants (Education Assistance-Participation and Equity) Amendment Bill, the States Grants (Schools Assistance) Amendment Bill and the States Grants (Tertiary Education Assistance) Amendment Bill allocate additional funds to important areas of Australian education. In a sense each of these Bills represents machinery measures which seek to supplement funds already committed in line with the Government's earlier undertakings and commitments. The amounts involved range from $823,000 in both 1986 and 1987 for the participation and equity program through to $23m in 1986, $10m in 1987 and $11m in 1988 for the schools assistance package and something like $98.43m, spread over 1986 and 1987, for the tertiary and technical and further education sectors.

SPEECH.PARA: Introduced in 1984, the participation and equity program has led a short, colourful and, one might say, controversial life. PEP subsumed the school to work transition program, a project with a clearly defined, if more limited, educational purpose. School to work focused on special programs to assist secondary students thought to have limited prospects in the market-place. In contrast, the participation and equity program focuses, in the words of a December 1985 Schools Commission report, `on the total education program and on reform of the school curriculum in order to increase student retention and participation rates and to improve the quality of schooling'. It will be appreciated that the Schools Commission 1983 paper entitled `Participation and Equality in Australian Schools' argued that our aim ought to be `a rise in participation that reflects a stronger commitment to learning by the whole age group'. It went on to recommend:
. . . schools should recognise and respond to the different ways young people learn.

Taken at face value, the key words and phrases in the 1983 Schools Commission report would, I believe, enjoy the support of most in the community.
