Unfortunately, when one comes to examine in detail just what is meant by the Schools Commission's 1985 statement `reform of the school curriculum in order to increase student retention and participation rates and to improve the quality of schooling', serious reservations must be expressed. Learning as it is generally and, I might say, correctly understood in the community at large has apparently taken on some new and rather odd meanings lately. Geoffrey Partington, senior lecturer in education at Flinders University, writing in 1985 said of the participation and equity program:
. . . concentrates into one powerfully funded package a range of previously separate brands of educational nonsense.

Far from trying to engage more students in the serious and useful pursuit of knowledge, PEP has aimed to improve retention rates in Australian schools by offering students what are, in practical terms, often-far too often-nothing more than childish alternatives to education. Instead of raising the level of the student to the level of the curriculum, we are in the process of lowering the curriculum to the level of the student. When we come to examine PEP we find that women's studies are as valuable as chemistry and media studies compare favourably with literature, that community action has a validity as great as physics. Plainly, that is nonsense. Should I be thought unduly partisan in these remarks, let me quote the view of Mr Bill Hannan, former adviser to the Minister for Education (Senator Ryan) and, at the time he expressed this view in January 1985, a ministerial appointee to the Curriculum Development Council and editor of the publication the Australian Teacher. In discussing accreditation and curriculum issues in Australian schools he argued:
. . . we first need to recognise that studies in various fields-pure science, applied science, arts, crafts and humanities-can all be equally demanding and equally useful.

That was the sort of advice the Minister was getting. It will be recalled that one aim of PEP is to increase the retention rates of older students in Australian schools. I understand that the figure is around 40 per cent in Australia while in the United States of America it is around 85 per cent. To get somewhere near the American figure would be an admirable target, but participation statistics are only part of the story. When one comes to look at the curriculum one finds that 25 per cent of students in United States high schools-here I am relying on the research of Professor Richard Powers, head of the History Department at the University of Massachusetts-obtain credits in physical and health education, work experience outside the school, remedial subjects and personal development courses such as training for adulthood and marriage. They are all worthwhile topics. They are all worthwhile subjects. However, I wonder whether they ought to attract academic credits for high school diplomas.

This question arises particularly when one considers the testimony of college academics and administrators in the United States of America, who claim that many undergraduate students after 12 years of so-called progressive education are unable to speak or write correctly or coherently; few are able to read more than the simplest prose; a large majority have never heard of the Enlightenment, the Reformation or the French Revolution; they know nothing of the deterioration of Athens or Rome, of Czarist Russia and Weimar Germany, and next to nothing of the history of technology, industry, labour, fascism and Stalinism, or of how we found ourselves in two world wars or even in Vietnam. Almost none can as much as identify Jane Austen, Dickens, Walter Scott, Milton, Blake or Shelley. That is the testimony of US academics. We need to be careful before adopting educational curricula and accreditation policies from abroad that leave students with almost nothing really relevant to them as intelligent human beings or as Australian citizens.

This brings me to the wider issue of education policy under this Labor Government-an appropriate subject as we consider the expenditure of funds on schools and the tertiary and technical and further education sectors. Speaking in the context of both the States Grants (Education Assistance-Participation and Equity) Amendment Bill and the States Grants (Schools Assistance) Amendment Bill, I must express my very real concern about the quality of education that Australia's youth is receiving. In support of that I refer to a quote from Robert Gottliebsen, Managing Editor of Business Review Weekly, who wrote in January 1985:
Australia's educators are failing to meet the challenge of equipping our future workforce for a changing world.
Along the same lines, in 1984 Senator John Button acknowledged in an address to the Victorian Economic Society:
Australia has been very badly served by its education system . . . How can we become competitive given the quite inadequate performance of this important sector?

Both Gottliebsen and Senator Button were acknowledging that both now and even more so in the future Australia will need to compete with work forces and skills in other countries in a competitive environment at a level never before experienced. Yet when faced with the testimony of some Cabinet Ministers, respected senior journalists, concerned educationalists, employers who complain that many job applicants are virtually unemployable, and university academics, who can spend hours providing example after example of major inadequacies in the most basic skills amongst first year students, the response from the educationalists who advance the theories and administered the policies which have accompanied the problems of our schools, is to insist that the practical meaning of all this evidence and opinion is a mystery beyond understanding because the possible reasons for these problems are `so many and so uncertain'.

As well, there are those who claim, in the words of one education `expert' at the Canberra College of Advanced Education, that `there is no decline'. That sort of assertion is made despite the fact that, in the words of the same individual, `we often hear that some child cannot read or write well, that some academic received a wretchedly written essay or that some applicant for a job did not perform as well in a test or at an interview as some past applicants'. That is how those claims are dismissed. We are told that this is all irrelevant to the argument. Apparently employers, parents and academics are all wrong. Yet the facts suggest otherwise. P. P. McGuinness, a former adviser to the Whitlam Government and, at the time he made these comments, Editor-in-Chief of the Australian Financial Review, noted in June 1984:
There is sufficient pent up dissatisfaction with the Government's system to make education reform long overdue.

A perfect illustration of what is wrong with Australian education was the decade long saga and eventual emasculation and abandonment of the idea of comprehensive surveys of school standards. The full details are contained in a fascinating paper by Andrew Parkin in the journal Politics, of November 1984. Suffice it to say that this unedifying story demonstrates the determination of the teachers unions and the educational bureaucrats to stifle meaningful independent research into education standards. When the Australian Education Council eventually announced in 1983 that its national testing program would end, the Australian Financial Review editorial said:
The radical chalkies have had yet another victory over common sense.

The decision amazed visiting American educationalist, Dr Michael Kirst of Stanford University, who said he was astounded to see Australian newspapers resorting to extrapolating from American sources when commenting on standards in Australian schools. One important reform would be the return of meaningful national testing of educational standards.
While the Americans are setting about repairing years of educational foolishness, our Commonwealth Schools Commission grandly informs us on page 14 of its 1985 report entitled `Quality and Equality':

The Commission has viewed with interest the way in which the particular genre of reports typified by the report of the US National Commission on Excellence in Education, `A Nation at Risk' has been questioned by commentators with respect to the view of excellence put forward.

Another good read is J. L. Goodlad's `A Place called School', which is recommended to set us all right about what the Commission calls `the dangers of taking a too instrumental approach to schooling'. The Commission goes on to note that measures recommended in `A Nation at Risk' tend to ignore `significant cultural and personal goals in education'. Presumably an `instrumental' approach would put women's, peace, media and community action programs at risk. This would, of course, be in direct conflict with the philosophy of a Minister for Education whose program is the embodiment of almost every odd enthusiasm of Australia's trendy Left educational establishment.

Far too often these topics are the soft options that emphasise process and explanation rather than fact. All too often they lead to uninformed views and prejudices going unchallenged. This so-called progressive hegemony has brought in its wake `values clarification' for students which invades their privacy and assumes adult level maturity. At the least such nonsense imposes a relativistic view of moral values; at worst it strongly influences students in values contrary to those prevailing in the home or community.

The school's role is to foster habits of intelligent methodological inquiry, and this requires the basic disciplines of literacy and numeracy. Indeed, one of the supposed aims of much so-called progressive educational reform-that of assisting economically disadvantaged students-in fact further disadvantages them. Many educationalists have pointed out that these students more than any others gain from a properly structured learning environment. Education is devalued when the curriculum is stripped of its content and when skills free of any cultural, literary or historical context are all that is taught. Students must be given accurate focal points from which to view the world. These must be of the right kind. They need to stress integrity, duty, compassion, discipline, respect for other's rights and the courage of individual convictions and intelligent patriotism.

Effective education does not require a narrow approach. We need to cover both the basic skill subjects such as English, including spelling, mathematics, science and computers, and broader subjects such as history, geography and at least one language plus arts and music. A proper curriculum, an interested, active and professional faculty and effective discipline are all vital. It is important to remember that a genuine equality of opportunity is often most strongly present when real standards are enforced.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McGauran Mr P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is undeniable that the Australian education system is beset by problems at different levels. However neither time nor, I suspect, your tolerance pursuant to Standing Orders, Mr Deputy Speaker, will allow me to canvass all those issues this afternoon. Instead, I shall concentrate upon the problems besetting the colleges of advanced education and other tertiary institutions in country areas. One of the most outstanding failures of this Government has been its failure to properly care for the colleges of advanced education in rural areas. It is impossible to overstate the importance of these institutions, not just to those country students attending them but also to the rest of the community, for the role they play and the influence they assert in heightening the awareness of all the different aspects within that community.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me give an example of an institute which is just outside the border of my electorate of Gippsland, but which is certainly attended by a great many students who come under my specific responsibility. I refer to the Gippsland Institute of Advanced Education at Churchill. It has a very important role to play in cataloguing and promoting Gippsland history and also the different industries of Gippsland, as well as establishing what is called the Gippsland bank of statistics and information, which is a very valuable reference point for a number of different industries, individuals and secondary schools. Yet the Gippsland Institute of Advanced Education, like so many others in rural Australia, faces an uncertain future because of drastic reductions in funding. This Government should realise that its responsibilities to higher education lie not only in urban areas, but also in rural areas where institutions such as the Gippsland Institute take on what is probably a far more important role in the community than that which is played by their urban counterparts.

The Gippsland Institute of Advanced Education performs a number of very important works throughout Gippsland, but none more important than the fact that it is a local place of higher learning for Gippslanders. A number of Gippslanders simply cannot afford or, perhaps for other reasons of which there are too many canvass, do not wish or are not able to attend, Melbourne tertiary institutions. The Gippsland Institute, therefore, is, if one likes, not just a home-based college, but an essential and much relied upon institution of learning. I was interested to receive correspondence recently from Mr Peter Farago on behalf of the Politics/History Teaching Team, seeking my support for the establishment, via the Victorian Post-Secondary Education Commission, of a course of study in politics-history. That is further evidence of the growth in maturity of this institution. I certainly wish that to be a successful application, as I know that the school of Social Sciences needs to offer a major in history and politics in its Bachelor of Arts course so that it will be given the same sort of weight which is given to universities in the capital cities.

These rural institutions of higher learning also play a crucial role in tackling what is a subject which is neglected by this Government-rural youth unemployment. I have received a great deal of correspondence over several months from the Rural Development Centre of the University of New England in Armidale, New South Wales, which is headed by, among others, Mr Scott Williams. Mr Williams has done a great deal of collating of information from various sources on an analysis of rural youth unemployment. He is certainly to be congratulated for his work. Together with him is Mr Geoff Harris and Mr Vitols who have also done extensive research on the extent of youth unemployment and its effect on individuals and their communities.

Such an approach by the Rural Development Centre stands in marked contrast to that of the Government. Mr Deputy Speaker, you would be aware that a number of Opposition members have called for a proper survey of rural youth unemployment to be undertaken without any further delay. Youth, who are always the main sufferers in an economic downturn, in the country have added difficulties because they are beyond the limelight of the Press and, in some instances, their own political representation. In my electorate youth unemployment is a staggering 26 per cent. Figures from the six Commonwealth Employment Service offices situated in my electorate and that of the honourable member for McMillan (Mr Cunningham), show that 2,110 teenagers are seeking work. So between the towns of Warragul and Orbost, a staggering 2,132 teenagers out of a total of 8,100 are seeking work. Such a figure paints an alarming and gloomy picture for the future of these teenagers. It is incumbent on the Government to understand the nature of the problem by way of, I believe, an extensive survey because we are lacking in knowledge of the causes and effects of youth unemployment in country areas.

The cutback in participation and equity funding has had a drastic effect on a number of youth unemployment schemes, not just in the electorate of Gippsland, but in other parts of Australia. The problem in regard to the 50 per cent cutback 12 months ago is that it was across the board. Why is it that this Government is incapable of distinguishing between good and bad projects when reducing funding? A number of worthwhile youth unemployment schemes are about to close or have closed. There may well have been wastage in PEP. Indeed, we know that there has been wastage in the secondary school sector of that funding program. But the fact remains that the technical and further education component of PEP was in many cases extremely valuable. To take one example, I refer to the youth unemployment project centred in Leongatha in my electorate and headed by Mr Michael McInerny. I have visited that project to see firsthand its operations. It goes under the title of affirmative action program for unemployed youths. The simple fact is that because of the cutback in funding to the TAFE supervision of these programs, a number of young unemployed in south Gippsland will have absolutely no assistance to prepare them, firstly, to obtain a job and, secondly, to retain it. In other words, the young unemployed in south Gippsland are left high and dry. The project is expected to close in June unless funding is forthcoming.

Mr Michael McInerny is only too pleased to provide a detailed submission, as he has to me, to anybody who questions the worth or effectiveness of his program. Certainly, the figures of those who have passed through the program and who have then obtained employment are very impressive. For instance, of the 39 people who attended the program last year, 70 per cent have found work-with Mr McInerny's assistance. It is incumbent upon the Government in its rationalisation, for want of a better word, of funding for educational projects to differentiate between those that are worth while and those that are, as the honourable member for Curtin (Mr Rocher) highlighted, an absolute waste of taxpayers' funds. I believe that this program in south Gippsland has been successful. It assisted those youths who would find it extremely difficult to obtain a traineeship under Priority One, if any traineeships were available. They are youths who are at a transitional stage and who often do not have the certainty and the skills of a number of other youths who will be able to take advantage of Priority One traineeships. But the point is this: What traineeships really exist? We were promised 10 months ago that 10,000 traineeships would become available by the end of June 1986. The Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations (Mr Willis) has admitted to the House that only 800 traineeships have been filled. Realistically, as the Governments admits, there is absolutely no possibility of the goal of 10,000 being met. It is therefore a fraud and dishonest commitment and promise which raised expectations and which held out some hope for the growing army of young unemployed. At present 22.8 per cent of young people between the ages of 15 and 19 are unemployed.

In drawing my remarks to a conclusion, I wish to touch on a number of matters. A particular worry is not just the indiscriminate cutback in funding to rural colleges of advanced education but the fact that in 1985 the Australian Vice-Chancellors Committee estimated that 30,000 Australian youths who were academically qualified would not be able to find places in our tertiary learning institutions. Indeed, it is expected that in 1986 the figure will be roughly the same, if not higher. Those youths are simply not being allowed to attend institutions for which they have qualified. Therefore, a drastic rethinking of Government policies in regard to higher education is urgently needed.

A number of other aspects of education worry the Opposition, particularly that relating to curriculum. There is a belief held by a majority of members of the community that, sadly, government schools do not provide the same discipline provided by many non-government schools nor pass on the same values and traditions. This is not a good thing. It is a responsibility of any government to ensure that the standards in the government school sector are, firstly, maintained and, secondly, enhanced. I realise that, as the Minister for Education (Senator Ryan) is quick to remind us, the problems of curriculum, standards of teaching and discipline of students are largely the province of State governments. That is certainly true to a certain extent. Nonetheless, there is a growing crisis in the government school sector, with the falling away of standards in too many places. I believe that the Federal Government needs to address this serious problem.

In summary, the Federal Government's record on education at all levels is quite appalling. It has a heavy-handed, indiscriminate approach to rationalisation of funding sources. This is particularly felt in country areas where institutions of higher learning and, for that matter, secondary schools, play as important a role in the local community as they do in providing education for individual students.

DEBATE.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN INSTITUTE OF SPORT BILL 1986[COGNATE BILL:AUSTRALIAN INSTITUTE OF SPORT (CONSEQUENTIAL PROVISIONS) BILL 1986]

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 17 April, on motion by Mr John Brown:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that it is the wish of the House to debate the Australian Institute of Sport Bill 1986 concurrently with the Australian Institute of Sport (Consequential Provisions) Bill 1986. There being no objection, the Chair will allow that course to be followed.

DEBATE.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN INSTITUTE OF SPORT BILL 1986

SPEECH.SPEAKER: White Mr P.N.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I note that the Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism (Mr John Brown) has just come into the House. Mr Deputy Speaker, while the Australian Institute of Sport Bill 1986 and the Australian Institute of Sport (Consequential Provisions) Bill 1986 are connected with the Australian Institute of Sport, I note, just as a very small diversion, that during Question Time today the Minister made very complimentary remarks about the Opposition's tourism policy which, of course, is just a draft document at this stage. As I would not like him to think that he is the only person who does not have a copy, I present him with one, and I would welcome his comments. The only problem is that he will pinch all the good bits before we return to government. But since that will not be too long, I suppose he will have to work overtime to do that.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Deputy Speaker, to return to the point, since you are giving me a rather hard look, the purpose of these two Bills is to convert the Australian Institute of Sport from a public company to a statutory corporation. It has become increasingly clear that the AIS requires more parliamentary and ministerial control, as the events of late 1985 indicate. It has also become clear that most people associated with sport in Australia, within the Institute, the Australian Sports Commission and the sporting world generally, do not see the necessity for yet another statutory corporation within the world of sport. The Opposition, while not opposing the Institute in any way-in fact, we fully support it-will be opposing this legislation because the purpose of the main Bill, the Australian Institute of Sport Bill, is to turn the Institute into another statutory corporation. We believe very strongly that there are more than enough statutory corporations, boards and committees in this country, particularly under the auspices of the Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism, and we do not wish to see another one.
The Minister, in his second reading speech, said:
The legislation will ensure appropriate accountability to the government of the day and, through it, to this Parliament.

We agree with that concept. We welcome the move to establish parliamentary control over this very important institute, which has something like $80m worth of facilities at its command and a budgetary allocation this year for its recurrent costs approaching $14m. It has a great number of staff and students, which I will come to in a moment. At one stage I believed that a statutory corporation was probably one of the options to establish more ministerial and parliamentary control over this important Institute. I do not believe this any more and neither does anyone on this side of House because a control mechanism is in place-that is, the Sports Commission-and that is where the Australian Institute of Sport should properly be placed. As I have mentioned before it is clear that no one in the sporting world to whom I have spoken is in favour of creating another statutory authority when the job could properly be done by one that is already in place.

The Australian Sports Commission has a board of up to 20 people which is not fully extended and which is looking for control. If one is talking about the proper direction of government policy in sport one should be looking towards one institution which can properly direct that government policy. When people come to Canberra-several people on regular visits to Canberra have seen me in the last few days-they have to see someone in the Australian Sports Aid Foundation, someone in the Department of Sport, Recreation and Tourism, someone in the Australian Institute of Sport and someone at the Sports Commission. It is not right nor is it a proper and efficient use of resources that people should have to traipse around the country trying to get simple directions, policy or assistance.
As we also see this as an extension of political patronage into an area where it should not be-that of Australian sport-we oppose the Bill and move the following amendment:
That all words after `That' be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:

`the House is of the opinion that the Bill should not be proceeded with as it does nothing more than add to the burgeoning number of statutory authorities already in existence when the functions of the proposed Institute of Sport could well be performed by an existing body'.

The amendment will be seconded by my colleague the honourable member for Cowper (Mr Nehl). When I say that it is not necessary to have a statutory corporation I in no way mean to denigrate or to cast any reflections on the present board of the Australian Institute-which as most people know is run as a public company-because it has given good service over the last eight years. The Institute owes its existence, and credit must be given, to both sides of politics because it probably had its genesis back in the days of Frank Stewart, a former Labor Minister for Tourism and Recreation in the Whitlam Government. There was a period of quiescence when it fell into limbo somewhat. In 1980 it came to life under Bob Ellicott, a Minister in the Fraser Government. A lot of the initial work-I pay credit publicly-is due to Professor John Bloomfield, the current Chairman of the Board of the Institute and to Dr Allan Coles who did a tremendous amount of the early work. It is not a matter of point scoring as to who set up what and who is responsible for what. Both sides of politics should take the credit, and that is as it should be in Australian sport. I make that quite clear.

In 1986 the Institute has, to a large extent, come of age. Some 297 athletes are in residence, there are about 150 staff, some 2,200 visiting athletes, $80m worth of facilities and $14m worth of budgetary allocation. We do not take issue with the Institute; we are proud that a Liberal member set it up. We acknowledge all the work that has been done. In this debate the Institute is not what is in question; we give it our full support. What we want to see is its running properly and under proper control.

I think it is appropriate at this stage to spend a couple of minutes on what we see as the appropriate role for the Government in sport. That role should be minimal as it should be for most areas in which the Government is involved. We would take an opposite view to what might be described as a strictly socialist point of view whereby governments should be massively involved in as many things as possible. I am not sure whether the Minister would describe himself as a socialist; I suspect not but he is a member of a socialist party and I presume that he will not walk away from that.

TALK.START.PARA: —A democratic socialist.
—Is there a difference between a democratic socialist and a socialist?
—Not much.

—Therefore the Minister is a socialist. We take the view that the Government's role in sport as in most things should be minimal. I believe that this Government is intruding far too much into the area of sport in Australia. Basically, sport is a private sector operation and we should be encouraging the private sector as much as possible and getting the Government out of areas in which it has no business to be. This encouragement, of course, runs to financial assistance. I acknowledge all the extra money that has been given by this Government in the last three years to sport and tourism. I will be interested to see whether a budget increase will continue in this area given the difficult economic circumstances which have been recently highlighted by the Treasurer (Mr Keating). He says that we are becoming a banana republic and that Australia is in a hole. Therefore, how much money will he give to the Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism?

SPEECH.PARA: I note with interest that at a recent function the Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism publicly said that he would not suffer and that he would make sure that sport got more money than it did last year. I wait with some interest to see whether that is true. Whatever money is allocated to Australian sport it has to be properly accounted for because it is public money. That leads me back to the Australian Institute of Sport and to the $13m-odd which is being allocated to it this year.

It must be said that the recent history of the management of the Australian Institute of Sport has been somewhat less than brilliant. I think there are two particular problems: One is lack of direction as to what path it should be following. What are its strategic objectives? I note with interest from one of the Bills that the Institute will be required at long last to produce a strategic plan as to where it is going. I welcome that being written into the Bill. Management and lack of a strategic plan are the problems.

I am not in a position to say who is to blame-whether it is the Government, the Board or the management structure. This Institute has had its problems and these problems must be rectified. They culminated in November last year when allegations were made in the Press against the Australian Institute of Sport. There was an inquiry and subsequently a censure motion was moved against the Minister in this House which, if there had been any justice, would have been carried. Unfortunately it was not. The reason for that censure motion was that the Minister kept insisting that all was well at the Institute. We all know that all was not well and what is more we know that as long ago as September, and probably earlier, the Minister knew that all was not well. However, he kept saying: `Don't worry. The Institute is in good hands. There is no problem out there'. I know-I think a lot of people also know-that as far back as September the Minister had decided that the Institute was to be brought in from the cold and that a new statutory authority was to be created. That goes back to September. If the Minister had come into this House when the problems arose and said `Yes, there are problems at the Institute; I have been aware of them for some time and I am taking action to make sure that they are fixed', there would not have been any censure motion.

What we are trying to do on both sides of the House is to make sure that the Institute is run as effectively as possible. When the Minister decided to take action back in September but kept saying to us in the House in November that he was not aware of any problems, he was rightly moved against in a censure motion in this House. I presume that he would not admit it because his ego would not allow him to say: `Yes, there is something wrong in my Department'. The minutes of the Institute's Board of 19 September clearly reflect that the decision had been made by the Minister. The interesting thing about those 19 September minutes is simply that the Board was very upset that it had not been consulted.

The allegations against the Institute were investigated by Price Waterhouse. I said at the time and I say again that those investigations should have been carried out by an independent investigator because Price Waterhouse were the appointed auditors for the Australian Institute of Sport. As it turns out, it appears that their report in November 1985 was thorough and satisfactory; but it would have been a neater solution if someone else had been appointed to do that investigation because it would have removed any onus from Price Waterhouse to investigate themselves, which is what happened when the Government asked them to do the job.

Price Waterhouse reported in November. The Minister kept on saying that there were no worries at the Institute. The fact is that the Price Waterhouse report listed these problems: There was excessive entertaining of staff, too many working lunches in restaurants, excessive travel and excessive expenditure on furniture. The higher duties allowance must come under the Public Service rules; the spot merit fund was doubtful and should be discontinued; the tender procedures were somewhat shaky. There was a lack of understanding of the budget process; there was a budget shortfall of $450,000; there was no corporate plan; the staff budgeting system was poor; and there was low morale at the Institute. Yet the Minister still comes into the House and says: `It is nothing'. If that is nothing and if that is how he expects the most prestigious sports institute in this country to be run-

TALK.START.PARA: —In the world.

—In the world perhaps. If that is the sort of standard the Minister expects, let me tell him that it is not the sort of standard we on this side of the House expect, particularly when some $13m of public money is involved.

SPEECH.PARA: Just to reinforce the point I am making that a great deal was amiss, on 28 November, the same day the report was tabled in this Parliament, the Board of the Australian Institute of Sport met in Canberra. It regarded what was happening at the Institute so seriously that it passed 30 resolutions at its meeting on 28 November-the Board minutes are available-at the very same time that the Minister was in this House telling us that nothing was wrong, in the face of the Price Waterhouse report. The Board, meeting on the very same day, passed 30 resolutions to tighten up the management of the Institute.

Let me read some of the actions the Board took to make sure that the Institute was properly run. It is a pity it did not move before. It established an executive committee; it reviewed the priorities of the Institute; it ensured that Public Service guidelines were put in place for entertainment and employment; that the spot merit fund was discontinued, and that tighter financial arrangements were put in place. The role of the executive director was clearly defined; the role of the general manager was clearly defined; a staff consultative group was formed; audit programs were put in place; travel arrangements were tightened up; and there were to be no further staff appointments and no consultants appointed without the express approval of the executive committee. On 28 November we had damning Price Waterhouse report and, on the same day, the Board of the Institute passed 30 resolutions. I ask the Minister, in all reasonableness, how can he come into this House and still say that there is nothing wrong at the Institute? The Price Waterhouse report and the Board minutes, which make very interesting reading, provide not a bad list for someone to say that all was going well.

At the same time that all this was going on we had the fiasco of Mr Rodney Groux. Mr Rodney Groux was hired as a consultant by the Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism. As I understand it, at one stage he was sent to try to help the Institute overcome some of its problems. I do not know what his job was. In fact, in all the months that he worked as a consultant for the Minister, no one seemed to know exactly what he was supposed to be doing. He disappeared for a month, on the Minister's own admission. The Minister said that he did not know where he was. I ask the Minister: During that month when he was adrift, astray, wherever he was, was any attempt made to find him? Did the Minister's Department attempt to find him? Was he paid for that month? What was he doing? Was he questioned when he returned? If Mr Groux was paid a salary during that month, can the Minister tell us now what Mr Groux did?

TALK.START.PARA: —What has this to do with the Bill?
—It has everything to do with the Bill.
— Order! I interrupt the honourable member. The Chair has been listening closely to his remarks and I am bound to say that their relevance is becoming somewhat tenuous.

—Mr Deputy Speaker, let me attempt to show you how relevant they are. The relevance of Mr Groux to the Australian Institute of Sport is that when he was hired as a consultant in 1985, as I understand it and according to the Minister, a great deal of his time was spent in assisting the Institute of Sport. During some of the time when he was supposed to be at the Institute of Sport sorting out some of the problems highlighted by the Price Waterhouse report and by the Board minutes-he was being paid out of the public purse to help the Institute sort itself out-he was adrift, away for a month, and no one knew where he was. That is the relevance of Mr Groux to the Australian Institute of Sport. Without dwelling on that point, because it has been made tonight and it was certainly hammered home in previous weeks, I simply ask: Was he paid during that month? Where was he and what work did he do during that period?

SPEECH.PARA: There are two main threads to the debate on the Australian Institute of Sport. The management structure is obviously wrong and must be addressed. I very much hope that it will be, and I will deal with that in more detail in the Committee stage. As far as I know-I would be delighted to be told otherwise-there has never been proper direction or a proper strategic plan for the Institute of Sport. It is no wonder we see legislation introduced to enforce parliamentary and ministerial control over the Institute. It is our most prestigious sports institution. It cannot be left to wander along with a will of its own. It must be properly administered for two good reasons: The first is that public funds are involved and the second is that it must be the institution which sets the example for the hundreds and hundreds of sporting bodies in our country.

The Opposition's view on the problem of the AIS is simply that control and direction must be established. We believe that, in regard to the overall administration of sport in Australia at a national level, either the Sports Commission or the Department of Sport, Recreation and Tourism has to run the show. The Minister knows as well as I do that there is a great deal of confusion amongst people in the sporting world as to who they should be dealing with, at what level and on what subjects. The Sports Commission has a Board of up to 20 members and 22 staff. It has almost one staff member for each Board member. The Board simply does not have enough to do, apart from the general direction and control of sport. The Government recently set up a Sports Aid Foundation, which we opposed. I ask the Minister to clarify who exactly is on the Board of the Sports Aid Foundation.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thought I read out all their names.
—The Minister did read out the names.
—Do you want them again?

—I have the list with me. The Minister should listen. The names that the Minister read out do not correspond to the names that were given to me by someone else-I will tell the Minister who gave them to me later. The discrepancy involves Sir Peter Abeles. Is he or is he not on the Board of the Sports Aid Foundation?
—Yes.
—If that is right, someone else is very wrong.
—Your information is usually fairly suspect.

—Someone over whom the Minister has direct control gave me the names. The Minister might like to get that matter sorted out. I ask the Minister again whether that Board has now been officially appointed. There seemed to be some confusion when we last debated these issues in the House. The members of the Board had met but they had not been officially appointed. That was very confusing. We have an Australian Sports Commission which, in our view, should be the agency for running sport in this country. It should control the Sports Aid Foundation. There is no need to have a separate Sports Aid Foundation Board. There is certainly no need to have a separate statutory corporation for the Australian Institute of Sport.

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister must sort out the responsibilities of the Sports Commission and the Department. Approximately 45 people in the Department are involved in sport and recreation. I admit that I do not know what they all do. I am told that many of them, able as they are, would be better placed in the Sports Commission. That matter must be clarified. If it is not sorted out by the time we return to government, we will certainly very quickly sort it out.

TALK.START.PARA: —It will be a long time before you get back into government.

—The way the Government has been going in the last week it will not be very long at all. The Government will be welcoming an early election if we get more statements by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) as to where we are heading. The Opposition supports the Institute of Sport very strongly. We want to make sure that it is properly administered and run on policy lines which are in accord with what the Government wants and not just with what the Institute wants. We want to see a broadening of the Institute's activities. It has an elitist role. No one will deny that. We want to see a broadening of its coaching activities so we get more of a system in which coaches are brought in and then sent back to the community. Certainly the Institute does that to an extent now-it is to be complimented on that-but the system must be broadened. The decentralisation program must go ahead. We want to see the use of the Institute and its facilities by a broader range of people. I will speak on that matter during the Committee stage.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition believes that the Government has been sloppy and careless in its handling of the Australian Institute of Sport. The Minister dodged the issue in claiming last year that all was well when he knew very well and had known for months that all was not well. He misled the Parliament last year and a censure motion was moved against him.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I do not think the honourable member can assert that the Minister misled the Parliament.
—I have said it often enough previously. Why would I not be able to say it now?
—The honourable member may be able to assert that outside the chamber--
—I have said it often enough in the chamber, Mr Deputy Speaker.

—There is provision in the Standing Orders enabling a person who believes that a Minister has misled the Parliament to deal with that. One then does not continue to raise the issue in debate. The honourable member may like to rephrase the way he put the matter.

—As I am running out of time, I acknowledge what you say, Mr Deputy Speaker. Last year in the Parliament we asserted that the Minister misled the Parliament and moved a censure motion against him which, if there had been any justice, would have been carried. I commend the Opposition amendment to the House.
—Is the amendment seconded?
—I second the amendment and reserve my right to speak at a later time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martin Mr S.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —Like most honourable members on this side of the House, I had a great deal of difficulty in following the logic of the argument put by the honourable member for McPherson (Mr White) during the last half an hour for a number of reasons. We are here to debate the Australian Institute of Sport Bill 1986 and the Australian Institute of Sport (Consequential Provisions) Bill 1986, which seek to establish the Australian Institute of Sport as a Commonwealth statutory authority rather than a public company, which it is now. In the 30 minutes for which the honourable member spoke something like five minutes was devoted to talking about what that might mean and what the Opposition's policy might be, if it could devise one, on the Australian Institute of Sport and on sport generally. The rest of the time was spent bagging the Institute or the operations of the Institute and generally bagging the Opposition, because one has to remember that the Australian Institute of Sport was established by the coalition when it was in government. We on this side of the House believe that came about essentially as a knee jerk reaction to a disappointing performance by Australian competitors overseas in a variety of sporting events. It certainly reflected the lack of any semblance of a sports policy by the Liberal Government. It also certainly reflected the pressure that emanated from the community and goaded the previous Government into some form of action.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for McPherson said, on the one hand, that the Sports Institute was a terrible institute because there are no concrete procedures for management and for directing how the place should operate and, on the other hand, agreed with the Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism (Mr John Brown) that the Institute was the world's best. When those sorts of arguments are put forward it is no wonder we on this side of the House find it difficult to follow them.

We pay tribute to a former Liberal member of this place, Bob Ellicott, for at least having the foresight to get involved in this area of sports management and see that the Institute of Sport became a reality. It is unfortunate that those on the other side do not seem to share the vision he had at that time and are proposing an amendment which in effect means, as usual, that they do nothing. The amendment says that the House is of the opinion that the Bill should not be proceeded with but there is nothing put forward to suggest that there should be anything in its place, other than to say that its management should come under the Australian Sports Commission. There are very valid reasons why this should not be the case, and I will come to that shortly.

The honourable member for McPherson also referred to some management problems which arose and which were raised in this House, and mention was also made of a censure motion. This Government clearly was of the view that, with the Institute being established as a public company, there were some deficiencies in terms of public scrutiny, and particularly government scrutiny. There was at that time an ongoing process under way to review the AIS and look at some of the questions concerning management. That was happening at the time the Opposition launched its attack at the end of last year condemning the AIS and also the Minister's handling of it.

Frankly, this Government, following its traditional process of discussing and consulting with those in the community who have relevance to these particular areas, took the view that we should look at it far more closely. A number of the problems identified by the honourable member for McPherson-he referred to certain comments of the auditors Price Waterhouse-of course were under consideration. It is the view of this side that because of the establishment of the Institute as a statutory authority, those sorts of problems will receive proper government scrutiny and the ongoing problems associated with some of the management difficulties in the past will be overcome. We have already heard that the Opposition wants to subsume the AIS into the Sports Commission, but it fails to recognise that the AIS is already an autonomous body, set up for a specific purpose. As such it needs to be independent in order to be able to focus on its own particular goals. That is most important. Accusations that the Bill is creating an additional instrumentality are ludicrous, because the AIS already exists. It is not being created by this Bill. That is an important point.

I wonder how many people in this place have had the opportunity to look at the Institute, to study what it does and to appreciate for themselves the contribution that it is making to improving the sporting talents of many people in Australia, particularly many young people. I had the opportunity a couple of weeks ago to spend a couple of hours over at the Institute, and it was indeed an eye opener. We have seen it grow, from a vision of perhaps one man on the Opposition side back in 1981 to something which, as the Minister has said, now takes its place as the premier institute for sports advancement in the world. I certainly subscribe to that view put forward by the Minister. It enables us to take the best athletes in Australia and give them the opportunity to improve themselves in their athletic areas and at the same time not hinder them academically. If we look at the situation at the Institute at the moment, we can see quite clearly what I mean by that. The opportunity is provided for people to go there and receive training and coaching from the best coaches available in Australia and at the same time to continue their academic prowess by going to local high schools, colleges of advanced education or whatever. So in effect we are marrying the idea of developing Australia's sporting talented people with the idea that once they have completed competing for Australia or for their State in their chosen sport they will not be placed on the scrap-heap because they do not have a further career to pursue. Those days are long gone, and this is an important part of the Australian Institute of Sport that many people do not recognise.

If one has the chance to consider in some detail how this place operates, one also sees that the main basis of the Institute's activities has been the residential sports program. Scholarships are awarded under this program, and they provide athletes with access to a wide range of services and facilities while at the same time enabling them to further their sporting and academic or work experiences. As I have already said, that is most important. We see that through a number of programs-such as the national training centre program, the satellite coaching program, the visiting athletes program and areas of overseas participation with which the Australian Institute of Sport is involved and on which some of my colleagues will speak a little later-we are offering the people of Australia and our nearby neighbours the opportunity for advanced coaching and improvement in their sporting prowess so that we can develop within Australia people who can in turn go on and pass on their prowess and coaching talents to other young people. That is most important because quite clearly, although the primary objective of the AIS has been to promote, provide, encourage and develop opportunities for Australians to pursue and achieve excellence in sport and activities associated with sport, it is not a medal factory. It is not there purely and simply to churn out medal makers for Australia so that, as many Eastern countries tend to do, we can parade them on the world stage and say that this makes us a dominant group. We are not about that. Rather, the resident athletes are encouraged to pursue their academic and work experiences and careers with the same diligence as their sporting careers. That is most important.

Nevertheless, the AIS has been associated with some remarkable and notable sporting achievements. We owe a great debt to those dedicated men and women who make up the coaching staff at the Institute of Sport. In 1984, for example, the Australian Olympic team included 52 athletes and 13 officials who were scholarship holders or coaches at the AIS. That is a significant contribution. Five AIS athletes, all swimmers, won medals in the 1984 Olympic Games. Three AIS swimmers won 1984 United States of America national swimming titles. At the 1982 Commonwealth Games, 26 of the 70 gold medals won by Australians went to AIS athletes. Robert de Castella, a well-known athlete-known probably to every Australian-who comes from Canberra, and the world's leading marathon runner, as proven recently in the Boston marathon, is a former AIS athlete.

TALK.START.PARA: —He is a present AIS athlete.

—He is a present AIS athlete, and his coach is on the coaching staff of the track and field team. A number of AIS coaches have been selected as national or assistant national coaches. On and on we can go. The AIS water polo team was undefeated in a 12-match tour of Europe in August 1985. Six members of the AIS soccer team represented Australia in the 1985 Youth World Cup finals in the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics. Five AIS team members were selected in the Australian water polo team which competed in the 1985 World Cup. There have been creditable performances in international tennis by players such as Patrick Cash, Anne Minter, Wally Masur and Simon Youl, and a number of others including Michelle Turk, who just happens to come from the great Illawarra region. The Illawarra region has provided a good share of the administrators and coaches at the Institute. We see, for example, that Dr Adrian Hurley is coaching in the basketball area. He is a former high school teacher I had the pleasure to work with in the Wollongong area a number of years ago. He is making his mark, and is contributing to the Australian Institute of Sport. A number of other people are in a similar position. As I said earlier, they are to be congratulated and commended for the effort they are putting in to see that the Australian Institute of Sport rightly takes its place in Australia-indeed, in the world-as the premier sporting facility to promote young people's abilities, young people's talents, and to combine the promotion of those sporting talents with the ability to continue to pursue academic or work careers.

SPEECH.PARA: As I said at the outset, the achievements of this Institute clearly demonstrate that this Government has been 100 per cent spot on, and this Minister has been spot on, in supporting this body. The Government also has been absolutely spot on in providing ongoing finance for the Institute. I believe that this Government is also 100 per cent spot on in endeavouring to bring this body under the umbrella of government control, which will occur through its creation as a Commonwealth statutory authority. To simply say that it is a public company and therefore should be controlled by or come under the umbrella of some other group is not to provide a feasible alternative. I was hoping that these Bills would receive the support of both sides of the Parliament. However, again I am disappointed, just as I was then those opposite opposed the legislation for the Sports Aid Foundation and the Sports Commission.

TALK.START.PARA: —We did not oppose the Sports Aid Foundation. We opposed the Board.

—It might interest the honourable member to know that the Sports Aid Foundation which he was criticising earlier this evening, has since its establishment processed some $45,000 in donations towards the Commonwealth Games. If that is the kind of response we can expect from the general public to initiatives by this Government to promote sport, I suggest to those opposite that they should re-think their ideas. I suggest that they might like to take back the draft policy that they flicked across the table to the Minister.
—That was on tourism.
—Oh, that was only tourism. Well, they like to give their sport and recreation policies a little more thought and take on board the Government's achievements. I commend the Bills to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wilson The Hon I.B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Institute of Sport Bill and the Australian Institute of Sport (Consequential Provisions) Bill do not call in question the role and significance to Australia as a whole, and to our sporting community in particular, of the Institute of Sport. The Opposition supports the Institute of Sport. In fact, the Liberal and National parties when in government, played a very significant part in the development of the idea of the Institute of Sport. The idea may have emerged some years ago, but it was under a Liberal-National Party Government that the Institute was established.

SPEECH.PARA: The circumstances of its establishment are well known to members of this House. At the time the decision was taken to establish an Institute of Sport it became desirable to do so as speedily as possible. It was administratively quicker to establish the Institute by the formation of a company to administer the conduct of that organisation through that structure. It has been under that structure that it has come from a dream to the reality that was described by the honourable member for Macarthur (Mr Martin), who preceded me. No one on this side of the House would have any argument with him about the significance, role and success of the Institute of Sport. Indeed, we too congratulate the administers, all the staff of the Institute from its inception, its board of management, the athletes themselves and all those from many other sectors, both from the private sector and from the government bureaucracy, who have in some way lent their support to the great success of that Institute.

The company that this legislation seeks to put into liquidation and replace with a statutory authority was formed on 24 September 1980, as the Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism (Mr John Brown) said in his second reading speech, and commenced operations on 26 January 1981. From a position of having no athletes and conducting no courses in any sports, within one year it had 151 athletes and eight residential sports-athletics, basketball, gymnastics, netball, soccer, swimming, tennis and weight-lifting. Since then the number of sports has been extended. During those early years the Institute and its concept acted as a very significant catalyst not only to the establishment of additional sports at the Australian Institute of Sport, but also to the creation in a number of States of State institutes of sport. I recall attending a Recreation Ministers Council meeting at which the idea of the establishment of State institutes of sport was discussed. From those discussions a number of States have taken up that idea.

In a relatively short time sport, and its role through institutes of sport, has come a long way. I am sure that just as the present Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism is pleased with the developments that have occurred in sport in the last three years, Ministers who preceded him in other governments were pleased with the dynamic and exciting developments that had occurred in sport.

Having said that, I turn to the Bills. The Opposition's concern about the legislation is not about the concept of an Institute. Our concern does not call in question the great success of the Institute or the need for its continuance and further development. It calls into question the procedure being adopted by the Government to convert a company into a statutory authority. We ask: Why is a new statutory authority in place of a company necessary when only 12 months and a week or two ago the Minister introduced into this House an Australian Sports Commission Bill and set up a Sports Commission? That was a new statutory authority. When the Minister introduced that Bill he said:
Central to those plans was the creation of the Australian Sports Commission to draw together more effectively our national sporting effort.
What is the Minister now doing? He is fragmenting that effort. He is perpetuating a division of responsibility between the Institute and the Sports Commission.

One is surprised that this legislation is not winding up the Sports Institute as a company and incorporating it within the Sports Commission. It is quite fascinating for us to look at this Bill and to read the Minister's statements concerning the role of this new statutory authority. The Minister says that the Australian Sports Institute is to have responsibility for the added thrust of the Institute's coaching efforts. It is to have responsibility for program implementation. It is to be responsible for the provision of sports medicine and sports science services. It is to be responsible for fund raising and for consulting with national and State sporting bodies and with State and Territory governments. It is to pursue a number of new sports development initiatives.

In addition, it is to provide resources, services and facilities to enable Australians to pursue and achieve excellence in sport, while also furthering their educational and vocational skills and other aspects of their personal development. Many Australians outside the Australian Institute of Sport are doing just that. This legislation would appear to give the Australian Institute of Sport a wide field of responsibility. I happen to have received a document called `An Introduction to the Australian Sports Commission'. I was interested to read the functions of the Commission. They are:

To maximise funding for sport from the private sector to supplement funds from the Commonwealth Budget; to provide leadership in the development of Australia's performance in international sport; to increase the level of participation in sport of all Australians.
Other functions are to advise the Minister in relation to the promotion and development of sport and to raise money for sport. Further functions are as follows:

. . . to administer and spend money from the Budget or raised by the Sports Aid Foundation; to co-ordinate activities in Australia for the promotion and development of sport; to consult and co-operate with appropriate authorities of the Commonwealth, of the States and of the Territories, and with other organisations, associations and persons, on matters related to its activities; to initiate, encourage and facilitate research and development in relation to sport; to collect and distribute information and provide advice on matters related to its activities.

Those objectives and functions are almost identical with the objectives and functions of the Australian Institute of Sport. How will the responsibility of the Australian Institute of Sport be limited? How is overlap with the Australian Sports Commission to be avoided? If there is complete overlap or a large degree of overlap, why not incorporate the Australian Institute of Sport within the Australian Sports Commission? If we look at the programs of the Australian Sports Commission we find that it is responsible for program implementation. The new Institute of Sport statutory authority will also be responsible and have powers for program implementation. The Australian Sports Commission has programs covering sports development, sports talent encouragement, sports science research and drugs in sport and an Australian coaching council, yet these are all areas of responsibility that are now to be conferred upon the Australian Institute of Sport. I am very concerned that we should ensure that the dollars provided by government to Australian sport go to promoting sport and not in providing duplicated, triplicated jobs within bureaucracies, statutory authorities or departments at the expense of Australian sport.

When one looks at the legislation governing the Australian Sports Commission, one cannot help wondering whether there is a need for a Department of Sport at all because if one analyses the work the Department of Sport is doing one finds that it is double guessing the Australian Sports Commission, that it is double guessing the Australian Institute of Sport. Why do we have this triplication? Why do we have two statutory authorities and a government department consulting with State governments and Territory governments and with sporting organisations and leading sportsmen and women around the country? People in sport will be utterly confused by this treble contact and yet the Minister 12 months ago said he wanted a body that would co-ordinate this Government's responsibilities in sport. He set up the Australian Sports Commission to do that.

My submission to the House tonight is that the introduction of this Bill is a denial of the purposes for which the Minister introduced a Bill 12 months ago to set up an Australian Sports Commission. It is for that reason, amongst others, that the Opposition is opposed to the conversion of the company now running the Australian Sports Institute to a statutory authority. We think that it should be done in other ways. By doing it in other ways the money that is provided by governments will go further because less money will be spent on bureaucratic corporate structures and departmental structures and more money will be available for scholarships for the Institute of Sport or to fund the great variety of programs that are now conducted through the Australian Sports Commission.

As I said a few minutes ago, one cannot help wondering whether the time has not come for the Government to face up in difficult economic times to the need to reduce the number of departments. If the Institute of Sport and the Australian Sports Commission are to have the responsibility that the legislation gives them, maybe those officers now working within the Department should be transferred to one or other of these two statutory authorities, although my preference would be to see it as one statutory authority.

I want to draw the attention of the House to another aspect of this Bill. Some 12 months ago, when the Australian Sports Commission legislation was before this House, I expressed my concern at the way in which the legislation gave ministerial control over a statutory authority in a way which, if used by a Minister, would give the Minister day to day control of that statutory authority as if it were a department of state. I would be interested to learn from the Minister whether he has given any directions to the Australian Sports Commission or whether he intends to give any directions to the Australian Institute of Sport. If so, does he intend to give them detailed day to day administrative instructions, or is it his intention to use that power only as a last resort, only in the circumstances of either or both those statutory authorities behaving in a way that has them trespassing beyond what he, as Minister, perceives to be the charter established for those institutes? It may be that the experience of the last 12 months has indicated that the Minister, in spite of his professed claim that there should be strong ministerial control, has really given to the Australian Sports Commission the degree of autonomy that I was concerned he may not give it. If one sets up a statutory authority for the purpose of giving it freedom to advise, that body should be free to give advice which sometimes governments may find hard to handle. Likewise, in the case of the Australian Institute of Sport, that body needs independence and autonomy.

I was interested to find in the Minister's second reading speech that he drew a parallel between the statutory authority this Bill will set up, the Australian National Gallery, the National Library and, indeed, the Australian Sports Commission. I think he had a case of apples, pears and bananas because--

TALK.START.PARA: —They are all fruit.

—They may be all fruit; there are some similarities, but there are also some quite significant differences between the two collecting agencies, the great National Library of Australia and the Australian National Gallery, and a sports commission and a sports institute. I would have thought that there might have been a greater parallel between the Sports Institute and a college of advanced education or a university. Having in mind the nature of the program of the Institute of Sport it may be that it needs autonomy and freedom, freedom of the type that universities describe as academic freedom. If a sports institute is going to be at the frontiers of sports training and development, it needs that freedom and autonomy and should not be constrained by tight bureaucratic administrative control.

SPEECH.PARA: In this legislation the Minister is given the power to give day to day directions. I hope that he will see that power as a last resort power and give to the Institute, its board of management and its director the academic freedom to conduct its programs in the best interests of Australian sport. If he does not do that we will find that the Institute will become more and more bureaucratised; its role will be less imaginative and, being less imaginative, less successful. Another point I want to bring to the attention of the Minister is the fact that in this legislation, as in the Sports Commission legislation, the Institute is required to bring down a strategic plan.
Sitting suspended from 6.30 to 8 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before the suspension of the sitting for dinner I spoke at somewhat more length than I will now on the Bill to make a statutory authority out of the Australian Institute of Sport. I do not have time to summarise in the very limited time I have left a number of points I made in my speech. I conclude by saying that I very much support the idea of the Institute of Sport but I do not believe that the Government's approach in establishing it as an independent statutory authority is the appropriate way to go. I believe it would be better if it were incorporated with the Sports Commission so that there could be genuine co-ordination and a simplification in the procedures and administration of the Government's policy on sport.
