DEBATE.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN INSTITUTE OF SPORT BILL 1986[COGNATE BILL:AUSTRALIAN INSTITUTE OF SPORT (CONSEQUENTIAL PROVISIONS) BILL 1986]

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before the debate is resumed on this Bill, I remind the House that it has been agreed that a general debate be allowed covering this Bill and the Australian Institute of Sport (Consequential Provisions) Bill.

DEBATE.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN INSTITUTE OF SPORT BILL 1986

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Charlesworth Dr R.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —Earlier in the evening, when I was sitting in my office listening to the shadow Minister, the honourable member for McPherson (Mr White), speak on the Australian Institute of Sport Bill, I was fascinated to hear him say that it was his view that sport should be a private sector activity and that the Government should get out of sport. I hope that as many sportspeople in this country as possible were listening, because it would seem that after three years in opposition, honourable members opposite still have very little empathy with the sports lobby and the sports people of this country. Clearly, sportsmen and women in this country have been the poor relations for many years compared with their counterparts overseas. I have not been one to espouse the views of Malcolm Fraser in this House over the years, but I will quote from his speech when he opened the Australian Institute of Sport on Australia Day in 1981. The then Prime Minister said:

SPEECH.PARA: Up until now, too many world class Australian athletes at the end of their normal schooling would have had to make the decision to undertake tertiary studies or to continue with their sport. There were no adequate facilities or opportunities to enable them to do both, as is common overseas.

The Australian Institute of Sport, established in close co-operation and arrangement with high class tertiary institutions of the National Capital, alters all of this. Here young Australian athletes can pursue their sport and gain other qualifications.
Coaches and athletes working together through this institute will, I am certain, produce great things for Australia and carry Australia's name high.

Indeed, the former Prime Minister was much more empathetic with the views of sport in this country than seems to be the case with the shadow Minister. Further, the honourable member for Sturt (Mr Wilson) talked about the confusion that would exist with the Australian Institute of Sport being established as a statutory body, and suggested that perhaps the Institute should be subsumed into the Sports Commission. It was only a year ago in this place that members on the other side of the House said that the Sports Commission should not be established. Now they seem to be supporting this proposal.

I will refer to one or two other aspects of the speech made by the honourable member for Sturt. He suggested that the high performance orientation of the Institute of Sport was in some way incorrect and that this aspect of the Institute of Sport should be subsumed into the Sports Commission. I point out to the honourable member that, of course, there are aspects of the Institute of Sport that are very specific. The sports science aspect of this Institute is an important and necessary part of high performance sport. Also, there are the commercial fund raising activities which the Institute of Sport undertakes. I have no difficulty with seeing Dr Dick Telford selling cereal on television if that brings to the Institute of Sport money which otherwise would have come out of the taxpayer's pocket. I have no difficulty with this practice. I cannot imagine why such commercial enterprise should be opposed by the Opposition. The AIS evolved over many years. Many governments presided over the gestation of the Institute, which developed rapidly and has done much since it was established. The present status of the Institute is one of world renown. Indeed, many sports people from overseas provide us with glowing reports of the programs and the work that the Institute has been undertaking.

However, there are problems with the AIS. Perhaps the biggest problem that is seen by sportspeople in this country is the untouchable, impenetrable nature of the Institute. Indeed, for many it is known as Fortress Bruce. I hope that in this speech I can point to one or two directions which could be taken by the Institute. I hope that the Institute will direct its activities beyond Canberra to the sports people of this country in general. Certainly this Government has undertaken to decentralise many of the activities of the Institute. This very appropriate action has gained wide support. It is also necessary for us to utilise more fully the fantastic facilities we have in Canberra. I have no doubt that the administration can be streamlined. I would like to see the Institute of Sport reach out in terms of its coaching programs, its international programs, its contact with sports people overseas and, as I mentioned earlier, perhaps even its commercial approach. I think this is an important area in which the Institute needs to move.

Of course, the residential sports programs that were mentioned by the honourable member for Macarthur (Mr Martin) are the basis of the activities of the Institute. The programs provide access to services and facilities for those who gain scholarships and allow them to pursue their sport as well as their academic or work careers. I hope that that thrust of the Institute will continue. However, it was this Government that saw problems in that approach. There are problems for teams being based in Canberra. Teams do not have significant competition or the right competition. In a sense, they are often isolated from the major capital cities where the best sports competition may occur. There may be difficulties in Canberra in regard to facilities. Because of that this Government sought to decentralise various aspects of the residential sports program which enables the Institute to use facilities provided in all States. It enables the Institute to involve the States and the Territories. Indeed, the State institutes of sport which have been established over the last few years are involved in that procedure. I hope that the Institute of Sport will also develop secondary level sports and appoint coaches in this area, so that particular groups or national bodies which cannot get together in a continual residential program are able to use the facilities where necessary, where appropriate, and where possible.

It seems very important also that many of those outstanding athletes in this country who for all sorts of reasons-work or study or family or social situations-are unable to move to a centralised residential program are able to get assistance from the Institute of Sport and avail themselves of the facilities and coaches that exist in their home towns or States. I note that the Institute of Sport is interested in moving in this direction and I commend it for doing so.

It is also important that this massive, fantastic facility that we have here in Canberra is used for individuals and for national teams. Indeed, the national training centre scheme which has been developed over the last couple of years should grow. National teams are able to come to Canberra and avail themselves of the facilities and services here to prepare for overseas competitions or for competitions within Australia. About 40 groups take up this option annually. This is another aspect of the training centre approach which is important and which must be developed by the Institute.

Another program which has developed-it is perhaps only in its embryonic stage at the moment but certainly should grow in the future-is the satellite coaches scheme. I hope that the Institute of Sport will continue to provide assistance in backup and wherewithal to coaches, who have been doing very good work in their States or capital cities over the years. These coaches provide a very reliable source of talent identification for the Institute and it is important that their work continue and that they be assisted by the Institute of Sport.

Perhaps one of the most important areas in which the Institute can play an increasing part is in the role of coaching. I am sure we are all aware of the importance of coaches. One only has to look at the success of Australian tennis players in this country in the early 1950s and 1960s to see that. One attaches the name Harry Hopman to that success. Percy Cerutty was a well known and renowned coach of a number of successful athletes; he was responsible for their success. Arthur Liddiard in New Zealand produced a number of outstanding runners. Even the coach, Pat Clohessy, of that outstanding runner we presently have in this country, Robert de Castella, is very important to his success. The relationship that exists between a coach and an athlete is an intimate one in many cases; it is central to an athlete's performance. It is an ongoing thing; it does not occur just on the day of the performance.

I believe that high level master coaching courses and facilities need to be provided and the Institute of Sport is the appropriate way this can be done. This will not usurp the work that is already being done in that area. The Australian Coaching Council co-ordinates the national coaching accreditation schemes that presently exist. It does a very good job with level 1, level 2 and level 3 coaches in association with national federations. Presently the Australian Sports Commission, through its development grants and its programs with children, assists with coaching initiatives for national federations.

The AIS runs seminars and courses for those who are interested in and require the backup support that the Australian Institute of Sport is able to provide. I hope that in future more top level coaching programs will be made available through the Institute of Sport. I hope that the technical backup that the Institute of Sport has and can provide will be better used. Perhaps there will be short and long term residential courses for those coaches who wish to coach at the very highest level. Certainly the Institute of Sport has the facilities and the ability to provide that backup.

I would like to say briefly one or two things about the sports science and sports medicine aspect of the Institute of Sport. It is worthwhile to look at the activities in which it has been involved over the last few years. It has provided a complete sports medicine service for those athletes who are based in Canberra; it has supplied personnel for Australian teams competing in major contests; it has taught medical, physiotherapy and nursing students from all over Australia and New Zealand; it has established links with many sporting medicine personnel from other countries. Indeed, it has hosted post-graduate doctors from all parts of Australia. In a lot of other ways the sports medicine aspect and people at the Institute of Sport have played a part in disseminating throughout this country information on the highest level of sports medicine.

In the same way, in the area of sports science, the Institute has given assistance to athletes and coaches in the areas of physiology, biomechanics, psychology and technical workshops. Residential athletes at the Institute benefit, the national training centre people benefit and coaches, visiting athletes and other groups throughout this country are assisted by the work of the sports science people. I would hope that this modern sports science and sports medicine facility that we have in Canberra-I understand that it is one of the best in the world-will continue to do that work and will continue to be involved in first class research, in sharing our ideas with those overseas and perhaps in learning from them and recruiting appropriate scientists and specialists from all over the world so that the interchange of ideas that is so important to high level performance in sport is continued.

There are many other programs in which the Institute of Sport is involved and I would hope that these programs will continue and grow, that the international goodwill that sport can often provide a vehicle for, can continue and that the exchange of ideas, possibilities and athletes from all over the world can continue and grow. I would hope that we could manage these facilities here; indeed, within the Bill there is provision for a strategic plan which I hope will improve that management of facilities in this country. I hope that the commercial sponsorship that the Institute is able to develop and very rightly so-it has a unique product to sell-can continue to grow. Certainly that will relieve the taxpayer of financial burdens. These Bills will see that the AIS grows, develops and succeeds, and produces better and better results. I have no doubt that it will. I commend this legislation to the House. I think that it confirms the Government's commitment to sports men and women in this country and they know it only too well.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McVeigh The Hon D.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —Migrants to this country have often expressed the view that the English language does not provide words which sufficiently and actively express thoughts permeating one's mind. We talk about the character and spirit of Australia, but these words do not really indicate what we are trying to describe. The Greeks had a far better word and it is ethos. Sport has been very much part and parcel of the Australian ethos. It is natural that it should be so.

SPEECH.PARA: Many reasons have been given why sport has become such a strong interest of Australian people. It is true that we have natural advantages such as the temperate climate and the availability of space. It is true too that, after a century of coming to grips with taming a rather inhospitable distant land, there grew a desire for a home-grown culture and it has found fertile ground in both the sporting and battle grounds. I believe that these three factors have developed the Australian ethos.

Writers and historians have argued that sport and war were the two main areas in which Australia's national identity could be expressed. In the arenas of international sport and war, Australians could strive to show that they were equal to, if not better than, all other nations. I refer to things such as the Gallipoli campaign, the Boer War and in sporting areas our contests in the international arenas of cricket, athletics, swimming and the various codes of football. We, as Australians, have forged a nation where performances in international sport and war, whether the encounters were won or lost, were a sure indication that, if we choose other fields in which to expand our energies, we could reasonably expect to do well.

Many people would disagree that there is a basic philosophic close association between sport and war. Indeed, Lorenz has described sport as `a special ritualised form of battle developed by the culture of man'. Australian sport can trace its origins back to the exploits of our international competitors, beginning with the first modern Olympics in Athens in 1896. It is interesting to note that, when the architect of the modern Olympics, Baron Pierre de Coubertin, propounded his idea for a new era in international sport on 25 November 1892, he said:

Let us export our oarsmen, our runners, our fencers into other lands. That is true free trade of the future and the day it is introduced into Europe the cause of peace will have received a new and strong ally. It inspires me to touch upon another step I now propose and in it I shall ask that the help you have given me before you will give me again, so that together we may attempt to realise, upon a basis suitable to the conditions of our modern life, the splendid and beneficial task of reviving the Olympic Games.

It is not for me in my contribution in this debate to harrow the ground that has been covered by previous speakers. I support the view that has been advanced by the Opposition, whilst at the same time giving general support to the initiatives detailed by the Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism (Mr John Brown). Surely it is sound common sense to ensure that the Australian Institute of Sport owns and controls the various facilities. That lessens government red tape and bureaucratic control. I would hope that, when this legislation is implemented, it will not increase government intervention in the Institute's administration and the carrying out of its aims and objectives because, quite frankly, people associated with the Institute are in a far better position to know what ought to be done, how it is to be done and when it is to be done. The only government intervention should be the requirement for the Director of the Institute and the Auditor-General to present an annual report to Parliament. If the Institute is to be hamstrung by too much inquiry and direction from government I believe that it will eventually flounder. It will prosper by harnessing the enthusiasm, the expertise and the balanced judgment of all who are associated with it.

The AIS has had many remarkable achievements in its short history. I wish to incorporate in Hansard the names of all 1982 Commonwealth Games gold medallists and the name of our 1984 Olympic Games gold medallist, Glynis Nunn. I also wish to incorporate in Hansard a list of all AIS board members since its inception because, quite frankly, unless their names are enshrined their valuable and valued personal contributions may never be adequately acknowledged. At least the fact that their names have been recorded in a parliamentary debate may be of some value to them. I seek leave to have those names incorporated in Hansard.

TALK.START.PARA: —Leave is granted.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —The question is whether the material complies with the directions that have been laid down by Madam Speaker. It will be looked at with a view to seeing whether it complies. If it does, we will note that leave has been granted and it will be included in Hansard. If it does not, it will not appear.

INTERJECT.PARA: The list of Australian Institute of Sport gold medal winning athletes read as follows-

TALK.START.PARA: —The Institute of Sport has created its own ethos, which I have spoken about previously. The ethos of the Institute has been created by the leadership of directors and coaches, by the inquiring minds of people who have searched world-wide for ideas and who have put their thoughts into action. I was very proud as an Australian, after my return from a trip to Europe last year, to be discussing some of the overseas institutes I had visited and to be told that during the World Cup Athletics in Canberra last year visiting athletes from the United States of America, Europe, the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics and East Germany had indicated that the Australian Institute of Sport was the best in the world, being superior to the Lenin Sports Institute in Moscow and the Colorado Springs Olympic Training Centre in America which, until the establishment of the AIS, were looked upon as the world's leading sports centres. Therefore, all associated with the AIS can be very proud indeed of what has been achieved.

SPEECH.PARA: It is interesting to note the respect that the Institute has gained from private sponsors. I have been reliably told that, notwithstanding the fact that private sponsorship has been sought only in recent years, already over $1m has been given by well established, highly regarded companies. The Institute plays a wider role than is commonly acknowledged. It distributes an enormous amount of literature to coaches and athletes. This literature covers such simple things as avoiding injury through proper warm-up procedures. The Institute has become established as a tourist attraction. Only last week, eight busloads of children from Victoria visited the centre. I can readily understand their enthusiasm for what has been established there.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It is a suitable time to interrupt the honourable member. I am inclined to allow to be incorporated in Hansard the list of Commonwealth Games gold medal winning athletes because it is a list which incorporates a table of events in which they have participated. I am not inclined to accede to the honourable member's request in relation to the list of board members. I am making this ruling now so that if the honourable member wishes to read the names into the record he is at liberty to do so.

—Well, they had better be given back to me. The Institute provides the opportunity for the pursuit of excellence, not only to those who are permanent residents but also in its capacity as a national training centre. Over 2,000 athletes from over 50 different sports have attended the centre for periods lasting some weeks or for three or four days. Similarly, coaches can make use of the facilities. Under the guidance of Dr Peter Fricker and Dr Dick Telford, the Sports Science Medical Centre has become a focal point for Australian sports medicine and could be described as a reference centre. This centre is one of the most advanced centres in the world as far as applied research is concerned. It is also doing a lot to make the findings of its research known to many people.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the interesting aspects of initiatives adopted by the Institute is that of international exchange. It is appropriate to recall at this time, with the visit of our Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) to the People's Republic of China, that in the very near future the well known Australian swimmer Steven Holland will be going to Beijing to conduct a swimming clinic, whilst the People's Republic will be sending to Australia a diving coach, equally highly regarded in international competition. Perhaps an excellent way of spending some of our overseas aid money would be to promote friendship and peace among athletes in various countries by this international exchange.

The Institute also has affiliated with it satellite coaches, which to my mind is an excellent idea insofar as it fits in with my philosophy of decentralisation. The idea of outpost scholarships-the great Australian athlete Glynis Nunn attends the Institute as an outpost scholar-allows the facilities to have a wide-ranging, practical application. The success of the Institute has been due in part to the efforts of the coaches. It is good to know that these coaches in the main are Australians. People whose names come to mind are Bill Sweetenham, the swimming coach, and Pat Clohessy with his colony of distance runners. These coaches have made their names because of their ability to adapt. For instance, the distance runners use not only the facilities at the Institute but also the forest at Stromlo because that allows for a change of scenery.

It is interesting to note that because we have a top quality Institute and top quality coaches we begin to attract top quality people from other disciplines-people like Judy Hudson, the well known Olympic swimmer and great Australian competitor of a decade ago who was good enough, academically, to get a scholarship to the United States of America. She came back, graduated from the University of Queensland and, having gained a lot of practical experience, came down here with her expertise and enthusiasm. That indicates what happens when we have top quality people running an institute; it indicates the type of people they attract. The Minister in his second reading speech recorded the thoughts expressed by Sir Donald Bradman. I too would like to refer to them. The Minister quoted Sir Donald as follows:

Whilst I applaud our Government's new found encouragement for the sporting fraternity, I hope nobody gets carried away by the mistaken notion that financial help and good facilities guarantee success. They merely open the door. Success must still be motivated from within. Hard work and dedication remain essential for all individuals, who must embrace with equal fervour, opportunity and responsibility.
Athletes who use the AIS have the advantage not only of the facilities but also of absorbing the philosophy of top class coaches, who tell all the athletes that they also have a part to play.

Sport is very much a part of life, and the success of the Institute can be recognised by the quality of the people who have trained there and who have now moved on to other facets of their lives. Four such people who come readily to mind happen to be Queenslanders and I just instance them because I have certain parochial pride in Queenslanders and people who come from my own electorate. I refer to Paul Narracott, Gary Brown-there is no greater competitor than Gary Brown and I for one would love to see him at Edinburgh as I think he would win another gold for us-Don Wright, a great hurdler who was educated in my own area, and of course Glynis Nunn. Those four people, like so many people from the Institute, are what we might term ornaments to the Institute and credits to themselves for the quality of citizenship they bring to the wider application of the Australian nation. They all epitomise, to my mind, the fact that the peaceful future of mankind depends upon our capacity to conduct international sport in a continuing and meaningful way. They pursued excellence by a determination to win, but not a determination to win at all costs through abuses, through over-zealousness, through senselessness and inhumanity. They relied on fitness, dedication and sporting tradition. They exemplify what should be the goal of any government, and that is to ensure that the athlete, at the various stages of his or her life, is regarded as a fully functional, productive member of society, who is also a diplomat and who is a great teacher because he or she teaches by the greatest teacher of all-good example. We know the Institute by the quality of the people it turns out, and in the cases I have indicated above, it is real quality.

Sport is very much part of human nature. It emanates from our natural impulses for freedom, symbolic meaning and the pursuit of perfection. To my mind, sport is a natural religion in the sense of involving one's spirit, a sense of awe and fate, a quest for community and for participation in life, and a respect for the mystery and power of one's own being and the being of one's rivals. Sport disciplines us in the sense that it is organised, it requires sacrifice and it teaches those real religious qualities of heart and soul which makes us better people. I would hope that Australia never ever becomes a nation of spectators, a nation which, as far as sport is concerned, merely wants to read about what is happening, to look at replays of sporting events and to have a hushed expectancy of the same things being repeated next week. Sport is a natural outlet for human emotions and we would hope that we can have a continuation of friendships made on the sporting field between individuals and teams, because personal and team loyalties, formed in adolescence and maintained through life, serve to remind us that there are areas in life which can give us a comfortable stability-things that have a permanence among the harrowing interruptions and continuing transitions of daily life. The Australian Institute of Sport has established its name because of the quality of the people who have worked there and the achievements of those who have brought it fame. The Olympic motto is citius altius fortius-faster, higher, stronger. That Olympic motto applies also to the Australian Institute of Sport, an Institute which has seen many great athletes pass through its ranks.

I have not been handed the right piece of paper; I wish there were not stealers in this place! While I am awaiting that piece of paper, I shall read into the Hansard record the list of all AIS Board members since its inception: Sam Richardson, John Cheadle, John Daly, Deirdre Hyland, Wayne Reid, Donald Talbot, Kevan Gosper, John Newcombe, Grahame Dempster-he happens also to be a product of Warwick, so it is no wonder he is such a great athlete-John Devitt, Joyce Brown, Lisa Curry, Peter Montgomery, John Coates, Michael Wenden, Geoffrey Pollard, Elizabeth Darlison, Herbert Macdonald, John Cheffers, John Bloomfield, Richard Pratt, John Landy and Paul Brettell. All those people have played a meaningful and significant role in developing the Institute. I am just sorry that somebody has not given me back my piece of paper with the names of Commonwealth Games winners and also that of Glynis Nunn, who won the gold medal for us at the most recent Olympics.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! To correct any reflection that may have been made on the Chair, the piece of paper was kept for incorporation in Hansard in accordance with the honourable member's request and my earlier ruling.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grace Mr E.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —It gives me great pleasure to support the Australian Institute of Sport Bill and the Australian Institute of Sport (Consequential Provisions) Bill. We have to go back some years to the Whitlam Government, for it was in that Government that the late Frank Stewart made the dream of a sports institute in Australia possible. It was Frank Stewart's determination that succeeded in getting a review into the role, scope and development of sport and recreation in Australia. That report-the Bloomfield report-became the platform for this country's direction in relation to sport and recreation. Ultimately this led to a proposal for an institute of sport and recreation, but unfortunately because of the political situation in 1975 it was never established.

SPEECH.PARA: Over subsequent years a number of the recommendations in the Bloomfield report have been put into practice by Federal, State and Territorial governments. It was not until 1980 that the idea of an Australian institute of sport was resurrected. The then Minister for Home Affairs, Bob Ellicott, to his credit pushed the Fraser Government into supporting the concept. On Australia Day 1981 the Australian Institute of Sport was incorporated as a public company.

When we look back to that day in 1981, we recall that some 151 athletes attended the Institute-representing a number of sports, including basketball, swimming, soccer, gymnastics, athletics, netball, tennis and weightlifting. That was just the beginning. Since then we have seen the Institute progress at an exceedingly strong rate. Funding levels and participation rates have grown, a testament to its great success. Current funding for the Australian Institute of Sport in 1985-86 is running at $13.94m. This compares favourably with 1980-81, when the original budget was just over $1m. Hopefully we will see the funding for the Institute increase even further in future budgets. At present some 300 athletes in 13 sports participate in the Institute's programs and around 2,200 athletes in 52 different sports attend the Institute under the auspices of the national training centre program which was introduced in 1982.

As I stated a moment ago, the Australian Institute of Sport was incorporated as a public company in 1981. The introduction of this Bill will enable the Institute to convert to a Commonwealth statutory authority from a public company. This will enhance even further the Institute's ability to accommodate the needs of our country's vastly talented young men and women. Australia has had over a number of years great sports men and women, but for many years they have had to struggle to scrape up as much money as they could to send themselves around the country to compete. Also they needed to provide themselves with money while at their home base. The second Bill, the Australian Institute of Sport (Consequential Provisions) Bill, will allow for the transfer of public companies' assets and liabilities to the new statutory authority.

Let us look at some of the areas that will be enhanced by these Bills. There are six areas altogether, but I do not wish to touch on them all. I will touch on, firstly, the objective of the establishment of the Institute; secondly, the functions of the Institute; and, thirdly, the powers of the Institute. I pose the question: What are the objectives of the Australian Institute of Sport? They are about providing resources, services and facilities. Those three areas in themselves are extremely important because without them a number of people would not be able, especially in this day and age, to afford the high costs associated with training for long periods. By providing those resources, services and facilities, the young men and women of Australia will now be able to pursue actively and, I am certain, will achieve their goals in life. It does not stop there. While those sports men and women are out in the sporting arenas achieving their goals, what happens to their educational and vocational skills and their personal achievements? The Institute provides for its athletes in those areas. I believe that the introduction of these Bills will make the running of the Institute a lot smoother.

The other major benefit that the Bill addresses is the coaching aspect. I think the coaching aspect was touched on earlier in the debate by my colleague, the honourable member for Perth (Dr Charlesworth). This area is also very important, for without good coaching methods it is very hard for our future stars to shine. It will enhance all levels of sports throughout Australia. It is fast becoming recognised that improved coaching methods improve performance. This is relevant when we look at the area of top grade sportsmen. Not only is it important for coaching methods for top grade coaches, it is also necessary for coaches in levels from junior school sport to those just below top grade. It is common knowledge that, as we progress through time, our athletes are becoming faster and stronger. Although when we look at the area of, say, junior sport, if improved coaching methods are available it may foster a young child who shows potential in a sport, but if those methods were not available the child may go unnoticed. I believe it is extremely important to foster this potential. A few years ago, sports medicine and research was not rated as highly as it is now. It is pleasing to see that the Government has seen fit to provide further assistance in these areas.

I would like to bring to the attention of honourable members a news clip that I saw not long ago. It relates to the areas of sports medicine and research. It stated that young sports men and women were most susceptible to knee injury during their growing years, around 13 to 18 years of age. It went on to say that at this young age, while playing a contact sport, they could, without any doubt, stop these injuries if they wore a support piece on their knee. This is because at that age their tendons, ligaments and bones are not fully developed. Someone in the early 20s may not be as prone to such an injury. That is just one area where research and sports medicine is so valuable.
Everybody recognises the importance of competition. Competition will bring out the best in everybody. I draw honourable members' attention to clause 6, sub-clause (2), which states:

In performing the function referred to in paragraph (1) (a), the Institute may conduct sporting events for the purpose of providing opportunities for persons participating in programs referred to in that paragraph to compete in sport against each other and against other persons.

This clause is self-explanatory. As I have just said, competition brings out the best. As the Institute will bring out competition from overseas, so our athletes will benefit. Not only will our athletes benefit; other sections of the community will benefit also. The Bill also makes specific reference to community access. The community in general has always had access to the Institute. The Institute does not belong just to those Australians who have excelled or who have the potential to excel.

I turn now to clause 7 of the Bill, which is entitled `Powers of Institute'. The wide-ranging powers in the areas referred to in that clause are very important for they will facilitate the smooth running of the Australian Institute of Sport. It is also important that the Institute operate within the framework of the Government's overall sports development objectives and policies. It must be stated that it is very important for the Institute to promote itself in the best way possible. The Bill outlines the ways in which the Institute can conduct its activities. There are two areas that I feel are very important. I draw the attention of honourable members to clause 7 (1) (e) which states in whole that the Institute may `provide scholarships and other like benefits'.

I feel that sometimes it is perceived that those top sportsmen and sportswomen have a life of luxury just having to do some running and weightlifting and some less demanding training and that they have ample time available to themselves. We all appreciate that that is not true. Without the provision of scholarships we could just say of those people that they are fit, but being fit in body will not endow them with what they need for the rest of their lives. I feel it is extremely important to be fit in body and in mind. The provision of scholarships will enable these people to become professionally equipped to handle the rest of their working lives. By applying their time to sport and to the educational side of things, their development must and will improve.
I turn to paragraph (h) of clause 7, which states that the Institute may:
obtain commercial sponsorship for the Institute and participate in marketing arrangements involving the endorsement by the Institute of products and services associated with sport;

That is a very salient paragraph indeed, because it is important, as the Institute is Australia's prime sporting hall, that we should make sure that the rest of the Australian community knows of the facilities that exist. Today millions of dollars every year go into Australian sport by way of commercial sponsorships. A couple of examples are, of course, the sponsorship of cricket by Castlemaine-Tooheys Ltd along with that of the Benson and Hedges Co. Pty Ltd, which also sponsors the Australian Ballet. To the best of my knowledge, from viewing New South Wales television, the Institute has been able to gain some marketing ground through television advertisements. I refer to a commercial promoting a breakfast cereal in which the Institute's facilities are used. I understand that this is only one way in which the Institute has become involved, but there may well be different advertisements in other States promoting the Institute along with a product from those States.

In the time remaining to me, I wish to address my comments to sub-clause (2) of clause 7. Hundreds of sports men and women would be able to improve their performance in their respective fields if they had access to the Institute's facilities and programs. The community will have access to these facilities. Community access is a very important part of the Institute's programs. Fees will be charged for the community's use of the Institute's facilities and its programs. The Bill also allows for community input into events arranged by the Institute. I point out that it is intended that the fees to be charged will be reasonable.

The last part of the clause I wish to canvass is sub-clause (3) and that is a welcome inclusion. It states that the Institute may exercise its powers inside and outside Australia. Suffice it to say that the most important part of that sub-clause is that which relates to the Institute's powers outside Australia, especially when sports people go overseas falsely representing Australia under the guise of being representatives from the Australian Institute of Sport. I commend both Bills to the House and I commend the Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism (Mr John Brown)for his handling of the Australian Institute of Sport.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dobie The Hon J.D.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the amendment moved by the Opposition with respect to the Australian Institute of Sport Bill. I believe that a debate such as the one we are having in the House tonight will not take place in the future if we adopt the suggestion that the Australian Institute of Sport should be answerable to the Australian Sports Commission and not directly to the Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism and, therefore, directly to the Parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: I congratulate the Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism (Mr John Brown) for his genuine interest in sport and its problems. Of course, he has a few problems-he supports the wrong football team in Sydney, although we mostly forgive him for that. However, I believe-I say this without any feeling of ill-will-that the problems he had last year with the Australian Institute of Sport, problems which I think most Ministers holding that portfolio would have had, would not have been resolved as satisfactorily as they have been had we not had the capacity to raise these matters in the House. I have some concern that with the Bill now before the House we will be moving away from the capacity to bring matters before the public, via this Parliament, following a Press report.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is the exact opposite.

—It is not the exact opposite. It is exactly what would happen in the future. I will be very brief in my speech, but the second point I wish to make concerns the fact that, although we are objecting to the legislation, that must not be interpreted, as it has been by certain members of the Government, as showing a lack of interest in sport and the problems and difficulties associated with sport. I listened with great interest to the honourable member for Perth (Dr Charlesworth) who, with his own splendid-in fact, outstanding-sporting record, has a good background in this area. A lot of what he said was very good and very strong. But, again, I was very disappointed to hear him speaking about the lack of interest in sport on the part of those opposite. This is particularly disappointing when the promotion of his own sport, which has now been decentralised from Canberra to Perth, was due entirely to a Liberal government. I refer in the first place to a Liberal government in Western Australia using its Bicentenary donation from the Federal Government for a hockey sporting complex in Perth, and, secondly, to the development of the Australian Institute of Sport here through Liberal legislation.
—He has a convenient memory.

—It is obviously a convenient memory. I was very pleased also to hear the honourable member for Perth say that he had no objection to the commercial sponsorship of the Institute of Sport. As far as I know this is the first occasion on which he has come forward with such a statement, and I welcome it.

SPEECH.PARA: I wanted only to say a few things about the fact that I believe we are moving away from parliamentary interest in sport by this legislation. No matter what may be said by the Government on this occasion, the reality is that matters will not be brought before the Parliament through a statutory authority with the same ease that would apply if the Institute had a greater responsibility to the Minister-a Minister who, as I have already said, has a great and compelling interest in sport which is much admired by the sporting community around Australia. I believe the sporting community will be somewhat confused by this legislation, which proposes to move the Institute of Sport away from the Minister's control.

I am one of the lucky members in this place who have had certain associations with the Institute-not as a sportsman, I am quick to point out. I know it is hard for honourable members to believe-it is a fact that I have a difficulty in maintaining the sporting image-but there it is. I have had contacts with several of the activities at the Institute of Sport.

TALK.START.PARA: —A former star beach sprinter.
—Wrestling.

—I hear the compliments flying, but I do not care to acknowledge them. I pay a great tribute to the coaches at the Institute. I was very attracted to the idea raised by the honourable member for Perth that the satellite coaching scheme should be given some impetus and should be developed with great urgency and great care. I pay tribute to a group I know very well at the Institute, namely, the men's basketball section. I pay tribute to Adrian Hurley, Patrick Hunt and Philip Smyth for the tremendous work they have done through the Institute in raising the standard of basketball, not just at the international level but at the club level throughout this country. They have a very interesting scheme. They are not interested in basketball `bums', as they call them; they want their sportsmen to have interests other than the sporting program they are following at the Institute. This style of program whereby those who have the scholarships are required to study or work for a minimum of 12 hours a week, is something that should be very much encouraged and publicised. In fact, the general public is not basically aware of the study and work demands on the students who gain the scholarships. Therefore in this brief speech I pay tribute to the coaches and to the programs that they introduce.

SPEECH.PARA: Other honourable members have talked about the problems of administration and direction. I do not criticise any of the people holding office at the Australian Institute of Sport, but I believe that, as with most new departments, the problem is one of ministerial direction-or in this case administrative direction. Exactly the same thing happened when the Federal Education Department was created some years ago. The reason it did not fall into a trap was that it remained a department, totally answerable to this place for all its items of expenditure. I am concerned that in the movement that is contained in the Bill before the House tonight, we are moving into a new area of administrative problems. We will not be able to examine these problems closely or in a critical and constructive manner.

In conclusion I must put in one plug-heaven knows, I have been trying for this for long enough. I would like to have rugby league included in the AIS as a sport that is worthy of great encouragement. I know that the Minister thinks that it does not need any coaching as a result of representations he has had from Parramatta and those other western suburbs clubs, but in our area around Cronulla we feel a great need for this great national-yea this great international-sport to be encouraged at the Institute with some training programs. Heaven knows, it has included soccer and I suppose it has a certain international flavour as well.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about Aussie rules?
—Honourable members keep mentioning strange words which I do not understand.
—What about Australian rules?

—Australian rules-that is better. It is a good sport. I hope that it will not be long before the AIS comes to the party and decides-as I know it wants to-to include rugby league as one of the vital sports in the important States of this country.

SPEECH.PARA: I wish to finish my speech by saying that I appreciate the tributes that have been paid here to Frank Stewart, Professor Bloomfield, Dr Coles and Bob Ellicott. Party politics aside, I hope that these names will be remembered for many long years as people who did much to bring Federal politics into the sponsorship of sport which had long been wanted in this country. I cannot see our sport going any further without continuation of that activity and, more importantly, that interest. However, we need more than just interest in our own local teams. It is all very well for those of us who are keen on rugby league to attend our club's matches every week and be thoroughly entertained and inspired, but we must go beyond that. We must consider those sports which do not have universal appeal and which do not claim large audiences-those sports which provide great activity and interest to a large number of participants but do not have the audience that Australian rules has, that rugby league sometimes has and that rugby union occasionally has. We must take a broad view here. I lament the passing of the capacity of this Parliament to examine critically the administrative problems which will face the Institute of Sport in the coming years. When one talks to the people at the Institute one realises that they are very conscious of the problem that will face them. If I can be reluctant and enthusiastic at the same time, I am reluctant that the Institute of Sport has become the topic of a party political debate--

TALK.START.PARA: —It should not have.

—It should not have, as the Minister says. But unfortunately, I say to the Minister that, in regard to the legislation that he has brought before this House, those of us who wish this Institute to be still answerable to this House for its expenditure must oppose the Bill and support the amendment to the motion for the second reading put forward by the honourable member for McPherson (Mr White).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Charles Mr D.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have great pleasure in supporting the Australian Institute of Sport Bill. I point out to the previous speaker, the honourable member for Cook (Mr Dobie), what the Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism (Mr John Brown) said in his second reading speech:

SPEECH.PARA: The legislation will ensure appropriate accountability to the government of the day and, through it, to this Parliament.

In contrast to what the previous speaker said, this legislation, by setting up a statutory authority under the provisions that have been spoken about, particularly by the honourable member for Fowler (Mr Grace), will put the Australian Institute of Sport on the footing it should have had before this day. Like all other major statutory authorities, it will be responsible to the Minister and the government of the day and, through it, the Parliament, which can oversee the workings and operations of that statutory authority. In contrast to what the honourable member for Cook said-in fact, what most members of the Opposition have said throughout this debate-we on this side of the House believe that accountability will be one of the pluses of this legislation.

Throughout this debate many members, including the honourable member for McPherson (Mr White) and the honourable member for Sturt (Mr Wilson), have suggested that they do not like this legislation. However, with the exception of the honourable member for Cook, and I disagreed with him, no one including the honourable member for McPherson and the honourable member for Sturt, said why he disagreed with the setting up of the statutory authority or what dreadful things it would do. Let us look at the amendment that has been moved to the motion for the second reading. The last sentence reads:
the proposed Institute of Sport could well be performed by an existing body.
It does not say `the existing body', it says `an existing body'. What existing body?

TALK.START.PARA: —The Sports Commission, for the tenth time!
—That is not contained in the honourable member's amendment. Is that the next amendment that will be moved?
—Can't you hear?

—I do not care what the honourable member is saying now. It is not contained in the amendment. Are we supposed to guess what his brain waves are? The amendment says `an existing body'. I am quite sure that the honourable member could sit here all day and come up with a different body every five minutes. The fact is that he does not know what he is doing. As the Minister interjected during the speech by the honourable member for Cook, it should not have become a political debate, but the Opposition has attempted to force one for no reason. Throughout this debate today at no stage has one good reason been brought forward to suggest that this legislation should not be passed, as it will.

SPEECH.PARA: The Institute of Sport was the brainchild of Frank Stewart in 1973. It was eventually picked up by the Fraser Government through Bob Ellicott, who was very energetic and enthusiastic about the project. It eventually got off the ground and came into operation in 1981. I am glad that the present Minister was appointed in 1983 because he is not only a sports enthusiast but also a knowledgeable person. He has brought many good things to the portfolio and has moved the Institute along. Funding for sport and the Institute have trebled in the time of this Government. The planning and programs that the Institute has brought into operation have expanded greatly over the last few years. The national training centre program and the visiting athletes program are just two of those. Last year over 1,000 athletes came here for tuition under the visiting athletes program.

The national training centre program is more for the elite-the international standard athletes. So far this financial year 52 sports have participated in the program with 2,200 athletes and coaches attending 105 training camps. This shows the extent of the programs and the good that is being done amongst our sport generally, not only in the elite area but right across the board. The Institute is planning all sorts of extensions in its programs to enable people who are less well off to participate in its activities.

As the honourable member for Perth (Dr Charlesworth) mentioned earlier, the sports medicine centre or science centre of the Institute is one of the best in the world. Sports medicine throughout the world has really leaped ahead in recent years. It is good to see that Australia has caught up rapidly in this area in the last few years. It has been marvellous to see the amount of money that has been put into sports medicine research in this country. Australia has benefited greatly; again, not only in the international sporting area but throughout the community. The benefits apply not only to sport but also to daily life. We are at last beginning to realise the many things, such as better nutrition, that flow from sports medicine research. As I said earlier, the Institute's sports medicine centre, which is one of the best in Australia, is becoming one of the best set-ups in the world. I congratulate the Institute on that. I am sure that it will move to bigger and better things.

A number of State institutes are now feeding into the national sports Institute, and this is very good to see. I am sorry to say that I do not believe the Victorian State Government has done as much for sport in Victoria as it should have done. It is one State that has not moved in that direction yet, although I must congratulate that Government for the fact that it is about to sponsor the national tennis centre, which will involve over $50m. Let us hope that that project comes off and is a success. I was also pleased to read recently that the Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism disagreed quite strongly with the collective wisdom of the State Ministers in regard to police intervention on the sporting field, whether it be football, basketball or any other sport. I agreed with the Federal Minister's comments. It is disastrous to have police running on to the grounds with pencil and pad trying to charge people with offences. If that practice is adopted, Australian sports will take us a step backward into the last century. Such an incident should never have been allowed to occur. The Leigh Matthews incident that occurred in Victoria last year was a disgrace and the political pontificating at that time by the Victorian Minister for Police and Emergency Services, Mr Race Mathews, was nothing short of disgraceful. I am glad to see that the Federal Minister disagrees strongly with all the State Ministers in that regard.
The national sports Institute has come a long way in a very short time. It has moved from covering eight sports to covering, I think, around 13.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is already 13.

—There are already 13 sports. There are plans for more sports to be involved and for the decentralisation of sports. It takes a certain amount of time for the benefits to flow through, not only to the international area but also throughout the community. In the next decade we will see the fruits of our efforts, in particular the efforts of this Government, which has trebled the funds for the Institute over the last three years. We will continue, on a genuine basis-unlike the previous Government-to assist our sporting people at the elite level and throughout the community. I am sure that we will see other programs emanating from this Government in the next few years to assist with the sport and recreation facilities of this country.

DEBATE.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN INSTITUTE OF SPORT BILL 1986[COGNATE BILL:AUSTRALIAN INSTITUTE OF SPORT (CONSEQUENTIAL PROVISIONS) BILL 1986]

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed.

DEBATE.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN INSTITUTE OF SPORT BILL 1986

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nehl Mr G.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —At the outset I would like to say that I am very pleased to have the opportunity of seconding the amendment which was moved by the honourable member for McPherson (Mr White) earlier today. In his speech he put the case very succinctly and very well for opposing the provision that the Australian Institute of Sport be changed from a public company to a statutory authority. He made it very clear that there was absolutely no necessity to do this because sporting bodies in this country are not asking for it and virtually no one in the sporting world wants it.

SPEECH.PARA: The trouble is that we have far too many statutory authorities in the country already. Just a very quick glance at the list of statutory authorities of the Commonwealth, which was published by the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations in October 1984, reveals that we have over 400 statutory authorities already and that, of course, does not include the various subsidiary companies. In the 12 months to October 1985 another 31 statutory authorities were created. We do not need any more. We need fewer statutory authorities, less bureaucracy and less expenditure.

This does not mean to say that I, and I am sure everybody on the Opposition side of this House, do not applaud the work of the Institute of Sport. I for one think it has done a marvellous job. I will not attempt to repeat what the honourable member for Groom (Mr McVeigh) said. He went through the workings of the Institute in very great detail and made an excellent statement on the work that it is doing. It is very satisfying that the $80m of facilities and the $14m budget are being used to assist Australian sportsmen and sportswomen.

The shadow Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism, the honourable member for McPherson, made it very clear in his speech that the Australian Sports Commission, which has a Board of up to 20, is quite capable of doing the job. At the present time this is a confusing situation in the sporting world. There is duplication. We have the Department of Sport, Recreation and Tourism, the Sports Commission and the Institute of Sport. If the Institute of Sport becomes a statutory authority, Board membership will comprise a full time or part time chairman, who will be appointed for five years, a deputy chairman who will also be appointed full time or part time for five years and no fewer than seven or no more than 11 other directors who will be appointed for three years. They can all be full time or part time directors. Excluding the Director of the Institute, who is ex-officio on the Board, there would be a minimum of nine members on the Board and a maximum of 13.

The honourable member for McPherson in moving the amendment made it very clear, in a very polite and sensitive way, that this opened the opportunity for political patronage. I will put it a little more vulgarly and say that it provides the opportunity for jobs for the boys and possibly jobs for the girls too. I know that the Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism (Mr John Brown), a man whom I like and respect-I know he is sincere in doing his job for sport-would not be involved in any form of political patronage of this kind. Nonetheless, the opportunity is there. I do not believe that it is right or correct that this Parliament should further enlarge the opportunities for jobs for the boys.

I would like to make some reference to the comments of the honourable member for Macarthur (Mr Martin). He is a very pleasant young man, very earnest and very sincere. The trouble is that he is misguided because he completely confused the issue with this amendment. He said that the amendment opposed the statutory authority and offered nothing in its place. Of course, the honourable member for Isaacs (Mr Charles) who spoke before me, also obviously did not hear the honourable member for McPherson's speech because the shadow Minister made it totally and completely clear that he believed the Australian Sports Commission would do the job. I just remind the House that that amendment reads, in part:

. . . the House is of the opinion that the Bill should not be proceeded with as it does nothing more than add to the burgeoning number of statutory authorities already in existence when the functions of the proposed Institute of Sport could well be performed by an existing body.

The honourable member for McPherson made it very clear that that existing body was the Australian Sports Commission. The honourable member for Macarthur said that the Institute needed to be independent. But it becomes quite clear, when we read the Bill and the explanatory notes that, under the new system, the Institute would be completely under the thumb of the Minister. I will just read some of the words in the explanatory memorandum. It states:
Clause 11 . . . Enables the Minister to give written directions on any matter to the Board and ensures that the Board must comply with them.
Clause 12 . . . Requires the Board to prepare and implement strategic plans for the Institute's operations.
That is a good thing. The explanatory memorandum continues:
The first plan is to cover a 3 years period commencing on a day occurring within 12 months of the commencement of the Act.
Clause 13 . . . Provides for Ministerial approval of the Institute's strategic plans.
Clause 14 . . . Allows the Board to vary the strategic plan, subject to Ministerial approval.

I think that reinforces the point made that the Institute will be under the thumb of the Minister. As the honourable member for Sturt (Mr Wilson) said, the Institute would be under the day to day control of the Minister.

The honourable member for Macarthur praised the Institute of Sport and grudgingly admitted that it was established by the coalition Government. But, instead of being a little gracious about that, he said that it was just a knee jerk reaction to the lack of medals at the previous Olympics. I think he could have been just a little more generous. Of course, the honourable member for Fowler (Mr Grace) also grudgingly said: `Bob Ellicott pushed the Fraser Government into it'. But we cannot escape the fact that the Fraser Government established the Institute of Sport. I would just like to make it very clear that we too praise the staff and the coaches for the great job that they are doing.

The honourable member for Macarthur made mention also of the five Australian Institute of Sport swimmers who won medals in 1984. He mentioned Robert de Castella, the soccer players and the tennis players and I support him in what he said about them. They have done a marvellous job, and those associated with the Institute have also done a marvellous job. But in bringing in that matter and failing to address the question of the amendment, the honourable member is obscuring the real issue. The real issue is the question of management and administration. We on this side of the House want the Australian Institute of Sport to continue to be successful. We want it to go on to bigger and better things. But increasing the number of statutory authorities will not do it, and jobs for the boys will not do it either.

The honourable member for Macarthur claimed that we on this side of the House opposed the Australian Sports Aid Foundation. We support very definitely the method of getting more funding for sport, but we oppose the setting up of another board to do it. There are up to 20 board members on the Sports Commission and 22 staff. I think there are six or seven-I do not think anybody really knows at this stage-on the Sports Aid Foundation Board and, of course, now we are going to have 13, 15 or whatever it is on the Board of the Institute of Sport.

The next speaker for the Government was the honourable member for Perth (Dr Charlesworth). I say in passing that I have great respect for him as a great Australian sportsman. I think his contribution to sport in this country has been quite magnificent. He made some reference to the Institute as being, I think, fortress Bruce. He agreed that there was a need for streamlining in its administration and a need to move out of Canberra and decentralise its activities. I support him in his suggestion that this should happen. He also said that this fantastic facility should be available for national teams more than it is at present and that 40 groups use it now. He spoke at length on the coaching provided and the sports development grants and the achieve- ments of the Institute in sports medicine. This is all great. It is tremendous. I endorse every word he said, but he missed the point of the amendment. All we are seeking to do is to support the work of the Institute of Sport, to continue to give it every possible support, but we want to reduce bureaucracy. For heaven's sake, in the last few days we have had talk from the Treasurer (Mr Keating) about banana republics and third rate economies. We are entering straitened financial circumstances. We are entering a period when we have to tighten our national belt. We will not do that by creating new statutory authorities ad infinitum. We have a responsibility to the people of Australia to reduce bureaucracy, waste and expenditure. I support the amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon J.J.

TALKER.NAME: Mr JOHN BROWN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism)

TALK.START.PARA: —I guess that in some ways I am winding up this debate on the Australian Institute of Sport Bill 1986 and the Australian Institute of Sport (Consequential Provisions) Bill 1986. The amendment moved by the shadow Minister, the honourable member for McPherson (Mr White), suggests that no statutory authority should be set up and that the Australian Institute of Sport should remain in its present role.
—Not as a public company, but under the control of the Australian Sports Commission.

—Not as a public company, but under the control of the Australian Sports Commission. What we are doing with this legislation, which seeks to turn the AIS into a statutory authority, is not a case of establishing a new statutory authority but merely converting the existing unsatisfactory expedient company status of the AIS into that of a properly constituted statutory authority created by the Parliament rather than, as exists now, by Executive prerogative. I would have thought that the proper role for this Parliament was to see that public moneys are properly supervised. The views that have been expressed by various members of the Opposition tonight strike me as being very odd. The honourable member for McPherson wanted more restrictions on management. That is reasonable. The honourable member for Sturt (Mr Wilson) wanted freedom similar to that of academic institutions for the Institute of Sport to roam free in whatever direction it wanted.

SPEECH.PARA: I would have thought that the difficulties which the AIS encountered-which I freely admit-at the end of last year were a product of the fact that its public company status gave me as Minister and certainly Parliament no proper purview. It is not a matter of trying to form another statutory authority merely for the sake of having another. It is a matter of ensuring that the Institute of Sport, whose achievements I am pleased to note have been the subject of congratulations from honourable members on both sides of the House tonight, is properly under the purview of the Parliament. We are not trying to do anything sinister in terms of extending the already extensive range of statutory authorities. We are merely seeing that the AIS performs according to the view and demands of the Parliament.

Another oddity I find is the demand by the shadow Minister that the AIS should be under the control of the Australian Sports Commission. I disagree with that proposal thoroughly for a number of reasons which I will elucidate shortly. It strikes me as being very odd that the shadow Minister would demand that the AIS come under the control of the Sports Commission because on 16 May his predecessor as the shadow Minister, the honourable member for Richmond (Mr Blunt), opposed the Australian Sports Commission Bill on the basis of the Opposition's `fundamental philosophy in view of its role and responsibility of government'. He indicated that a coalition government would establish in lieu of the ASC an advisory body with no administrative role. I note that the existing Opposition policy on sport states:

A Coalition Government would re-institute a Federal body to be an independent adviser on sport and recreation. It would be representative of national sporting organisations and charged with providing the forum to stimulate national levels of participation and achievement of sport and recreation.

This body would be autonomous and advise the Government of long term policies and programs to develop the diverse needs of the Australian community at all levels. It would not have an administrative role.

That is greatly at odds with the Opposition's new proposition that the Australian Sports Commission should be given even greater powers and should control the functions and day to day running of the Australian Institute of Sport. What does the Opposition want?

TALK.START.PARA: —I will tell you in a minute.

—It is about time the honourable member did. I have noticed the varying strands of opinion that have come out tonight; maybe this great new policy the honourable member is about to tell us about might clear it up.
—Haven't you got the new policy?

—No, but I have the tourism one. I notice the Opposition released it, to save me doing so. The Opposition has to realise that the Institute of Sport has a very specialised day to day role, developing sports persons and coaches and managing substantial facilities for sporting, recreational, general entertainment and other community activities. That huge amount of property now under the control of the Institute of Sport must require a special body to run it. It could not possibly be run by the Australian Sports Commission, which has an entirely different role. The Sports Commission should not get bogged down with oversighting day to day operations such as running swimming pools and providing facilities for pop concerts. It should not risk being side-tracked from the important overall roles it is already performing. The ASC, being a relatively new body, has yet much to achieve, and I might say that in its short history it has achieved a great deal. Certainly we cannot agree that the Sports Commission should be undertaking the overall day to day running of the Institute of Sport.

SPEECH.PARA: The suggestions the Opposition makes are a fairly gratuitous insult to the hard working AIS Board, which comprises outstanding people. That is particularly the case when it is suggested that my motives are to extend political patronage into Australian sport. I would have thought that the people I have appointed to that Board were sufficiently well known and sufficiently respected in their own right to be insulted with any suggestion of political patronage. We propose with the statutory authority to move away from any form of political patronage. That has certainly been my view in the running of my Department since I have been Minister. In fact, the large amounts of money that are given to sporting organisations in Australia are now allocated by an independent authority and I have not yet, in two Budgets, altered one decision it has made. There is no longer any possibility of political patronage, with some sport that I favour being given money. That Board of 20 commissioners of the Australian Sports Commission expended $8m last year and something like that this year in a way that had no interference whatever from me. That is exactly the way it should be.

I notice that again the shadow Minister has raised the matter of the Price Waterhouse report, casting doubts on its validity. I would have thought that Price Waterhouse would have been considered in enlightened enough terms by everybody in this House for nobody to cast aspersions on its propriety. It was a poor reflection upon that company when the honourable member suggested that it should not have been asked to do it.

TALK.START.PARA: —You should not have put them in that position.

—Price Waterhouse volunteered to do it, and it produced a report which was furnished in this Parliament to everybody's satisfaction except the honourable member's. It seems to be a great disappointment to him that it uncovered no sign of dishonesty, impropriety or illegality. I think most people, especially the speakers in this debate tonight, are happy with the report. In particular, two former Ministers spoke glowingly of the Institute of Sport and I am sure they are happy that the report proved what it did.
—It proved that there were some inefficiencies, though.

—Nobody is suggesting there were not inefficiencies, and that is exactly why we are moving to a statutory authority-to allow this Parliament to have a greater purview of the public moneys that are being expended at the Institute of Sport. I think the mismanagements to which the honourable member pointed were fairly understandable, given that suddenly the Institute of Sport Board was given the function of looking after not just the running of the Institute but also the whole of the physical facilities associated with that area at Bruce. It is quite understandable that at that stage, very early in its career, it could have run into a few minor management problems. They have all been solved to everybody's satisfaction, and the House will be pleased to note that the Budget of the AIS will come up in a better than balanced position-in fact, in a positive position-although maybe at the halfway mark it was running behind. That is fairly normal practice in most businesses and I cannot see anything terribly sinister about that.

SPEECH.PARA: I find it quite disturbing that once again the shadow Minister has come in here tonight and given me a negative, carping, miserable, defeatist speech on sport. It is a matter of great pleasure to me that other Opposition speakers adopted a much more positive view. It is a great pity that this basically apolitical area-in which I ran as shadow Minister for three years and had only one argument with the Government in that period, and that was over the attempted boycott of the Moscow games-has now become the subject of contentious, political debate. It is disillusioning to sporting bodies around Australia who believe sport to be apolitical.

TALK.START.PARA: —So, if we agree with you, that is all right.

—No, I am not saying that. I am saying that the honourable member could adopt a more positive attitude to what we are trying to do in sport. If he takes a dispassionate look at his colleagues' miserable record towards sport in 30 years of government and compares it with what has happened in the last three years, perhaps he will take a more positive view. Certainly a positive view was taken by the honourable member for Groom (Mr McVeigh) and by the honourable member for Sturt-and certainly if the Hon. Bob Ellicott were here he would adopt the same view.

SPEECH.PARA: Things are happening in sport now that never happened before. I am inundated every day with letters from surf clubs. In three years the surf club grant has gone from $200,000 to over $1m. It has gone to the most noble of the sporting bodies in Australia. For the first time ever disabled athletes in Australia have $1m with which to fund their activities. The Institute of Sport has had its budget doubled. The Australian Sports Commission has now introduced Aussie Sports, which I venture to say is the most inventive, imaginative and useful sports policy that any government has ever invested in in Australia. We shall now have the prospect that every child in Australia, no matter what his or her sporting inadequacy, will be involved in some form of sporting participation, because this Government has been able to get the State governments and education departments in every State to agree to include the Aussie Sports program as part of the core curriculum in schools.

In regard to the Sports Aid Foundation, about which I was asked a question earlier, Sir Peter Abeles certainly has accepted membership of that Board. The information received by the honourable member for McPherson was probably a couple of days old. It is only in the last couple of days that Sir Peter has accepted a position on the Board. The Board is composed of Mr Ted Harris, Sir Donald Trescowthick, Herb Elliott, Kevan Gosper, Kerry Packer, Nick Whitlam and Sir Peter Abeles. I doubt that anybody could put together a board of more respectable and more capable people.

TALK.START.PARA: —How much is that going to cost?

—It is not going to cost anything. I am sure the honourable member for O'Connor will be pleased to learn that these honourable persons have decided that they will accept no fees, no travelling allowances-no expenses whatever-in pursuit of this task. In their four weeks of operation they have put more than half a million dollars through the sports aid campaign for the Commonwealth Games and also for the America's Cup challenge. That is a product of this Government having the guts to introduce tax deductibility for contributions to sport.

SPEECH.PARA: I make no apology for the Government's record in sport. I am appalled that the honourable member for McPherson, for whom I have a high regard in many ways, does not take a more positive attitude towards sport. We are certainly not above criticism, but if he were to take a dispassionate view of what this legislation is all about he would see that it seeks to make the Australian Institute of Sport more responsible and more answerable to this Parliament. That is the way it should be. We reject the Opposition's amendment out of hand.
Question put:
That the words proposed to be omitted (Mr White's amendment) stand part of the question.

Oringinal question resolved in the affirmative.
