Clause 42, page 15 (lines 41 to 44) and page 16 (lines 1 to 6), omit the clause.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: White Mr P.N.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the interests of time I just wish to make a few points in response to the Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism (Mr John Brown). I make a point that has been made again and again during this debate, that we on this side of the House strongly support the Australian Institute of Sport, but are totally against the setting up of yet another statutory authority to administer it when there is already in existence an authority which is quite capable of administering it and when most of the members of that authority want to take that responsibility on board. This is not a degradation of the existing Board. Acknowledgment of all its work over the years has been made time and time again in this House.

SPEECH.PARA: We are saying that, particularly in the economic climate in which we are working, there is no need for another statutory authority. Although a board is in place, this is an opportunity to reduce by one the number of statutory authorities for which there is absolutely no need. I make the point in regard to the Price Waterhouse report that it is not a reflection on the company, which has done good work. I am saying that the Minister should not have put that company in the position where it had to investigate itself.

In conclusion, I wish to say that we on this side of the House wish the Institute well. We want to see it go from strength to strength. It has already established a massive reputation in this country and overseas. We want to see it administered efficiently. As the honourable member for Perth (Dr Charlesworth) said in a very good speech, we want to see it broaden its approach to sport in this country. We do not want to see it unduly handicapped and we do not want to see it being run by yet another statutory authority.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon J.J.

TALKER.NAME: Mr JOHN BROWN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism)

TALK.START.PARA: —The shadow Minister, the honourable member for McPherson (Mr White), hoped that the Australian Institute of Sport would go from strength to strength. Let me forecast two initiatives which will take place. Two new sports will be introduced in the Institute of Sport this year. I can assure the House that as a positive step towards improving the sporting facilities available to the depressed black African people of South Africa we will be inviting four or five black South African coaches to the Institute of Sport on a scholarship this year. We will try to send them back to improve the lot of that very depressed majority of black people of South Africa. The honourable member may rest assured that the Institute will go from strength to strength. That in fact, will be the case.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak following the debate we have just had on the Australian Institute of Sport and its future. I rise to talk about a sporting event that in fact is now taking place in my own electorate. Of course, I refer to the sixth world three-day event which will be attended by the Opposition spokesman on sport, recreation and tourism, the honourable member for McPherson (Mr White), on Saturday in the city of Gawler in the electorate of Wakefield.

SPEECH.PARA: Yesterday I attended the opening of the sixth world three-day event. The opening was held at Roseworthy Agricultural College, a prestigious agriculture tertiary education institution situated in the town of Roseworthy since 1883. Roseworthy College occupies 1,200 hectares of land. There, in front of the grand old college building, stood the eight teams from around the world who were to participate in this sixth world three-day event. They appeared before His Royal Highness Prince Philip. Each stood in front of a flag pole from which the flag of the appropriate nation was unfurled while the national anthem of that nation was played. I must say that it was a proud moment for everyone who stood there to witness that ceremony and the pomp and splendour that surrounded it.

While we sit here in this House there are teams from New Zealand, Germany, Canada, Great Britain, France, Ireland, the United States of America and Australia participating in this horse event. I make the point that in fact this is the first occasion on which there has been such a world equestrian event held in the Southern Hemisphere. Why should that be so? It is simply because the quarantine restrictions maintained in this island of Australia are so rigid that it has not been possible to have an event of this size in this nation before. As honourable members will appreciate, simply airlifting a horse from the United Kingdom to Australia can cost up to $30,000. There have been strict quarantine provisions enforced at Torrens Island in the electorate of the honourable member for Port Adelaide (Mr Young), who is the Leader of the House. There will be 10,000 overseas visitors in South Australia for this Jubilee 150 event. That is more people than were involved in the famous Grand Prix, which was also a part of our State's Jubilee 150 celebrations. The cost of the event is being shared by sponsors and the South Australian Government, which has underwritten the event. I gladly concede that that Government has been aided by a $98,000 community employment program grant from the Commonwealth Government.

The event will involve dressage competitions which are taking place today and tomorrow, followed on Saturday by the most spectacular cross-country course event, which is the heart of three-day eventing, and the show jumping on Sunday. By any standards this is a prestigious event. After the Grand Prix it is the largest event to be held in South Australia and it warrants the attention of the Federal Parliament. Unfortunately the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) was in China and was unable to be present at the opening of the event, and I suppose that for that reason the Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Lionel Bowen) found it inappropriate to be there too. I regret that the Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism (Mr John Brown) also found it impossible to attend, for some reason, and what was quite unforgiveable was that I was the sole member of the Federal Parliament present when Prince Philip opened that event yesterday. Where was the Government? Where were the back benchers? Where were the Australian Labor Party senators? This week the Senate has not been sitting. Would it really have been too much for the Government to have requested one South Australian senator to represent it at what will be a key event in South Australia's Jubilee 150 celebrations? Where were the ALP senators at this key event? Why has the Government chosen to snub South Australia--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

—In answering the question put to the House by the previous speaker, the honourable member for Wakefield (Mr Andrew), probably they were all out training for that big event that will be held throughout Australia-the Run Against Time organised by Sports Aid. I will be running in that event on Sunday and I hope that any other members who happen to be in Canberra this weekend will join me for the run, which begins outside Parliament House at 9 a.m.
—They will not join you. They could not last the distance, but you can make it, Ros.

—I do not know about that; I would not put my money on it! However, I do not wish to speak about that matter tonight. I wish to discuss the program of the United Nations Children's Fund to immunise the world's children by 1990 against six vaccine-preventable diseases which are currently killing more than three million children each year. It is estimated that vaccine-preventable diseases kill a total of 3,450,000 children each year in the developing world and a similar number are crippled or handicapped. About 58 per cent, or two million, of these deaths are caused by measles. Tetanus is responsible for about 803,000 deaths and whooping cough for a further 606,000 deaths. The toll is as heavy for those who survive. If immunisation remains at today's levels then polio, to take just one example, will paralyse for life about 2.5 million children over the next 10 years. This should be of concern to everyone in this Parliament and throughout Australia. There is no doubt that in the past 18 months several nations have doubled and trebled their levels of immunisation against vaccine-preventable diseases which have been killing so many children each year. Throughout 1985 world-wide demand for vaccines has been running at approximately three times the 1983 level and it is estimated that because of this about 800,000 lives are being saved each year by current immunisation programs. But of course that is only touching the surface. It is important--

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Peacock The Hon A.S.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 20 March 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has New Zealand's stance on the visits of United States ships to its ports resulted in 22 military exercises programmed for 1986 being cancelled or restructured and approximately 6000 man days of training being lost.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The disagreement between the United States and New Zealand has not resulted in the cancellation of any Australian sponsored combined exercises, nor have any training opportunities been lost by Australia. Twelve exercises were previously listed as ANZUS exercises. These exercises are now conducted as separate bilateral exercises between Australia and the United States, or Australia and New Zealand.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Australia, New Zealand and United States: Defence Budget

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Peacock The Hon A.S.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 20 March 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What has been the additional cost to the Defence budget as a result of specific exercises carried out with New Zealand following the break down of tripartite co-operation under the ANZUS alliance.
(2) How are these costs broken up.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (2) I refer the honourable member to my answer to question on notice No. 3155 (Hansard, 13 March 1986, page 1389).

QUESTION.SPEAKER: White Mr P.N.D.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism, upon notice, on 8 April 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has he stated that Australia does not have the tourist infrastructure to cope with a large number of Japanese tourists.

(2) Is it a fact that the 1984-85 annual report of his Department indicates that (a) average room occupancy in Australia falls as low as 53 per cent and (b) firm commitments in the construction of tourism accommodation at June 1985 were $3,500 million.
(3) Has he referred the matter of tourist infrastructure to the Kennedy Committee for investigation; if not, will he do so.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon J.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) I refer the honourable member to my answer in the House of Representatives on 29 November 1985 to a substantially similar question without notice from Mr Jull and to my subsequent press release of 6 December 1985.
(a) My Department's 1984-85 annual report indicated that in the four quarters to March 1985 hotel and motel room occupancy rates did not fall below 53.8 per cent.
(3) No. I would not wish to delay the work of the inquiry by adding substantially to its terms of reference at this late stage.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Carlton The Hon J.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Local Government and Administrative Services, upon notice, on 10 April 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What was the cost of the (a) site and (b) construction of the carpark in Cowper Wharf Roadway, Woolloomooloo, New South Wales.
(2) How many car spaces were provided.
(3) What is the average level of occupancy of the carpark.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Uren The Hon T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (a) The Commonwealth obtained the site for the Department of defence in an exchange with the local council for Commonwealth land which was transferred to the council for the re-alignment of a roadway. I am advised by the Department of Defence in respect of the remaining issues that;
(b) The carpark was completed at a cost of $19.83 million which included $2.26m for demolitions, relocation of services, roadways, etc.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Department of Science: Payments to Mr Phillip Adams and Mr Rod Cameron

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Downer Mr A.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Science, upon notice, on 14 April 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: What (a) were the amounts paid to and (b) projects undertaken by Mr Phillip Adams and Mr Rod Cameron, their associated companies, or principals of those companies, for work on behalf of the Minister's Department or authorities under the Minister's control in (i) 1983-84, (ii) 1984-85 and (iii) 1985-86 to the date of answering this question.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Jones The Hon B.O.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (a) The amounts paid to Mr Phillip Adams are (i) 1983-84-Nil (ii) 1984-85-$1,293.00 and (iii) 1985-86-$601.00. Payments made to his associated company Monahan Dayman and Adams Pty Ltd are (i) 1983-84-Nil (ii) 1984-85-Nil and (iii) 1985-86-$6,666.23. The payments to Mr Phillip Adams relate to his statutory office of Chairman of the Commission for the Future and were paid for sitting fees, in accordance with the rates set by the Remuneration Tribunal. The payments to Monahan Dayman and Adams Pty Ltd relate to reimbursement of moneys paid by the company for Mr Adams airfares, accommodation, taxi fares and telephone calls for attendance at Commission meetings and for the transaction of other Commission business. No payments have been made to Mr Rod Cameron or his company.

(b) There have been no projects undertaken by either Mr Phillip Adams or Mr Rod Cameron or their associated companies in (i) 1983-84, (ii) 1984-85 and (iii) 1985-86 to the date of answering this question.
